content:
Posted: December 1, 2015
												Easily one of the best roguelikes out there. I'd put it at number 2 in my book.The companions are terrific; each have their own stories and quests. I don't think I've ever seen a roguelike with a story that was actually compelling. The spell casting is phenomenal, something I could never enjoy in Nethack, Slash'em, and other turnbased roguelikes.Terrific soundtracks, another thing that many roguelikes lack. I'd say on-par, maybe better, than FTL soundtracks.IMO, this game has an excellent balance of luck vs tactical sense (Its not a total crapshoot but there is enough randomness to make repeat playthroughs rewarding and fun.Incredible sense of adventure as you flee the oncoming doom from the west; different biomes offer unique challenges and enemies.Most people don't realize there are actually THREE ways to win. If you think you da man just because you stomped the demon lord, think again. You ain't done yet, lil ♥♥♥♥♥.And... its 87 cents during sales. You could buy a soda... or you could save half that money and buy a game with at least 20 hours of content. What a time to be alive.

It seems like more and more roguelikes are hitting the market these days and while some of them are 'meh', this one most certainly isn't. content:
Posted: March 6, 2014
												Though the idea of a "time-limited RPG" threw me off at first, I quickly realized that this game has such huge potential, and is a very fun game. If you can get past the first few playthroughs without wanting to hit a cheatcode button for every monster that chases you, then you have a very playable and fun game. The game is set in the style of an old Japanese RPG but with the twist of the Darkness coming from the left side of the screen, essentially moving roughly 1/3 - 5/12 of a block every turn. You have to continue running to the right and beating off monsters that hunt you down like a wild animal. There are multiple difficulty levels in this game, starting with a Walk in the Park difficulty, which is where the End-Boss appears at 400 km and you get npcs to help you when he appears (basically easy mode). There are multiple choices of class in this game, each with it's own Steam achievement, and each with it's own unique skill set/passive stats. The 8 different classes are Swordmaster, Knight, Hunter, Pirate, Bard, Adventurer, Force User (Mage), and Hero. Some of the classes are rather overpowered, where they can one hit anything with a sword or axe that has at least 10-15 Attack power, and some of them are very weak, requiring you to play like a coward and run until you can get a Holy item or find equipment that makes you super powered. Although there is a lack of creativity in the active skills of each class (basically just Awakening, and some skill you learn at level 1), the uniques are nice to play around with. For example, the pirate has a maxed out Swimming unique, where he uses only 1 turn to swim instead of 5. In terms of playability with the classes, you essentially master one, usually the Hero class, and run through the whole thing playing strategically.There is an element of playability where you can transfer over items that you really like or want to use on a different playthrough called the Dimensional Vault. After you die or beat the game, you can place items, up to a limit, in the Vault and access it through your next character. This was a nice idea, but I feel like instead of having a NPC that you have to talk to in order to access it, there should be an option to ask you if you want to access your vault at the very beginning of the game, after you've already started. Another thing the developers added were perks. There is a very limited number of perks, and it's a nice addition. Lastly, there is the Heroics leve ratings, where you get rated from F - SS on how well you did in the criteria of Levels, Battles, Chests looted, and Distance. This was really sweet, and there is also the bonus points that you get for certain actions, like killing no friendly characters. This portion makes you want to play again until you get it right, and I loved it. It could definitely be expanded upon.I really enjoyed the dimensions, but it feels very plain when using "Create random dimension". When you create a random dimension, it's just a normal dimension with everything placed around differently, no bonuses to equipment, unique NPCs that can join you, or any of that sort. It's just a map with the areas randomized. However, every day, the game updates a few special campaign dimension, about 3-4, and they have unique differences. Some have stronger monsters for more experience, others have a special NPC that you can recruit. Those are nice, but they only change once a day, and though it's a nice catch to get people to play every day, when you beat the game a couple times, it gets very boring and you lose interest of even looking at the list.That being said, the time you do spend playing this game would be worth it, especially for a low price. It's super cheap, fun for a good amount of time, and you can replay through the campaigns as much as you want. The perks are very limited however, and I do hope they update it to have a comprehensive list of unique skills, and possibly vary the classes more to feel more balanced.

Posted: March 4, 2014
												An excellent game, able to be played in short bursts or over long periods it offers a good mix of challenge and ease of entry. It has several classes most of which play differently enough to feel like you are actually playing different classes rather than just the same class reskinned twenty times. A surprising variety of enemy types also help to keep the combat fresh and the looming threat of both the demon lord and the darkness keeps things tense as you try to make the best use of what resources and time you have.To top it off the random maps mean that while you can have the same adventure over and over if you want to there's always something fresh to do.

content:
Posted: March 5, 2014
												Worth noting:+It's only like £2, and for that price you get a pretty expansive rouge like.+Randomly generated areas combined with ticking down clock for boss appearences makes it fun to replay after a while away+It's got a good gimmick - you have to keep moving right or die, which means movements should be careful.+Can grab a dimension name from a friend in order to play their experiences, so you can organize group races easily+Really nice looking GUI, so you don't need a tileset unless you want to mix it up or hate 2d for some reason-As of right now, there's only like 7 or so classes in the game and about as many perks (excluding stat upgrades), so-Monster appearence, even on afternoon stroll (normal difficulty) is kinda limited, but I've only just started...-Offer small dungeons and towns, but the constant eating of the left side of the screen offers little time to reap their benefitsI've not logged as many hours as I'd like into this game, so I may put up a second critique later. But if you've got £2 to spare and want to get started in the rougelike genre, this game is practically a steal. I'd really recommend getting it.

content:
Posted: March 9, 2014
												One Way Heroics is a lot of fun.  It has four difficulties (plus an added setting to make things even harder,) three main endings, as well as several epilogues based on the allies that you manage to recruit along the way, and limitless replay value, thanks to short playtimes, unlockables, and the ability to transfer a limited number of items from one playthrough to the next.  The world is ending, and unlike every other rpg ever made, the threat is very obvious and imminent.  As you run, behind you the world is being devoured by the darkness, and you along with it if you dally.  You have to find the best equipment you can, upgrade it, level up, and recruit any allies that might be willing to help, and stop the Darkness from destroying the world by any means necessary.Edit:  One Way Heroics Plus only adds even more reason to play.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 2, 2014
												Fun game, I really recommend it for it's price. Basically, you're just running right in an 8-bit, procedurally-generated world, trying to become as strong as you can by fighting enemies and picking up a ton of different pieces of equipment and items before the final boss of the world comes to ♥♥♥♥ your♥♥♥♥♥♥up. There's an interesting gimmick involved though, you can't just stop and grind on enemies or bother trying to crack open a chest because darkness is forever swallowing the world from the left. This makes things incredibly interesting, because every step you take is another few pixels or so that the darkness is moving towards you. Every "turn" you take to attack, every person you talk to, every shop you enter, every enemy you kill is another chance for the darkness to eat your world. It's really a fun game, and it's a great price, so if this looks interesting to you, go ahead and get it!

content:
Posted: March 7, 2014
												By far this game is one of my most favorite  indie games ever. I've played quite a few inclusing Bastion and things like Trine but this is on a different level. Its simple, combat is flawless  and easy to work with. You can survive sometimes by just spamming  'z' on monsters and get away with like 2hp.But the game is not about surving. You need to build up your character, make decisions on whether to give up 5 lvls to increase stats such as strength. There are so many different variations it's nearly endless fun. There are different gamemodes , many classes with their unique skill set and many types of weapons. Also one of the key things i love about the game is the amount of save files, when they were making this game i'm certai nthey wanted to let ur imagination go wild so they gave u tons X_XIn conclusion, this game will rekindle that feeling you ever had when u played games like Pokemon Mystery Dungeon. Along the way you gain new allies, and based on your choices they might leave as quickly as they go.BTW THE SOUNDTRACK IS ONE OF THE BEST EVER !My rate-4.5/5 starsHave Fun :D

												One Way Heroics surprised me immensely. For 3 dollars you are getting a real gem.

content:
Posted: March 8, 2014
												I'd like to start by saying that I bought this game on a whim (mostly persuaded by the $3 price-tag).  I rarely spend less than a week considering whether to by a game or not.I've only just scratched the surface of this game (3 runs so far), and yet I'm already so happy with it.  There's a large variance of items, the character types and skills feel unique from one another, and even though the game is constantly pushing you forwards (it's quite literally "One Way"), I don't feel rushed at all while playing.  It's an excellent game to play for a short break or a long session of multiple games, and the RPG & Rouge-Like elements blend seamlessly.  On top of that, it has a top-notch soundtrack and intuitive scoring system.I can't even say all of these things about some AAA titles.  This is a small Indie game.  If there's one Indie game under $5 that's worth your time, it's this one.  I would go as far as to recommend it to people who have never even glanced at a Rouge-Like before.

content:
Posted: March 4, 2014
												One Way Heroics has a straightforward but great concept. I was just about to overlook this game and not buy it but brought myself to anyway. Did I regret it? Definitely not. Why? A small price to pay for several hours of game gameplay and replayability. Was it worth it? I don't know about you but if I followed the concept of "$1 = 1 hour gameplay" then this is definitely worth lots more than what it's priced at. -Overviews and stuff- (if you just want the opinion go straight to it)You play as the "almighty" hero and continue travelling right to take down the demon lord who is slowly consuming the world in darkness. This darkness will continue following you throughout your travels. The game will also happily remind you that the very left side of your screen is death and despair and you don't want to be caught in it otherwise it'll eviscerate you......or something along those lines. There are several dimensions and special ones every now and then. This means you may share a dimension with friends (though you won't see them, you'll see how they did).In case you don't know what rogue-likes are, they are basically games that start you at level 1 and if you end up at the game over screen you have to start the game all over again, at level 1. Games like these however will allow you to carry certain 'things' over to your next playthrough. In this case, you'll be allowed to carry a limited amount of items you found across your previous travels (the limit of items can be increased as well).With One Way Heroics, you'll want to explore as much of an area as you can because you cannot stick around for long, and this is the part I liked best about this game. Exploring dungeons is risky because walls end up being an obstacle (and possibly sandwich you with the darkness if you can't get out). Don't stick around towns for too long as you'll want to do what you need to do then get out so then they can die and you'll continue on your journey.There's quite a number of items you can obtain in-game, dungeons to explore and as you finish your playthrough, you'll see your "Heroic rating". Depending on your rating, you'll earn certain amounts of Heroic points to use to unlock perks, classes and the cap limit of your dimensional vault. What you do affects your rating (challenging yourself can be rewarding as well). Perks are upgrades to your hero and you may change them to however you like. Extra perks are unlockable if you earn enough points for them. As for classes, you may either use your points on buying them OR you can unlock them for free by doing the objective for them. Dimensional vaults can be used to carry items from your last playthroughs and into your new game. The cap limit can be increased with heroic points and become more costly the more space you have.-Opinion(s)-There's a lot to why I find this game enjoyable but I'll tell you the main ones.1. The concept is pretty simple, and when it comes to concepts, I usually prefer simple ones. It's how you execute the concept is what appeals to me the most. This game actually did a great job at it and you'll be reminded very 'clearly' as well. I personally liked it and of course, this is basically my opinion of it. It'll either be a hit or a miss. Definitely a hit for me.2. Usually when it comes to RPG, I tend to think that there will be a lot of items that aren't neccessary but are there anyway for the quanitity. Most cases I prefer quality over quantity and in this case, it was the right amount for either two. You won't find many things necessary but they are useful items so it is completely up to you how you want to play and you'll have a variety of items to venture with.3. The gameplay mechanics are simple but for this top-down it also features diagonals (yes, very strange for a top-down to certain people but this added more of a challenge and I enjoyed it). I enjoy playing with a controller and I'm glad I don't have to actually use my mouse or keyboard at all to play this game.4. Music. Why? It was great to listen to when I played the game and never thought about turning it off.5. After you die or finish the game, you get to choose a variety of messages to tell others how you died or survived the struggle in dimensions. Even if the game ends, I'll be left satisfied with these messages (and unlocking more stuff).6. Bread crusts. You'll understand once you play the game and meet the chefs.Overall, I was very close to missing out this amazing game. I usually don't play top-downs, rogue-likes and what not but this game, whether you play games like this or not, I recommend you at least give it a go. It's not a grindfest and it's not too hard to pick up as well. It's also a cheap game, whether you get it on sale or not. This game was worth buying for just a few bucks.

content:
Posted: March 11, 2014
												Take (a kinder version of) Rogue Legacy's "death gains you currency to improve all future runs" mechanic, put it in a more traditional turn-based, top-down roguelike format, and remove the ability to head left without risking death massively. Congratulations: you've got One-Way Heroics down relatively well. Add in the concept of daily challenge worlds a la Spelunky HD, and you have a killer combo - every day, random custom worlds show up for everyone to play in, and the deaths of others can benefit you directly. Find someone's corpse and gain XP/items from it... but be careful, god only knows if what killed them is going to come out for you as a result.It's a solid roguelike with interesting mechanics and "permadeath" that still gains you progress. Plus it is CHEAP AS HELL. If you aren't interested by this description, dodge it, but I really can't add more to this without going stupidly in-depth on mechanics and I think you should be able to pick out your choice from here.

That only begs for a more important question -  Why can't you love One Way Heroics?Library, New start, gameplay and the end. The cycle of a steam game and the end of playtime. Though we mostly have unplayed games in our library, we want to give each and every one of them at least a try. It is in such desperate times we find ourselves caught between playing League of Legends or playing a few minutes on Steam, as we don't have enough time for all the games we own. However, this one is a very important game you must try.Although One Way Heroics is like a piece of artwork, even the most popular one might not be suited for everyone. It's for that I spend so much time writing these great reviews.  Despite how much we bare ourselves, no matter the cost, no matter the repercussions, there is always something more to say about a good game... but sometimes it is best to not say anything and just let the game communicate it's strengths and weaknesses, and take the gameplay over reviews.This is one of those unique games. I highly recommend it even if it is sometimes very unforgiving (example: playing force user and not finding a single energy item for 800 turns).9.5/10

number of helpful: 6 of 8 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 1, 2016
												A modern side-scroller roguelike with anime-style graphics. It has most of the hallmark features of the roguelike genre -- procedurally generated world, tactical turn-based gameplay, interesting items (although much simpler than in big roguelikes such as ADOM or DCSS), multiple classes to choose from. The main thing which set its apart than other roguelikes is the side-scroller aspect -- the world is constantly moving to the right, and you lose if you don't move along. There are also some important aspects which are a bit anti-roguelike. One is that there are "save crystals" which can be used to save your game, but they felt more like an option for casual players -- the game seems balanced for permadeath play. Another aspect is that, after your game ends, you can store some of your items in the "dimensional vault", and use them in your next games -- this goes a bit against the traditional roguelike style, where your every game starts exactly the same as your first -- and when you win, you know that you won because you have learned the skills, not because the game became easier. However, I don't see it as a problem in the case of this game.One problem I have with this game is that it does not run in Linux -- I run it via Wine, but this is inconvenient, and I lose music, which is apparently good.In my opinion, it is far from the best games in the roguelike genre, but I still recommend playing it.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 24, 2016
												Taking One Way Heroics to a new level, Plus adds almost double the content with new classes, enemies, features and more. Defeat the Demon Lord in a whole different dimension with this unmissable addition. Literlly the DLC and the Whole entire game in a nutshellIf you are a fan of Rouge like Dungeons / Openworlds like Minecraft - Binding Of Issac series, and Cyrpt of the Necrodancer. Then this game is also a must in your inventory of wonderous games.I personally would like to say I spent countless hours offline and online on this game. Trust me, it may look low now. But I spent 100+ of hours playing this... Why? I had worlds to explore. I maybe explored over 1000+ worlds and yet have to save not even 40% of them yet. You get to choose your class and you are already set to go on a journey of a everlasting battle of darkness. Not only that,  the darkness is actually a dragon!  is also a very impending doom of your very world you travel and  saving!Fear not, you have time on your hand. No joke, time is of the essance and so is key placement, fighting, item usage and your weapon durability. May I also say you have a day/night cycle? Vision ? More over that you have Bonuses and debuffs? Even more so you can find allies! Even if you're willing to sacrifice some of your levels,  A bard and hero is more sufficient in creating a co-op NPC!  you can obtain some Cooperating Enemies or other misc!. The content of the first game is already a great stand alone game. But the expansion far over gives it more power and bang for your buck. Even at a sale price, the game is fantastic. The updates are nearly weekly and they are on the clock * LOL PUNS* constantly checking for bugs and patching new campaigns.The classes are easy to understand, the game mechanics simply easy to use, and if delt well , very useful to master. As time, placements, and generally the whole landscape. You too can already learn the many ways of becoming heroic.There is also a _Afterdeath_ Screen where you can save, trade, expend, repair, and increase your items you collected in your traveling of the worlds. Hell you can even gain items you can't get in certain campaings. But if you complete it , you gain special other perks, even endings you can get if you finally get them! Game has perks in it... PERKS! Even Debuffs that make your heroic level skyrocket, but not for the faint of heart. As the Debuffs increase levels, yes, but make your game FAR more Harder and more time pinching then the other easy pickings. Even if you think you got a nice going class you like and you unlock another and gain them the right set for them. You want to try to get more classes. The DLC does that for you, it adds 4 more classes, ON TOP with more perks, settings, increase in more items, drops, enemies. Even more campaigns you can do in your  Castle Renavations and also other main / side quests!  More toys to find. Even going beyond the limit. The world never ends. The Pros  Rouge Like - Infinite Possiblities  Low Price   Trading Cards  Retro Gameplay with innovative tactics.  Weekly Updates / New Campaigns   Great for Game Stuffers and Collectors!  Great storyline - Mini Campaigns with Plots and Events  Great Quick Game for short players - Walk in the Park if you have a break in your schedule!The Cons  Time Waster - Somewhat good too.   Slightly challenging to a new RPG Player if not prepared -  Be Fairly Warned - If going for harder campaigns and doing it for cheevies, I suggest trying to use Hero / Knight Classes to survive if not, Bet your heroic tush goodbye! [spoiler/]  No Multiplayer Base - But What you expect? I said *Co-op* but it's your Allies you make in game.  Options and HUD UI a bit ... Cluttered but I let it slide as it trying to keep all your info in the game as you travel without the need of constant back tracking.All in All A very great game, I love it, I play it, I am Addictted to it.In my score I give it 9.2 / 10 Review9.5/10 - Gameplay9.0/10 - Music / OST9.0/10 - Graphics8.5/10 - Storyline10/10  - Creativity and Originality

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 1, 2014
												As I've mentioned before and is somewhat common knowledge about a niche genre, every rogue-like is a balancing act between luck and skill to varying degrees. One Way Heroics, to its credit, trends more toward skill from my play time so far. There are moments of failure, but they are logical moments. "Whoops. Forgot about the scrolling screen of doom.""Whoops. Ignored the icon above an enemy showing it's a miniboss.""Whoops. Forgot about my potions."That's what is refreshing about the game; every failure makes sense. Often, that isn't the case in other examples of the genre. Each game has its own unique learning curve and priorities, of course. But this isn't the kind of game where you decide to drink a potion and roll the dice on it being poison or acid. It's far more structured than that, with information clearly presented to the player. This ensures that any difficulty is genuine, and not just a random number generator. I can appreciate that.Aside from that noteworthy benefit, One Way Heroics is pretty cool on its own merits. Classic pixellated graphics aren't rare, but the game uses them in a charming way rather than seeming budget-minded. The scrolling mechanic is fairly unique, and adds elements of point-focused gaming such as Cannabalt. It's a simple thing, but executed just right to encourage that "one more run" mindset. In short: I got this game less than a day ago, and I already feel like I've got my money's worth and then some. Give it a shot.

content:
Posted: March 4, 2014
												This is a pretty good turn-based RPG for $3. It's short (less than an hour to reach the end) but the replay value is mostly what keeps the game interesting.You start out with 2 classes and unlock several more as you play through the game's randomly-generated worlds. You can also carry items from game to game, and they'll be available from the start. As you're forced to keep moving to the right, you have to plan your actions more than you would in something like early Final Fantasy games. You can take things at your own pace for the most part and One Way Heroics isn't too difficult. If you mess up, the game will give you hints, and you have a couple of abilities to make things go easier. If you want a more difficult game you don't have to use them, and there are multiple difficulty settings. Save points can be easy or hard to find, depending on your luck and where you go.I don't like that weapons and armor have a limited number of uses, but since you can upgrade stuff it would probably be game-breaking to have unlimited uses on things. A couple of playthroughs would give you way-too-powerful weapons.Overall this is a decent game to get, and the price is adequately low. If you see it on sale for less than $1 you can't go wrong buying One Way Heroics.

content:
Posted: May 21, 2016
												"One Way Heroics" is a great roguelike where you play as a hero who tries to stop the darkness from swallowing the world - literally. You are forced to travel to the right in your quest as the darkness destroys everything from the left. Each world you save unlocks more classes, perks and other bonuses that bring you closer to solving the mystery behind the threat that engulfs endless worlds.The gameplay is quite well balanced, allowing for different playstyles. The variety of difficulties, campaign types and options encourage players of all skill levels to continue moving forward. While the art could use some improvement, the music is decent and the story is quite interesting and well-written."One Way Heroics" brings the excitement of permanent death while giving players many reasons to keep trying again. I highly recommend the game to both roguelike veterans and those new to the genre. Do consider buying the DLC - "One Way Heroic Plus", as it adds even more content, features and replay value

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 3, 2014
												Despite its ridiculously tiny native resolution (which you can scale up) and its random crashes, OWH is a fantastic take on the roguelike, boiled down to its most simplest form - keep moving, and hack at everything.  Well, that's kind of trivializing it a bit as there are a bunch of abilities, weapons, and generally oodles of lootles to find and methods of keeping them from game to game.  There's also a save system, so it's not entirely roguelike at all, but close to a J-ARPG from the dayes of Yore.Ahem... the main mechanic of the game is that the world is constantly scrolling into oblivion (the game is turn-based so as long as you stand still, nothing happens) and you need to keep moving right until you meet the boss.  If you make it that far.  If you can survive.  If you brought/found the right gear.Regardless, success or fail, once you've concluded a run, you earn Hero Points in order to unlock character classes, abilities, perks, and most importantly, slots for your DImensional Vault.  Whazzat?  Easy - it's a safe to store items you've found so you can give it to the next hero you roll.  Pretty simple stuff.Presentation is great, sounds are perfectly retrofit, and the only hit against it (considering this thing is priced less than a hamburger) is that it's a bit unstable.  Good thing there's a save system.Anyways, if you have money in your pocket, you could spend it on stupider things than One Way Heroics; don't.  This game will satisfy you more than glitter putty ever could.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 3, 2014
												One Way Heroics is a fine example of a miniature Roguelike done right. Character building isn't tremendously deep, and the randomly-generated environments are never fiercely different from one another, but the constant pressure from its unique side-scrolling progression affords precious little time to test the boundaries as you press on, resulting in an experience that always feels satisfyingly complex despite its lighthearted presentation.The premise and gameplay are dually summed up with this statement: The world is being swallowed up by a deadly shadow ever creeping from the west, and your only means of surviving long enough to undo this cataclysm is to travel east with the shadow ever at your heels. You pick your character's name, class, gender, a handful of flavorful perk, and prepare to go right a whole lot.One Way Heroics likes to keep things light. Classes are differentiated by variations in starting stats, plus one or two spells to break out when the going gets rough. Maps are relatively linear, with occasional obstacle mazes to keep players light on their feet and miniature dungeons and towns to venture into when there are a few extra turns to burn. Not that there often are, of course, as every turn scrolls the screen a bit more to the left, and getting swallowed up by the left side of the screen is fatal. The decision to enter a stone dungeon isn't one to be taken lightly, though neither is anything else. Using an item, equipping a weapon, or speaking to an NPC is just as dangerous as any other action that isn't stepping to the right, but as the monsters grow fiercer the further east you go, deviating from the main path to grab extra equipment or visit a merchant is often prudent.One would think laying this mechanic on top of an otherwise traditional roguelike would make the experience drastically more difficult, yet surprisingly, One Way Heroics is not that bloodthirsty a game. Actual victory is a completely attainable goal, and not neccesarily all that challenging a task (unless you want it to be). Your character will only last the length of one run, but "horrible, horrible death" isn't necessarily going to be the reason for their retirement. It's a nice feeling.With comparatively few options for character development, streamlined combat, and limited variety to be found even in the mix-and-match biomes of the extremely linear maps, One Way Heroics doesn't run quite as deep as the games it seeks to emulate, yet unlike many mass-production Roguelikes it still manages to capture pretty much all of the fundamental qualities that make the genre great, all while introducing unique and memorable mechanics to set itself apart from the crowd.Whether you're a newcomer to the genre seeking something unintimidating but satisfying or a long-time Roguelike fan looking for something simple and unique, One Way Heroics is worth a fortune more than its humble price tag, and should be investigated as soon as possible.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 3, 2014
												Warning: Not to be underestimated.One-Way Heroics combines turn-based combat, side scrolling arcade style gameplay, limited saves, and a hearty dose of classic RPG nostalgia. It also ranks in difficulty with the likes of Mega-Man, Ninja Gaiden, and Castlevania. The foundation of Heroics would make it seem like two things that should never go together. On the left side of the screen, the world fades into a Darkness that consumes men, women,  children, small animals, dungeon bosses, buildings, eveything. It is your job to find out what is causing the darkness by travelling to the ends of the earth and defeating the source (oh, and the final boss has finally attained some common sense, and will randomly spawn in an effort to kill you before you get enough power and equipment to wreck his world.)  It would start to sound as if it's an infinite runner (akin to Temple Run and Flappy Bird).And then there are the RPG elements.Randomly generated worlds, item upgrades, exploration, looting, unlockable perks and classes, the element of permadeath between save points (random enemy drops and treasures will not be the same after continuing from a save file), and the random enemy attributes lead one to question their sanity. Each playthrough is different. You have the option to create a new random world every time that you start a new game, but you can also play through the same world as different classes.There are 8 different classes in total, (Only the Knight and Swordmaster are available at the start, but with additional playthroughs, the roster expands with Hunter, Pirate, Bard, Adventurer, Force User, and Hero) with very different play styles. Swordmasters are tough, but it comes at a cost to stamina and carrying capacity. Hunters, however, are better suited to stealth, ranged weapons, and have a special ability that allows them to see off-screen enemies before they encounter them.All in all, it's got great addictive gameplay, the sprite animations are charming, the music is fantastic , and I would give this an 8-8.5

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 25, 2014
												So no bulls-hit, One Way Heroics is possibly my favorite game of the year so far. It's neck and neck with Banner Saga, and though Banner Saga definitely has a greater immersion factor, the pick-up-and-play roguelike aspects and the replayability of OWH put it over the top.What you have here is a game with the energy and fun of a classic Japanese RPG on the Super Nintendo, but with the ruthless difficulty and randomness of a roguelike. However, the developer very wisely simplifies the roguelike formula, so that you are not playing an overly complicated survival simulation; you are playing a game that feels both fun and intense; it is demanding of your judgment without being a drain on the limits of your attention span.It's not perfect; once you've seen the 3 or 4 variations of "towns" and "dungeons" in the game they'll get stale quick. Enemy and landscape variety becomes a little threadbare after a few (successful) playthroughs as well. Also, even in full screen mode, the characters are ridiculously small. Don't even bother trying to play in windowed mode. You might as well go outside and stare at ants.The achievements are very good as well; they're almost all challenge-oriented, encouraging you to push your skills to their limit, rather than go out of your way to fulfill random garbage achievements (I'm looking at you, Rogue's Tale).One Way Heroics is a badass game, especially for the price.

content:
Posted: May 21, 2016
												"One Way Heroics" is a great roguelike where you play as a hero who tries to stop the darkness from swallowing the world - literally. You are forced to travel to the right in your quest as the darkness destroys everything from the left. Each world you save unlocks more classes, perks and other bonuses that bring you closer to solving the mystery behind the threat that engulfs endless worlds.The gameplay is quite well balanced, allowing for different playstyles. The variety of difficulties, campaign types and options encourage players of all skill levels to continue moving forward. While the art could use some improvement, the music is decent and the story is quite interesting and well-written."One Way Heroics" brings the excitement of permanent death while giving players many reasons to keep trying again. I highly recommend the game to both roguelike veterans and those new to the genre. Do consider buying the DLC - "One Way Heroic Plus", as it adds even more content, features and replay value

content:
Posted: March 22, 2015
												*tl;dr:This game is basically walking to the right side, while avoiding the darkness that keeps eating everything from the left side, with RPG elements and randomized world.*-The game has different classes.-Each world is different (randomized).-The game has good difficulty modes (They are not too easy and not inhumanly hard)-You level up your character, by gaining exp from creatures that spawn around the world or in dungeons.-The game has multiple classes that you need to unlock. Each class has different strenghts and weaknesses.-Each class levels different stats up faster. For example the sorcerer levels inteligents faster than the knight class.-Story is scattered. You need to beat the game multiple times on different difficulties and with different characters, to find out more about the story.-Great replay value if you like walking east every time.Overall I'd say this is a good game for the completionists, who dont mind doing the same thing in a randomized world over and over again.I wouldn't recommend buying this if you're not planning on spending hours unlocking the characters and the different endings or difficulties.DLC EDIT:-Monster spawn more and items spawn randomly, so no more waiting or sitting around-More items have been added and the spawn rate has been reworked so powerfull items are more rare-More story has been added and the main story has been completed.-Mini bosses have been added-Random events have been added-More terrain has been added-More NPC's and shops/dungeons have been addedThe DLC is a great addition to the game, the events, mini bosses and random loot will keep you busy during your runs, while the extra quests and companions will keep you coming back for more.(I apologise for my bad english)

content:
Posted: March 6, 2016
												TLDR:  Only buy this game if you get it WITH the expansion, and preferably on sale.  The reason I don't recommend it is because One Way Heroics is still an incomplete game, with the expansion and all.The review:After 70 hours playtime, I can't recommend One Way Heroics.  Without the expansion (One Way Heroics Plus, $6.49), this game is borderline unplayable.  The expansion brings in much needed UI updates, gameplay tweaks, more items and more characters.  And a ton of bug fixes.Problem is, most of that stuff should have been patched in to the base game.  Or, more realistically, put in to the game before it ever released.  Especially since, even with all that, it still feels like a beta version.  Very late in the beta process, but still not quite ready for release.  Somewhere in the polishing phase.  Bugs are still being squashed to this day, and I experienced plenty in my time with the game. Once you take all the things from OWH+, and subtract them out since they should have been included in the main game prior to release, you're left with just the new classes and the castle expansions.  And they aren't worth $6.49 by themselves.  The classes are easy to gloss over, and none of the castle expansions have a huge impact on your game.  You can easily do without both.With a bit of a shallow story, one that was also poorly translated, the gameplay is what keeps you coming back.  And it's (almost) all there... so long as you make sure to pick up OWH+ as well.

content:
Posted: May 15, 2015
												It's really fun. You'll stumble around for hours until you start to figure out the little secrets to winning. By no means easy, but despite the simple nature of the game it completely hooks you and you lose about 20 hours in a week to it.If you want to know what it plays like, imagine how Binding of Issac uses seeds to determine items and layout (only you're not punished for using them), then imagine you play bumper cars (ie ram them) with enemies to damage them and finally  add some "multiplayer" where you can see progress of other adventures in the same seed. If they die, you can find their ghosts and get free stuff. Then imagine all this on a auto scroller.Talking about it really isn't the same as playing it. It's really robust, despite the simplicity. There's like 8 classes, and you can fully customize your starting stats and abilities, which really changes everything. Great game, and it's dirt cheap. Have about 22 hours, and I spent less than a dollar on it. Give a try, you might just love it.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 9, 2015
												This is the sort of game that feels really well realized.The gimmick of One Way Heroics is the constant movement of the screen to the right. This may seem like a simple mechanic, or maybe something that would limit the fun you could have, but it's honestly what makes this game so addicting.You have to plan ahead. If you blindly rush into any dungeon you see you'll likely find yourself stuck behind a wall, frantically trying to break it down as the darkness creeps up from behind. You have to consider whether you can clear it before the darkness catches up, whether you have the HP and gear required to take on the monsters inside, and whether to advance into a room or wait and let the mobs come at you one by one.It encourages you to pack all those items that you'd discard without a second thought in other games. Scroll of Confusion? Use it on the Demon Lord so you can run away while he flails randomly. Teleportation Pill? Use it when caught behind a mountain range and pray it drops you on the other side. (Seriously, watch the map. Mountains are just as dangerous as monsters.) Nayuta Fruit? Use it when in a snow area to replenish your energy. Big stone? . . . Leave it, this one is actually useless.The character classes are reasonably varied. Each class starts with different stats and abilities depending on what their purpose is. For instance, the Knight has the Great Wall ability, which lets him regen health every turn. While the Bard has the Song of Heroism, which increases party members damage and defence. There's also an adventurer class, with stats that make him perfect for stashing as much loot as possible.The world generation is simple, but effective. You'll be seeing the same tiles over and over again, with few real differences between the biomes. Thing is, it's the layout that matters, not the scenery. It's the generation of Alters of the Goddess, towns, Dark Brotherhood hidouts, and Golems (Be very prepared before you try to take these things on) that make each new world interesting.After each run you'll be awarded Hero Points which you can spend to unlock new perks, classes, and expand your Vault. (In which you can store items from your previous run, in order to use them in the next.)The last feature, and judging from the other reviews here also the most unappreciated, are the story missions. These change every day, one day you'll be accompanied by the healer Dosey, the next you'll be tasked with rescuing the Queen. Each of these NPCs have different stories which you'll learn more about as you fight with them. These really make adventuring more interesting, and are a nice addition to the game. They didn't have to be there, but it's nice that they are.One Way Heroics is, in my opinion, criminally underpriced. I fully recommend picking this up.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 4, 2016
												I've never posted a review of this game until now only because it's hard to find words to sum up how great it is without dragging the review on and on.Here's what you need to know.One Way Heroics is a relatively simple take on a lot of RPG elements woven into a roguelike fantasy. The system for gear statistics is pretty straightforward, as is the story-telling, as is leveling up. There are no skill trees or any choice of what stat you level up, but I promise you it won't matter.That being said, the simplicity is nice. It allows you to play the game casually without taking away that constant strive some players have for better gear or "the perfect run".The combat is also quite simple. You have a basic attack you will use most of the time, as well as a few abilities learned from leveling or NPC's. It's quick, with you likely not spending more than 5 seconds on most enemies besides bosses. It keeps the game moving, which is nice because in a roguelike its important not to drag things out. This also allows you to keep the game short if that's what you want. Personally my average session is maybe 2 hours long, but if you insist on going as far as 2000km (which isn't neccessary to win), it's a bit closer to 4 or 5 hours. Optional saves make those long games far less daunting.As I said, this game can work for casual players, but it does not leave the more dedicated players with nothing to do. 170 hours as I'm writing this review and there is still more to do. The game has a few interesting objectives woven into it to DRASTICALLY increase replay value, such as daily campaigns that change up the rules of the procedurally generated worlds you play in, multiple bosses to defeat, 4-5 different difficulties and 4 different ways to "win" a playthrough. Also it has one particular aspect I love to see in roguelikes; you can transfer a limited amount of gear from one playthrough to another. This helps you to continue your quest for the absolute best gear by allowing you to keep enchanting gear instead of losing everything at the end of a playthrough. But it's not at all essential for beating the game if that's too easy for you ;)As for the "One Way Heroics Plus" expansion (without going into detail), it's not neccessary for enjoying the game. It's the icing on top of the cake, and the odds are you will want it at some point or another, so I suggest buying it right off the bat to really enhance the game.Whether you are looking for a game to waste a few hours on, or one to get really sucked into, you just can't go wrong with One Way Heroics.

content:
Posted: July 21, 2014
												Quite honestly one of the best roguelike RPG's i've played.There's a character creation system with a variety of classes, perks and appearances. Most need to be unlocked but there's quite a lot to get.The movement and battles are turn-based and the unique flavor to this particular game is a encroaching wall of darkness from the left that closes in each time you do something.(Move, attack, etc) This means you have to keep a eye on the darkness and consider wether to go on or maybe try to clear that one dungeon or pick up that one item in time.This creates a sense of pressure that makes for a fun atmosphere.There is a online aspect to the game in the form of death/milestone messages from other players in the same world that show up in the upper left of the screen.The worlds are randomly generated but there are specific types that have special quests or certain restrictions. There is also the ability to share world ID's with others so they can play the same world.For a fairly cheap price this is a great game to pick up.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 5, 2014
												So for those who don't know what this game is, let me first explain what my impression (and the tldr) of the game is:One Way Heroics is a new twist on (somewhat) rogue-like RPG's, bearing similarities to Shiren the Wanderer (the non-Atlus-screwed-up one) but with an urgency placed on time and what you do with it.Understandably, some people wouldn't call it a roguelike because of the save/load feature or the dimensional vault, but since you do not accumulate hero points after resuming a loaded game (after death), my interpretation has been that saving/loading is only a feature for those who are in it for the story content.  A good compromise imo.What I likedA creative take on this style of game.  I haven't seen anything like it -- the closest comparison would be Shiren the Wanderer.An objective (the demon lord) that plagues you from the start, but not impossible to vanquish once you have progressed enough.Party members that serve a purpose, but also have depth.  Like everything else in the game, they are not permanent.The music is fantastic.What I didn't like that others might likeI'm not a fan of visual novels (?), so the abundance of text serving as the beginning and end of your adventure is not something that is fulfilling for me.  It's very well written, imo, so I imagine JRPG / Story-reading fans will like this.No cursed items.  Unidentified items you can wear, but none of them cursed. :\  The only undiscovered attribute on an item that poses any uncertainty is the durability.The price is so low, it feels like I robbed some poor hard-working developer that just loves making games like this.  Playism's site says something about letting you pay what you want (donation-based I guess?), so hopefully some people have been more charitable towards this game.What I don't likeThere is no way to isolate the leaderboards to personal social groups - as a result, it's all meaningless information, sadly. :\  It would be great if I could see where I rate among my friends list.There's no underground -- Yah, it's a pretty big game already, sure.  But fantasy games need dungeons.  An intricate right-way-progressing dungeon would've made the screen edge much more intimidating.Those are my impressions of this game. :)

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 29, 2014
												Very fun twist on roguelikes, with streamlined and fast-paced gameplay, pleasant music and a highly addictive concept and progression format.Basically, this is like a roguelike game (such as Nethack or TOME4: Tales of Maj-Eyal), mixed with one of those old school platformer "scroller" stages where a wall of death is coming towards you. The combination and design makes progression interesting, as gameplay never really stagnates because of the wall keeping you moving forward and requiring you to make decisions. "Is it worth it to enter this dungeon? Will I have a way to get out in time? Can I reach the shopkeeper before the appraiser gets eaten by the darkness?". At the end, you have to battle the boss, the Demon Lord who summoned the wall of death, which packs quite a punch compared to everything else you fight. To aid you, you can find loot, money...all your traditional JRPG elements, but streamlined to be as fast-paced as possible.The presentation is a mixed bag. Sprites are tiny but appropriate, and look very much like what you'd expect in a Super NES RPG. Music is not the best ever, but makes itself noticeable when needed, and stays out of the way during the less exciting parts. Controls are very simple and consoley, but doesn't really need a pad to be enjoyed, as it controls with mostly 3 keys and directions. The interface is however quite confusing, with vital stats near the middle of the screen, with other stats at the bottom, buffs at the right...it's a bit all over the place and takes a bit to get used to, but at least you can get used to it after a couple rounds.Larger character artwork is also a mixed bag, with some portraits looking good, others looking kinda bland. Character design is very old-school JRPG medieval fantasy, a bit retro while at it, looks more 90s than 2010s if you get what I mean. I guess it is a good effort at looking old-school.As for gameplay decisions, it's all quite slick. Weapons have durability, but are usually easy enough to replace, and repairing is possible, while not straightforward. To compensate, the limit on enchantments, buffs and powerups for each individual weapon or armor is quite big, allowing to kind of craft superweapons with a bit of luck or planning, not too much. Dungeons, terrain and towns are terribly simplistic, but then again, you can't really stay more than a dozen turns in most places, so it works out for the best. There's plenty of decent loot lying around as well, although deciding what stuff to keep and what to drop to satisfy your weight limits can bring the action to a temporary halt as you ponder advantages and disadvantages, or wondering if that unidentified item is crap or highly enchanted.An average game from start to finish can take like 40 minutes. Since it's designed to be played over and over, difficulty is high, and you can store lucky drops for your characters, replay value is pretty good. Specially if you are into beating high scores, a bit of an outdated concept in general, but works pretty well here. Different classes, builds and worlds play quite differently, so there's noticeable variety. Special and shared worlds also have leaderboards, for a slight competitive vibe if you are into it. Could be a good choice for a let's play or speedrunning.Extra features are quite convenient and welcomed. You don't get a tutorial, but "advice" based on your actions, reminding you of basic tactics and features if you don't use them. Likewise, you have Iris, a little fairy companion, that will give you general advice and specific details of some aspects of the game (such as terrain penalties) on request. At the end of your quest you get rated on a number of aspects, such as looting and combat, and gives you extra advice or praise if it's bad or good. Your general score awards you "hero points", which you can use to make any new playthrough stronger by unlocking perks, player classes or item storages.This game features a peculiar version of "permadeath", a common roguelike trope, where your character is completely gone after death. You can save your game, but the default would be to start over once you die. However, you can continue a saved game after death, but you aren't awarded hero points if you continue after dying. The game encourages permadeath but doesn't mind very much if you go for the opposite, basically.You can't play together with other players, however, it has a fairly interesting approach similar to shared Nethack servers of old, where a single-player game gets peppered with messages and other bonuses caused by other players being in the same "Dimension" (a fancy name for random seeds). As well, special events updated daily give special challenges, such as more experience gain in a harder setting; replacing all item drops for money and so on. Or quests with special NPCs, some fairly funny or endearing. 6 months after the latest update, special events are still getting rotated daily, which is a good sign.A great plus is that, while the game isn't available for Linux, it runs flawlessly on WINE, only having a minimal sound glitch with the conversation sound effect (which echoes a tiny bit), but all online features, replays, input, video, music, all other sound effects and such, works perfectly.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 11, 2015
												Interesting? Yes. Entertaining? Yes. Cutesy? Yes. Frustrating? Perhaps. Addictive? Most definitely.One Way Heroics is a nice little game created in Wolf RPG Editor. When I first played it, I was excited. Games like this always caught my eye and the dialogue the characters/NPC's have only made it more fun. A tad bit silly, but nonetheless still great. So, I started it up and was ready to play. I thought it would be rather simple. It looked easy enough to do; Avoid the darkness consuming the world. In other words, avoid getting scrolled off the screen. I fought monsters along the way. It was very tedious, sure, but entertaining. Then, finally, I encountered the boss, the Demon Lord. I swear, I have never been defeated so quickly by a boss in my entire lifetime. Eager to defeat him, I retried. And thus started the endless cycle of trying to successfully defeat the Demon Lord.This game is a bundle of joy, frustration, and addiction. You are provided with numerous classes to choose from and to defeat the Demon Lord with. Each world is randomly generated so there are always new surprises to look forward to. You are also given opportunities to save here and there, so if you are absolutely certain this particular world is suitable for you to achieve your goals, then save at a save point and viola! No need to worry about losing your progress. There are also a number of skills you can obtain, as well as weapons, armor, items, partners - you name it. In addition to the gameplay, the soundtrack is beautiful, enjoyable, and is certainly enough to keep you motivated. Obviously, the graphics are pixelated (with the exception of when character dialogue pops up), but the art is nice and I will admit that I find some of the monsters rather cutesy.I somehow managed to hop off this game for a while (which was good because if I hadn't, it would've been an unhealthy addiction for me), but I have taken note that the One Way Heroics Plus DLC is coming around Steam sometime soon, so I'll definitely be playing soon again. Do I recommend this game? Of course I do! If you choose to purchase this game, I now wish you all the good luck on your journey to defeat the Demon Lord!

content:
Posted: March 1, 2014
												It's basically a JRPG combined with a roguelike. There's a big amount of content for the price (which is even cheaper if you buy it off of Playism), including varied classes, daily challenges/runs, hidden endings, and more. It's not too difficult for beginners to get into, but hardcore roguelike fans will still find challenge in the harder difficulty modes. It's really addicting to see how far you can get in a few hours, and you can compare how well you're doing against other players on the same seed in real-time (you can even post your wins/losses on Twitter #OneWayHeroics). Some people might complain about its lack of depth; don't expect a complex turn-based combat system like in Final Fantasy or a deeply complicated and engaging story. The real fun in this game is in how easy it is to pick up and play. It's definitely worth the price, and it has way more replay value than most of the games priced at $5 - $10 here.TL;DR - Probably the most fun, easily accessible Roguelike you'll find on Steam that's under $5. :)

												This game, despite being a little difficult to get the hang of, is good fun. I is a combination between Rouge Legacy, Finaly Fantasy, and Mario (the fact being you can only go forward, never back). The procedurally generated worlds adds to the complexity of the game. If found myself making character sheets of past characters so should i find a weapon that suits them in a run through in which the weapon is useless, i can stick it in the storage and make them the header for the next run. I've also found myself becoming addicted to the worlds i create, wanting to defeat them before I create a new one. To paraphrase, this game is a refreshing bundle of originality, ingenuity, whilst also winking at the games from the Ninetys. In a way, this is a less masochistic 16-bit version of Dark Souls.

content:
Posted: March 24, 2014
												Don't listen to any of the negative reviews. They're all either people complaining about it being "too hard and frustrating" or complaining that it crashes and is buggy. I haven't had this game crash on me once, and it's not frustrating. This is one of the funnest games I've played.Like most rouge-likes, once your character dies he/she stays dead. Depending on how good your run is, you can use points to unlock more classes, perks, and slots in your Dimensional Vault, which is where you can store items from your previous run to use in your next run.But of course, the games main attraction is the darkness that is constantly following you. Every action you do such as move, attack and use an item inches the darkness closer to you. If it engulfs you, you die. This makes going into dungeons tricky. You need to stop and think "Will I be able to kill all the monsters in there, loot the chests, and get out?"Amazing game. Great soundtrack. Overall fun as hell. For $3.49 you can't go wrong, buy it.

content:
Posted: March 30, 2014
												Holy CRAP! well well I bought this game based only on a whim, and Man! you pay pennies for a great game here. Am no reviewer Heaven Forbid, but when i see something great I must do somethin to show how good this thing really IS. Well first of all its not a great Graphical looking game it looks like one of those Early SNES kind of game like Mystic Quest but don't let the graphics fool you or some other guys who have given this game bad reviews with no reason whatsoever. The claim the game is tough I finish it on my 6 try with the Knight class. SO its not hard really just dont start with the Swordmaster class. Well this is the thing the game is really interesting you start with only two unlocked classes the swordmaster and the Knight. The knight its worth saying its for beginners start with that ONE, and you will see the greatness of this game. Its all about gameplay in this game and a turn based game but you wont really see the turn and stuff in this game its like a really fast flow to the right all the time but even when your only moving to the right all the time (because of a dark screen corner on the left who is eating the whole world) you will still find NPCS selling you stuff and giving you advice, save shrines and rest stops. the climax of the game is this (at least on the normal difficulty) after you walk 400km or 12 days in real time about 10-20 minutes of real time gameplay you encounter this Demon Lord Guy who by then you will be lvl 17-25 and depending on your luck and starting strategy (mostly strategy) you will be able to defeat because of the items and weapons you have encountered and saved during your game. There is also alot of Replay Value on this title because there are alot of unlocked classes here to discover which will present their unique challenge to get to the Demon Lord. This Game  is for those looking for plenty of gameplay on a small price fee.

Posted: July 21, 2014
												Quite honestly one of the best roguelike RPG's i've played.There's a character creation system with a variety of classes, perks and appearances. Most need to be unlocked but there's quite a lot to get.The movement and battles are turn-based and the unique flavor to this particular game is a encroaching wall of darkness from the left that closes in each time you do something.(Move, attack, etc) This means you have to keep a eye on the darkness and consider wether to go on or maybe try to clear that one dungeon or pick up that one item in time.This creates a sense of pressure that makes for a fun atmosphere.There is a online aspect to the game in the form of death/milestone messages from other players in the same world that show up in the upper left of the screen.The worlds are randomly generated but there are specific types that have special quests or certain restrictions. There is also the ability to share world ID's with others so they can play the same world.For a fairly cheap price this is a great game to pick up.

												One Way Heroics is great. It's a randomly generated game with a ton of replay value. You choose a class, name your character and embark on an adventure to stop the Demon Lord from destroying the world. There are different generated dimensions for you to explore, some will have criteria that you might find fun or challenging. Though there are some that are just ridiculously difficult. I can't recommend this game enough for fans of JRPGs or Roguelikes.

content:
Posted: March 4, 2016
												I've never posted a review of this game until now only because it's hard to find words to sum up how great it is without dragging the review on and on.Here's what you need to know.One Way Heroics is a relatively simple take on a lot of RPG elements woven into a roguelike fantasy. The system for gear statistics is pretty straightforward, as is the story-telling, as is leveling up. There are no skill trees or any choice of what stat you level up, but I promise you it won't matter.That being said, the simplicity is nice. It allows you to play the game casually without taking away that constant strive some players have for better gear or "the perfect run".The combat is also quite simple. You have a basic attack you will use most of the time, as well as a few abilities learned from leveling or NPC's. It's quick, with you likely not spending more than 5 seconds on most enemies besides bosses. It keeps the game moving, which is nice because in a roguelike its important not to drag things out. This also allows you to keep the game short if that's what you want. Personally my average session is maybe 2 hours long, but if you insist on going as far as 2000km (which isn't neccessary to win), it's a bit closer to 4 or 5 hours. Optional saves make those long games far less daunting.As I said, this game can work for casual players, but it does not leave the more dedicated players with nothing to do. 170 hours as I'm writing this review and there is still more to do. The game has a few interesting objectives woven into it to DRASTICALLY increase replay value, such as daily campaigns that change up the rules of the procedurally generated worlds you play in, multiple bosses to defeat, 4-5 different difficulties and 4 different ways to "win" a playthrough. Also it has one particular aspect I love to see in roguelikes; you can transfer a limited amount of gear from one playthrough to another. This helps you to continue your quest for the absolute best gear by allowing you to keep enchanting gear instead of losing everything at the end of a playthrough. But it's not at all essential for beating the game if that's too easy for you ;)As for the "One Way Heroics Plus" expansion (without going into detail), it's not neccessary for enjoying the game. It's the icing on top of the cake, and the odds are you will want it at some point or another, so I suggest buying it right off the bat to really enhance the game.Whether you are looking for a game to waste a few hours on, or one to get really sucked into, you just can't go wrong with One Way Heroics.

Posted: March 5, 2014
												I bought this on a whim due to the low price. Have to say it's worth far more. I've already spent more time on this game then Dungeons of Dredmor, and can imagine playing it even more. Unlike most roguelikes, it's fast paced and easy to get into, but becomes complex once you know the basics. I beat easy difficulty on only my second playthrough, which took around 30 minutes. Normal difficulty adds recruitable party members, new items, and removes the fixed end point in easy mode. My longest run lasted 3 hours. I have yet to beat hardThere are very un-roguelike save points and 'Dimensional Vault' to carry over items from old characters. Your end game rewards are reduced for using them though. If you are good enough at roguelikes to do without them, it's worth trying as there is a lot of stuff to unlock.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 5, 2014
												So for those who don't know what this game is, let me first explain what my impression (and the tldr) of the game is:One Way Heroics is a new twist on (somewhat) rogue-like RPG's, bearing similarities to Shiren the Wanderer (the non-Atlus-screwed-up one) but with an urgency placed on time and what you do with it.Understandably, some people wouldn't call it a roguelike because of the save/load feature or the dimensional vault, but since you do not accumulate hero points after resuming a loaded game (after death), my interpretation has been that saving/loading is only a feature for those who are in it for the story content.  A good compromise imo.What I likedA creative take on this style of game.  I haven't seen anything like it -- the closest comparison would be Shiren the Wanderer.An objective (the demon lord) that plagues you from the start, but not impossible to vanquish once you have progressed enough.Party members that serve a purpose, but also have depth.  Like everything else in the game, they are not permanent.The music is fantastic.What I didn't like that others might likeI'm not a fan of visual novels (?), so the abundance of text serving as the beginning and end of your adventure is not something that is fulfilling for me.  It's very well written, imo, so I imagine JRPG / Story-reading fans will like this.No cursed items.  Unidentified items you can wear, but none of them cursed. :\  The only undiscovered attribute on an item that poses any uncertainty is the durability.The price is so low, it feels like I robbed some poor hard-working developer that just loves making games like this.  Playism's site says something about letting you pay what you want (donation-based I guess?), so hopefully some people have been more charitable towards this game.What I don't likeThere is no way to isolate the leaderboards to personal social groups - as a result, it's all meaningless information, sadly. :\  It would be great if I could see where I rate among my friends list.There's no underground -- Yah, it's a pretty big game already, sure.  But fantasy games need dungeons.  An intricate right-way-progressing dungeon would've made the screen edge much more intimidating.Those are my impressions of this game. :)

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 19, 2014
												You are a hero.  There's a darkness steadily advancing from the left.  If you get caught in it, it kills you, so you'll be steadily advancing to the right.  There's a demon lord that'll show up at some point to try to kill you.  It's your job to kill him first.  That's pretty much the story.This is essentially a turn based RPG.  Every step you take, action you make, etc. is matched by both the encroaching darkness and all other creatures/NPCs in the game.  As you progress right, you'll run into friendly NPCs that can sell/buy/give items, enemies that want to end your quest, random items strewn across the landscape...pretty much everything you'd expect from an RPG.The worlds you'll play on are randomly generated, so you have the option of a new map each time you play, although you also have the option of playing a world you or someone else has already played by inputting a code.  So, if you find a world you like, you can keep returning to it, or you can keep exploring new layouts...although if you return to a dimension already visited, there will still be some things that change, as shops will have different stocks and random item drops will be different.You start out with two classes available(and a male and female skin for each one), and as you either perform tasks during your attempts(killing an enemy with a bow, for example, unlocks the Hunter class) or spend the points you accumulate at the end of each run, you will unlock more classes and various boosts for your characters, known as perks.There's something about this game that keeps managing to pull me back in, even after it humiliates me.  This game is not much in the way of being forgiving.  Your character is pretty weak to start out each run, and there's always a good chance that a fairly strong monster will be hanging around a few meters from the start to make you notice just how weak you are, and there are always chances you'll take the wrong path through some terrain and get pinned behind a wall of mountains that you won't be able to cross before the darkness catches you.  But, even with that, there's always a chance the next run will drop off an awesome weapon early on, or the planets will align perfectly and you'll take a golden path through the land and take down the Demon Lord with ease...only to never be able to recreate that run again.So yes.  I highly recommend this game.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												This game is decievingly good!  If you're a fan of the roguelike genre you've probably seen a lot worse in terms of presentation.  But it'd be a real shame if you passed this up because of generic looking graphics.  This game is hugely underselling itself at its price point.The game features very modular gameplay, easy to pick up in small intervals.  But the depth is real.  Be prepared to get in all kinds of difficult situations and play them differently based on your class.The real strong suit of the game however, is it's gimmick.  The encroaching darkness seems simple enough, but wait till you try to get a treasure chest underwater, and then swim out in time.  It requires you to think ahead in a way other than "how do I get this baddie out of my face"  which is refreshing in a roguelike.If you're still reading this review, go ahead and pick it up.  This will cost you less than a fastfood combo even at full price.  Seriously, you can't go wrong here.

												Fun game. It's like a RPG combined with a roguelike. It made me think of a mystery dungeon game I used to love called Shiren The Wanderer.The music is great. The online component is pretty interesting aswell. It reminds me a bit of Dark Souls. There is no direct multiplayer component but there are ghosts and you can leave messages and such.The thing I like less, is not being able to save when you want to. You need to find a certain NPC or have a certain event occur to be able to. It's a gameplay mechanic and games probably don't take super long so I can understand it but eh, I'd like to turn off the game and return from where I left off. EDIT: After playing some more, you're also able to buy consumable items that allow you to save at any point. Good enough for me.
