Posted: September 15, 2014
												This game is amazing. It has a combat system similar to what you would find on one of the Pokemon Dungeon games, which is one of my favorites.You don't have a whole lot of classes to choose from, but you wouldn't expect to at the price. You still have enough to keep you busy for hours on end.Each run scores you based off your treasure looted compared to treasure possible to loot, monsters killed without being hit, distance traveled, and your overall level. There are some other minor point contributors, but with those four main ones, it means getting to a high score means you have to be focused and make good use of everything you see.I would recomend this game to anyone who has free time, because it will eat up a whole lot of yours.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 29, 2014
												Very fun twist on roguelikes, with streamlined and fast-paced gameplay, pleasant music and a highly addictive concept and progression format.Basically, this is like a roguelike game (such as Nethack or TOME4: Tales of Maj-Eyal), mixed with one of those old school platformer "scroller" stages where a wall of death is coming towards you. The combination and design makes progression interesting, as gameplay never really stagnates because of the wall keeping you moving forward and requiring you to make decisions. "Is it worth it to enter this dungeon? Will I have a way to get out in time? Can I reach the shopkeeper before the appraiser gets eaten by the darkness?". At the end, you have to battle the boss, the Demon Lord who summoned the wall of death, which packs quite a punch compared to everything else you fight. To aid you, you can find loot, money...all your traditional JRPG elements, but streamlined to be as fast-paced as possible.The presentation is a mixed bag. Sprites are tiny but appropriate, and look very much like what you'd expect in a Super NES RPG. Music is not the best ever, but makes itself noticeable when needed, and stays out of the way during the less exciting parts. Controls are very simple and consoley, but doesn't really need a pad to be enjoyed, as it controls with mostly 3 keys and directions. The interface is however quite confusing, with vital stats near the middle of the screen, with other stats at the bottom, buffs at the right...it's a bit all over the place and takes a bit to get used to, but at least you can get used to it after a couple rounds.Larger character artwork is also a mixed bag, with some portraits looking good, others looking kinda bland. Character design is very old-school JRPG medieval fantasy, a bit retro while at it, looks more 90s than 2010s if you get what I mean. I guess it is a good effort at looking old-school.As for gameplay decisions, it's all quite slick. Weapons have durability, but are usually easy enough to replace, and repairing is possible, while not straightforward. To compensate, the limit on enchantments, buffs and powerups for each individual weapon or armor is quite big, allowing to kind of craft superweapons with a bit of luck or planning, not too much. Dungeons, terrain and towns are terribly simplistic, but then again, you can't really stay more than a dozen turns in most places, so it works out for the best. There's plenty of decent loot lying around as well, although deciding what stuff to keep and what to drop to satisfy your weight limits can bring the action to a temporary halt as you ponder advantages and disadvantages, or wondering if that unidentified item is crap or highly enchanted.An average game from start to finish can take like 40 minutes. Since it's designed to be played over and over, difficulty is high, and you can store lucky drops for your characters, replay value is pretty good. Specially if you are into beating high scores, a bit of an outdated concept in general, but works pretty well here. Different classes, builds and worlds play quite differently, so there's noticeable variety. Special and shared worlds also have leaderboards, for a slight competitive vibe if you are into it. Could be a good choice for a let's play or speedrunning.Extra features are quite convenient and welcomed. You don't get a tutorial, but "advice" based on your actions, reminding you of basic tactics and features if you don't use them. Likewise, you have Iris, a little fairy companion, that will give you general advice and specific details of some aspects of the game (such as terrain penalties) on request. At the end of your quest you get rated on a number of aspects, such as looting and combat, and gives you extra advice or praise if it's bad or good. Your general score awards you "hero points", which you can use to make any new playthrough stronger by unlocking perks, player classes or item storages.This game features a peculiar version of "permadeath", a common roguelike trope, where your character is completely gone after death. You can save your game, but the default would be to start over once you die. However, you can continue a saved game after death, but you aren't awarded hero points if you continue after dying. The game encourages permadeath but doesn't mind very much if you go for the opposite, basically.You can't play together with other players, however, it has a fairly interesting approach similar to shared Nethack servers of old, where a single-player game gets peppered with messages and other bonuses caused by other players being in the same "Dimension" (a fancy name for random seeds). As well, special events updated daily give special challenges, such as more experience gain in a harder setting; replacing all item drops for money and so on. Or quests with special NPCs, some fairly funny or endearing. 6 months after the latest update, special events are still getting rotated daily, which is a good sign.A great plus is that, while the game isn't available for Linux, it runs flawlessly on WINE, only having a minimal sound glitch with the conversation sound effect (which echoes a tiny bit), but all online features, replays, input, video, music, all other sound effects and such, works perfectly.

Most monsters are a breeze and nothing seems challenging at all.One day, you casually walk up to a dragon... just another day... and you notice too late that it's actually a red star boss dragon. All of those hours you spent arduously preparing materials, training your blade, and gathering new OP weapons along the way... all gone... in all but a blink of an eye.That's this game.

												Getting brutally beaten to death while climbing some mountains is my jam! No, seriously, I'm all for permadeath but I lost many promising runs in a fashion similar to that.Woes of stupidity aside, this game is great, and much more deep than the interface and graphics might suggest. The mechanics take a while to get right and it's harsh to new players, but it's a far cry from the most complex of roguelikes. And, once you have the basics down, you have a high chance of beating the Big Bad with something like the Swordmaster. Personally, I still can't get a hang on the more fragile classes, and just cheese it with a shield-wielding Hero.Anyways. If you are a fan of roguelikes, unorthodox design choices, deep, lighthearted but at times sad plots, and, of course, the buffload of content RPGs usually come with, then One Way Heroics is for you. 												This game is very innovative, and whilst playing I can't help but bring to mind Half Minute Hero as well. If you've played that and enjoyed it, you'll love this. This game is very fast paced, and if somehow you manage to plow your way through it immediately (good luck) you will have only spent 30 minutes on it. content:
Posted: September 23, 2016
												Don't mind the 4hrs played, this is like my third account that I have the game on.Now shut the ♥♥♥♥ up, this is my review.Have you ever played a game so good that you always wanted to come back to it and play it again, even after years, and it's just as good as you remembered?Maybe, back in the day with games like Zelda and Mario64, or whatever you played. Whatever, it's not important.This game, One Way Heroics, is exactly that. I play it on and off, and every time I play it, it's just as good as the last. It's fun, it's lighthearted, it's frustrating, and it's a game that's worth every penny that I paid for. Hell, I've paid for it multiple times, like I said, this is my third account with the game. Not to mention every time I've bought it for my friends. It generates the world as you go along, so even though there are similarities, no two playthroughs are the same, unless you play on the same seed as your friend, or you retry a seed.It's challenging. I had to grind up a lot of gear to be able to beat the boss, it took me a while to be able to do that, but in the end it was satisfying. Then, when I finished that, I went ahead and beat the boss on the harder difficulties. Then when I finished that, I played the second campaign.WAIT, YOU SAID THERE'S A SECOND CAMPAIGN???Damn right I did. It's in the DLC.WTF DLC THIS IS 2016 I DONT WANT MICROTRANSACTIONS!!1!I will break your ♥♥♥♥ing jaw if you open your mouth again.The DLC is 7.79CDN and that's more expensive than the base game. You know why? Because the DLC has more content than the base game, imo. It has a new class, you can customize your castle, there is the new campaing, new biomes and dungeons, etc. It's just incredible how much content there is in it, and it's safe to say that the DLC kept me even more busy, figuring out everything.But that's not all, at least like four times a ear, the game goes on sale, along with the DLC for like 75-80% off. At a dollar, you really can't go wrong.Honestly, this game is the game you're looking for. It has your oldschool JRPG graphics, a unique take on the sidescroller, amazing soundtrack, a kinda generic and dull story, but it gets made up by the sheer amount of gameplay in this game.So shut up and buy the game already. Or wait til it goes on sale, you poor ♥♥♥♥.

content:
Posted: March 1, 2014
												So, I bought this game because it was cheap.Was it worth it?Of course it was. Why not check it out for a dirt cheap price?It has a feel like The Binding of Isaac to me, without the random item rooms. Instead, you get sacks on floors.While I experienced a crash after creating a character, I figured out that you can just go to options and disable online settings.(crash fix right there for you folks.)After a while, it felt like a clash of genres of games that I loved;Perma death, (you can have a vault in which you put items from your last run in)On my third or fourth run, I got the hang of it.It felt a bit bland, but online might seem like fun.The jist of the game is that you can only continue to go right, and after 400km you have to fight the final boss, who is obviously quite difficult.Each time you die, you get Hero Points, which you can use to unlock classes, perks, and expand your vault to store items in in order to pass it on to your new character, like Rogue Legacy.It seems like it'll hold me over for a good week in single player, but I can't wait for multiplayer to work for me.

content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												An incredible game for its price. Developed by a one man team, the game is very simple: Walk right, train your character, defeat the demon lord, and save the world. You have to avoid the forever approaching darkness so you'll have to plan each and every move you take. Simple, right? Except that the world of One Way Heroics contains much more. Endless adventures in endless worlds and the hilariously ridiculous interactions with the characters present in the game makes it much more enjoyable. However, as you start to encounter more of these characters and start to learn more about this world you'll be trying to save endless times, things are not as simple as they may seem. What exactly is the darkness? Is the demon lord really the source of all the disasters happening to this world? And why is Panty named Panty?This game is definitely worth playing if you are a fan of RPGs and are looking for a game under $5. Also, to spice things up, sometimes the characters you meet may be a little "different" than they usually would.  cough Perverted Queen Frieda cough

content:
Posted: July 15, 2014
												Forced-Sidescroller meets RPG in a game where the world can be generated a hundred different ways.Good notes: High customization options, good feedback system to help you out, unlockable content makes each run feel like a step forward, replay data is semi-entertaing to watch, and a system with depth to items/combat.Neutral notes: Well executed 8 bit stlying, faux-multiplayer in which you interact with the dead and recieve semi-selective notes from other players (only available in that day's multiverse world).Bad notes:  Even on full screen the text may still seem a bit small and some world combinations (I've only found 2 and have entered no less than 25 worlds) are less than enjoyable due to constant mountains or being nearly devoid of interactable content(villages/dungeons/chests)With all of that said, I give this a full recomendation if you enjoy a rogue-like.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 27, 2015
												tl;dr- Seriously. You like JRPGs? Buy this game. You like persistant unlockables? Buy this game. You like random levels? Buy this game. This is one of my favorite games out there. Its fun to sit and play for 15 mins - or 4 hours straight.Also - be happy knowing you're supporting 16-bit style WITHOUT USING RPGMaker. This game runs its own engine.That in and of itself its worth it.___________________________________________At first glance, One Way Heroics looks like it was made on RPGMaker. It wasn't. Its a completely custom engine, from someone in Japan.And, boy is it unique. Seriously. Yes, its an RPG. Yes, it is done in 16 bit style. But that is about the only thing that makes it anything like the RPGs back then.The description on the store page really doesn't do it justice. It explains the base game. But it doesn't explain how incredibly addicting it is to go just "one more run". See, there's a bunch of dimensions - and they are slowly being swallowed up by the darkness. Meaning you can't go left for too long, as the darkness slowly advances from left to right across the screen every step you take. You are slightly faster than it, though. The game is turn based, so like Rogue, everything only moves when you do. Its like Rogue too, in that all you have to do is hit the attack key near an enemy  You are trying to defeat the Demon Lord who's causing the darkness, but its going to be quite a few playthroughs even on the easiest mode to beat him for the first time.You will die. A lot. No biggie though as it has permanent unlockables. A "vault" which you can upgrade to store items in. Perks to make your char stronger. And you can either choose to adventure in a completely randomly generated realm, or you can choose one of the "online" realms, 1 of which is random, and the others of which have "specials" (a certain character is there, darkness, better items, more XP etc). The online realms change every 24 hours. There isnt multiplayer as such, however in the online realms, theres a constant scroll of a pic and brief info about each other person playing. You can also set 1 of about 20 "online messages". One of the nicest features of online is you can also encounter the "ghost" of another player in your game at the spot where they died. They help you by giving you an item they were carrying and some of their XP.Theres also 5 game modes, eacxh slightly harder than the last, but with better items and more story. Oh did I mention that? Theres a story too. Each companion which you can find (and theres quite a few) has a story associated with them you can learn by talking to them. Oh, and both enemies and companions can have "prefixes". Some make them stronger, both enemies and companions. Some change dialogue with companions. (Really, EVERYONE needs to see Naughty Queen Frieda)...The base game is I think around $4. Its totally worth it. There's also DLC, which is totally worth it as well, if you like the base game. It adds even more awesomeness.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 23, 2016
												Let me start by saying that I cannot give this game enough praise.One Way Heroics is a game that initially came off as a game that was inexpensive and potentially should have had a short lifespand on my ever growing list of titles I've played...But not only did it stick out from other games, I still can go back and play it today with the same enthusiasm I had when I compleated my first run. I was blown away by the in depth story and the diffrent charecters that you could encounter, and did I mention the soundtrack? They would make a fortune off that alone if AGM Playism put it up for sale (I don't know if they are selling it on like I-tunes or something of the like. I'm mainly refering to a steam realease). This game will surprise you in how much charecter it has, but I must recomend you play on AT LEAST afternoon stroll to get the full experience. Party members are mvery importent, and each have there own story to learn, but are mostly locked on walk in the park. And the multiplayer feature can be interesting for long runs. But to shorten up the message in a recomendation:Should you buy the game? Yes. Its very cheap for the ammount of good content you are getting.Should you buy the + DLC?Yes. It not only improves the orriginal gameplay, it also adds in one of my favorite Party members that you can gain.Should you buy the Sequal!?Woah, don't get ahead of yourself. I just found out about it today and haven't gotten to play it yet! So I have no idea yet! But other reveiws I read said new players should at least play the original first, so thats all I have on that topic right now.But as I said before, I am but a lowly gamer on this wide earth. I can never give this game the justice it deserves in just a few words, But I do want people to know that this game has more to see then the surface. I won't spoil anything, but this game is special and is worth the price of admission and so much more.By the way, Pirates can be surprisingly Charismatic.

Then, when I finished that, I went ahead and beat the boss on the harder difficulties. Then when I finished that, I played the second campaign.WAIT, YOU SAID THERE'S A SECOND CAMPAIGN???Damn right I did. It's in the DLC.WTF DLC THIS IS 2016 I DONT WANT MICROTRANSACTIONS!!1!I will break your ♥♥♥♥ing jaw if you open your mouth again.The DLC is 7.79CDN and that's more expensive than the base game. You know why? Because the DLC has more content than the base game, imo. It has a new class, you can customize your castle, there is the new campaing, new biomes and dungeons, etc. It's just incredible how much content there is in it, and it's safe to say that the DLC kept me even more busy, figuring out everything.But that's not all, at least like four times a ear, the game goes on sale, along with the DLC for like 75-80% off. At a dollar, you really can't go wrong.Honestly, this game is the game you're looking for. It has your oldschool JRPG graphics, a unique take on the sidescroller, amazing soundtrack, a kinda generic and dull story, but it gets made up by the sheer amount of gameplay in this game.So shut up and buy the game already. Or wait til it goes on sale, you poor ♥♥♥♥.

content:
Posted: June 18, 2015
												In addition to the Steam version, I've also logged another 50 hours on One Way Heroics Plus.  Even at full price, it's totally worth it, if you're even tangentially into procedurally generated roguelikes.PROS:Three dollars at full price, and constantly going on sale.Several ways to beat the game.Nearly infinite replay value.OWH+ has already been released on playism, and adds even more depth to the game.Nobody is immune to anything.  If it says it works, it will work.  No more pesky "Poison only works on player, but not bosses" nonsense.CONS:dated graphicsWeapons are hard to keep forever (Not that you need them, but you grow attached).Poor scaling for super long runs.  There's no setting between "You slaughter this guy" and "You die in one hit"

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 3, 2014
												This game is very innovative, and whilst playing I can't help but bring to mind Half Minute Hero as well. If you've played that and enjoyed it, you'll love this. This game is very fast paced, and if somehow you manage to plow your way through it immediately (good luck) you will have only spent 30 minutes on it. However, the game's replay-ability is it's biggest feature. Each victory ends with more loot, more rewards, more knowledge, and more challenging modes to continue playing with. The game is endless hours of fun, and I must say it is well worth the small amount of money it costs. ($3.00 For anything that lasts for hours and hours is a good deal, regardless of what your interests are.)

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 6, 2014
												First off, you start off as a hero and you're trying to defeat the demon lord in order to stop the darkness that is following you and eating up the world. It's a very generic premise, but the thing is: There is no turning back. If you miss a shop keeper, you have to restart the world, or keep on going. You're hungry? You just missed the last piece of food for a while? Well too bad. This game has tons of replayability in it, and really is just one way. The levels are randomly generated and there are daily quests every day. Of course you don't get anything out of the daily quests, but they're still fun to adventure through when you really have nothing much to do.Each run can last more than 45 minutes if you're lucky, but they can also last less than 5 minutes. This game has tons of decision making and luck based things, but it feels perfectly balanced to me. There's a pixie in your inventory to help you with tips so that might help as well. Anyways, the game is well worth the purchase.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												Great value for the price. One Way Heriocs has the Rogue-like quality of multiple face-palming failures until you win (and that win is so sweet).The base game and the "Plus" dlc is relatively cheap. Worth giving up a coffee for.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2016
												This game is THE RPG for those that want a faster paced RPG, while being turn-based, but don't want to invest too many hours going through lengthy cutscenes and dialogue, and be able to enjoy its various challenges. The roguelike nature of this game provides many hours of adventures with the many randomly generated worlds that you can play through (and go back to if you want) and the 4 difficulty settings that allows new players and veterans at the game to enjoy at various levels.Each run is quick, simple, and fun, being able to quickly go from a fresh, level 1 character to an unstoppable hero with hundreds of levels, provided you can survive long enough. The world is being consumed in darkness, and you must run from left to right and outrun the darkness while going on your journey. There are several win-state goals in the game, each of which with varying difficulty. In other words, just because you've defeated the Dark Lord doesn't mean you've finished the game. There is more to the game than simply defeating the Dark Lord. With the different classes with different play styles, the potential allies that you can recruit, the different worlds and encounters, there are many unique adventures to be had in your quest to save the world. The amount of content and hours of gameplay you will get out of this is well worth the very cheap price of this game. I also highly recommend getting the One Way Heroics + DLC as well as it adds more classes, content, and functionality.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 27, 2016
												So close to being a perfect game.The only painfully glaring development flaws are that potential party members (and other frendly NPCs) often get killed by monsters before even appearing on the screen (the game loads a ways ahead of what is accessible), and that several of your own abilities will kill or harm cooperative NPCs that are following you, i.e. mercenaries, cows, packhorses, etc.All that aside it's an amazingly addictive and satisfying game, one which hopefully inspires future developers to do it right.

content:
Posted: April 9, 2015
												60% of the people who played this game probably hated it, but that's only because they didnt pay attention to what was happening. It's not frustating or boring, you just didnt pay attention. You're dropped in a world  with no tutorial and no context, but once you do understand what you're supposed to do and how the game works, you'll se yourself playing a very VERY fun and interesting game.There are lots of classes, lots of ways to play it, lots of bosses (!), there's even a way to befriend the boss and get him into your party, like what the hell that is amazing. I still didnt beat the game because ♥♥♥♥ this♥♥♥♥♥♥is hard, but its so fun i cant stop playing it.Great game, great music, _GREAT_ price, HELLA ADDICTIVE, and the best thing, in my opinion, its a totally different game when you actually understand what is going on and what you're supposed to do. Also a gigantic plot twist in the end. Look foward to that.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 27, 2015
												A cute JRPG with a roguelike twist. Plays quickly and satisfyingly and gives a new random dimension every day to challenge a leaderboard for, as well as other challenge modes and random modes to do for fun. Combat is simple but there's a decent amount of classes, perks, gear, and items to find, as well a sparty members to recruit that come with mini storylines to complete. You can also save items from previous runs to hand them forward down the line.The game forces you to continually press ahead or die to "the Darkness", so exploring and fighting is balanced with continuing onward, ever onward. Everything you do takes up a turn, so exploring a dungeon and hacking down chests takes time, and you need to make sure you've got time to get out of the dungeon you went into! Or break a hole in the wall.At under 5 bucks, the game is a steal if you're looking for a small, simple game to play bits at a time. You can get in a game before work, or at lunchtime, or etc. You can play for a lot, lot longer at a time if you want to! But the game's strength is its ability to deliver a full package run in about a half hour.

content:
Posted: July 1, 2015
												If you like rogue-likes then you'll love this game. You start off with a few classes of characters and can choose a few perks to augment stats or gain abilities, and your goal is to defeat the demon lord who appears to be the cause of a darkness swallowing up the lands. Literally. The game has you constantly running to the right as the darkness behind you swallows up everything. Time only moves when you're moving or performing an action however, so don't be worried about being idle. This provides an interesting mechanic and a rather unique gimmick to this game similar to what Half Minute Hero does with having a time limit to defeat stuff. This game is also highly replayable; With each death you gain hero points and can use a thing called the dimensional vault to store some of your fallen hero's goods for the next hero. You can use hero points to expand said vault or unlock more classes or perks.  Each day there are new "dimensions" basically randomly generated worlds that are downloaded each day, for you to explore and play with others, well, not with others like a party of folks to fight, but you can go through the same dimension as everyone else and see their current progress in the dimension, which is pretty neat. The music is great, and surprisingly enough is all public domain music you can use if you want, and while the art might not be the absolute best, it has an endearing charm to it that is only enhanced with the characters themselves. For so cheap, this game offers a lot of hours of fun times for anyone wanting a rogue-like with a lot of content.

content:
Posted: March 11, 2015
												when i first saw this game i thought that it was just a normal rpg with the twist of time preassure, and though this didn not seem so appealing i thought i might as well give it a try. This game is such an inspiration for the rougelike genre.for those who haven't looked up a review or anything about the game, the game has something called a dimensional vault where you can store a number of items whenever you die with a charachter. After your first attempt and death you are awarded with hero point and you can use these to buy mor dimensional vault slots and perks that you can use for the next attempt. Becuase of this every playthrough becomes valuable as you have to try you best every time to get good stuff and even though you may fail at beating the boss at that atempt the stuff you gathered can be stored in the dimensional vault and be withrawn at the start of the next game.The game itself can be a little bit disappointing when you walk around and see a house or dungeon way too many steps away and you see it disappearing in the shadow every step you take, but be sure that there's going to be way more epic loot ahead. And if you are really obssesed with entering precisly that house you can reload the same world with the next charachter if you want to do so.Personally i find the Pirate class to be the best one. Yeah he may have negative charisma making the villagers hate his face, but after adding 2 charisma+ perks everything is fine. Be aware that you have to unlock him though but it is way worth it.anyway a great game and seems like something i will come back to now and then whenever i have hard time finding a game to play in my steam library containing 74 games....

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 20, 2016
												The game is amazing. I'll elabore below.I'll start with the bad things i saw on my first minutes. Negative  -   UI : At first you will be overwhelmed by the UI, lots of stuff you don't know of, and weird position (I'm still not used to having a map in middle of the screen). -   Everything looks so small : The graphics are distant, but you'll accustom to it pretty easily. F4 (window size) will be your friend here. -   "Chatbox* : System info can be hard to see (the thing that looks like a chatbox) and you can't (or i haven't seen/found such feature) really scroll it up in case you missed something.After my first few minutes, i was able to withstand the things i was concerned from. All thanks to these pros. Positive  +   Soundtrack : The music is amazing. Each area has its own music and you'll be used to hear them pretty often, but the thing that i enjoyed the most, was event music.Each event has a different soundtrack, and that adds a nice variety to your ears.I'm just talking about design here, but the quality of the soundtrack is also amazing.Area music matches pretty well with the environment.Event music matches with the element of surprice and the feelings you may have while thinking your next move.Lore (game over / special characters / victory / etc) music is nice, you won't feel that it's out of place or that it affects negatively to what's going on. +   Story : This one can be subjective. I love with all my heart the genre of medieval fantasy. You'll find a few clichés, but there is also room for nice plot in between. I won't say which kind of plot, but it was worth it, even tho i kinda like all medieval fantasy plots. +   Replayability : I'm pretty serious with this one. I make sure to not buy any game that can't offer a good replayability. Please understand that after this point, i'll tell some stuff that even tho it's not a spoiler, it counts as stuff that is nice to see for yourself. You don't have to see all the game features in order to see if you'll enjoy it.After this point i suggest you to try a demo or buy it and play it for as long as you can refund it in case you don't like it. Following the replayability...You have different classes, each with unique skills, strenghts and weaknesses. At easy difficulties it isn't that big of a deal, but if you want to beat the game on the harder difficulties, you'll have to make good use of each class' strenghts.After beating the game, next time you pick a class, you'll see a medal based on the difficulty on the class that you beated the game with.A nice replayability factor is to complete the game on every difficulty with each class. And... +   Randomness :As long as you keep playing on different realms, you won't have the same experience.In case you are not that hardcore of a player, you can still repeat the last realm you played, and thus, having another try on the same encounter/environment.Still, some stuff will be randomized, like items, monsters, treasure and such, so it won't be that boring, you almost won't feel like doing exactly the same.This is getting too long, and i can't leave my games waiting for too long. So i'll jump to something i found average. Bipolar  +/-   Save system :You'll either love it or hate it. But you'll have options either way, remember that.There are three ways to save your adventure (which can turn out to be some pretty long and hardcore expeditions).1. Find a save attendant.A young elf will offer a save feature when you find her. I won't say much more, that's up to you. But you'll be able to find her pretty often.2. Save stone.A crystal used to save the game. Save attendants sell it, but you can find one in your adventures if you are lucky.3. Goddess gift.Once in a while, a goddess will offer a save option at the cost of 5 levels.Did you see what's so different here?All saving methods include finding something. This is not a game you can start and leave every 8 minutes. So no gaming at work i guess.Personally, i love this feature. I like to have to save some money for save crystals and use them wisely. As i said, you'll either love or hate this. +/-   Load system :The game allows you to save > try > fail > load > try again. It's kinda expensive to do it often, but you can.I don't like this, and i'm not the kind of person that can avoid to use an advantage when i see it. That's why i like unfair traps and the lack of Easy/Normal difficulties.Even tho i never play on Easy... If i struggle a lot on normal, i'll consider it.However, this system is also good in case you are not a hardcore player and you get too frustrated by dying because of a single mistake. (Like unequipping a shield and forgetting to equip it for the tough encounter.)That's all, i need to go back and play more games. Have fun!

content:
Posted: November 24, 2014
												Fun and unique interpretation of the Japanese RPG game type. On paper, the concept sounds forced and confusing, but the game plays intuitively after only a few lives. Most importantly, there is a great design sense that unifies the game as a whole. Each class encourages its own gameplay style, and character customization, through an unlock system, is flexible without being overwhelming. An inter-game treasure chest, like that in Shiren / Mystery Dungeon, allows players not used to roguelikes accumulate treasure without being able to horde it. Well worth the price: a game that is rewarding whether you invest hours into it or simply play it as a coffee-break roguelike.

content:
Posted: March 2, 2014
												What a cute little game. So far the fun I have had in it has been well worth the small price tag. It is a fun and very replayable rogue like with forced side scrolling of the map. Let the darkness touch you and you will be consumed. Aside from the adorable classic rpg graphicsThere are really nice features like:-exchange levels of experience to gain main attribute boosts.-Classes with more to unlock either by points or meeting the small requirement.-Many weapons and armors to pick up or buy from vendors in game. -Fun and yet very simple combat that should be pretty much common for most rpg/action rpg players.-Perks that you can assign to you character to give them a little more oomph out the gate. -Good soundtrack.-Accessable gameplay that also really plays well on a x-box/ps3 controller.-A vault you can expand to hold a few items from previous adventures that are made available to all your future runs.-Random generated worlds The game is great fun and easy to pick up for a short time and put down if need be. I do reccomend!

content:
Posted: November 19, 2014
												Good challenging game, best one I've ever played. And I hate challenging games, but this one is great! 9.5/10.  Here are pros and cons.Pros:- Great game, great balancing.- Level system is nice.- The stamina and stuff gives is a nice addition.- I've never seen another RPG game like this, so thats great! Making a new idea is always nice!- Whatever else I think is nice.Cons:- Lack of multiplayer, it would make the game a bit better in my option, give it that and you get my 10/10.- Co-op would be cool too.- Lack of classes, so far i've only found 5. I dont know how many there are, but still- It should be completely new. They should make new classes that no one has ever seen, that'd be nice. There are the basics like Archer, Swordfighter/Warrior. Sure, all RPGs have that, but this one would be better without, because this game is a one of a kind, I dont think any other RPG game like this could top it. I have a few new class ideas in mind, like the Warage. It'd use a combination of wands, spellbooks and swords and shields. I think that'd be nice. This game should have stuff like that. Also, you can use my idea if you want.- Finally, not much in the game itself. It gets repeatitive and boring really fast. Adding like Daily Challenges, Missions you could do like "Go 500 meters in 20 seconds" or something would be great. Also adding something like a Christmas mode at the appropriate time each year, it'd bring in the holiday cheer! :D-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Overall, One Way Heroics is a great buy. It could use some more updates and things, but its good.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
												I really believe in this game's concept. Incredibly addictive. Forget all the flashy FPS games out there. Forget all the epic post apoc zombie hipster nonsense. Get One Way Heroics. A STEAL AT SUMMER SALE PRICE OF $0.87!!!!!! A STEAL AT REGULAR PRICE OF $3.49!!!!! The world is depending on you to side scroll away from the darknessStarts out with only 2 available classes. More classes are unlockable. Basic Strength Agility Vitality Intellect Willpower Charisma type stat set up. You can choose up to 3 perks and they are stackable. With more perks being unlockable. Basic life bars are Health Stamina and Energy. As you perform certain actions, your Stamina decreases. If your Stamina decreases below zero you begin to lose Health. Just living makes your Energy decrease so I look at it as a Hunger bar. There is food you can eat to keep these numbers to an acceptable level. You apparently always start with a plant that constantly grows Healing Herbs so don't forget to pick them. After a playthrough you get Hero Points and you can spend those on unlocking perks, classes, or slots in a Dimensional Vault that will allow you to keep items after you die, so you may use them in other playthroughs.The Darkness never stops. If you get consumed by it, you die. Game over, man. Luckily for you, this is a Turn- Based game. So you'll have plenty of time to see what's in front of you, check your inventory, and plan your moves. It's funny because you might see a merchant NPC and you'll do some trading and then continue to run from the darkness and the NPC will scream as he gets swallowed up. Get. This. Game.

Posted: June 21, 2014
												I went into One Way Heroics...not expecting too much. Rogue-likes were always difficult for me to grasp. And I am always weak at taking on the difficulty curve, however those expectations were quickly turned around though. It was great, not only that there's something about the...feel? of the game that really struck a chord with me, the...melancholic, joking, and sometimes self-sacrificing manner the chat, dialogue and text went about.One of the best things I can say about One Way Heroics though, is the relative simplicity of it compared to other Roguelikes. Personally, I always loved Roguelikes, but I could never really enjoy them due to the aforementioned rather crazy steep learning curve which I always had issues handling. However, One Way Heroics was easy, Simple goal, Simple controls. A truly magnificent experience. I am sorely tempted to rate it among the top of the games I played ^_^

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												First of all, this game is unforgiving. If this statment puts a bad taste in your mouth, then this game is not for you. However, if what I just said doesn't bother you at all, then you just might have found a gem worth keeping. This game is a rougelike, so don't expect to have all the pieces of the puzzle when you first begin. (Google "Rougelike" if you don't know what that term means, trust me it helps.) Your first dozen (or few dozen, depending on your luck) playthroughs are more than likely going to end in failure, and the world will be doomed without you. However, as you discover strategies that work (and ones that don't) things will start to turn around. Still, odds are you will die more times than you will reach that happy ending. But that's the thing, the game doesn't stop at the ending. Multiple endings add to replay value, as do multiple objectives that you don't even know exist when the game begins. Add in the fact that worlds are randomly generated, and you will never have two playthroughs that are quite the same (aside from multiple deaths, as that is always a possibility).In short, this game will give you back everything that you put into it. If you don't give it a chance, you will have wasted your money. Fight through the first dozen deaths and learn from your mistakes, and this game will leave you addicted like it has done for me.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 11, 2014
												Having beaten this game once, I feel as if I definitely got my money's worth.  One Way Heroes takes the concept of a roguelike, and twists it here and to create an enjoyable end product that reminded me of 30 Second Hero and Desktop Dungeons.  In the beginning, the jrpg graphics threw me off slightly, as did the premise of a scrolling field of darkness.  The text-based screams of people being enveloped was a nice touch that may both cause cringing as well as a chuckle. After my first death, having made a decent run, I was suprised to see an entire system in which I could not only store items I had acquired, but also purchase new ablities for the next run, as well as extra storage space for my 'dimensional chest'.  Although the procedurally generated structures becoming familiar after a time, the randomness of both the wares of merchants and the contents of containers keeps things fresh, not to mention the occasional mob with a modifier on them, from cheap merchants that can rip you off, to ancient monsters that drop a rare item.  The prices for many items may be steep at times, but a trick I've found is to bring high-priced items like the fox tail into your next playthrough with the dimensional chest, making your next endeavor a bit more comfortable upon reaching a merchant.  Perhaps you might want to bring in a favored weapon, perhaps one with multiple upgrades?  With the scrolls of swordplay and armoring, you can upgrade equipment, and although they have durability, with luck you can grab a repair item to keep that overpowered sword nice and sharp.  The mechanics are complex, but simple enough to pick up on.  You have an hp bar, energy bar, and hunger bar.  The hunger bar continuosly goes down, and you use energy for many of the special abilities.  With hunger being directly tied to your ability to regenerate, similar to minecraft, food becomes a valuable resource, and since potions don't fill hunger, even the slightest morsel becomes important.  Luckily, food is still not incredibly hard to find, and you even recieve some at the beginning, so although you may be led by your stomach, you won't always feel compelled to make mad dashes for food.  A weight limit means you need to make tough choices between grabbing a strong armor or weapon (which by rule of thumb weigh more the better they are) or carrying more of the much needed potions.  If you feel a huge need for a higher weight limit, simply change your character's starting buffs and abilities.  Energy is used for swimming, climbing mountains, and using abilities, paricularly as the force user, who spams the one damage spell in the game with imputiny.  You will often find yourself conserving this, as without energy, ever expidenture eats your own health.  In terms of climbing and swimming, these are desprate measures taken when there is nowhere else to go, and if possible, always find another way.With a rolling screen at your back, this sidescroller of a rpg may make you cry with frustration as you fail to escape due to a wall. Luckily, the developers added a skill to help you called awakening.  With a cry of "Time, Stop!" you can stop the movement ofeverything for three turns, plus an attack boost.  Although you have limited uses, this can be used to survive almost any encounter, from freezing bandits in place so you can thin numbers without fear of being triple-teamed, or gaining enough time to destroy the afformented wall with your sword and escape the dungeon.  Besides this, each class is varied and unlockable modifiers and classes are accessible, and in terms of classes, unlockable even if you don't fufill their requirement if you use the points gained on your runs.  Of all the things this game reminds me of, the frantic escape reminds me of cutesy 30 second hero, where you get limited time to defeat a level, causing a similar amount of frantic despair as the end of your attempt approaches and Desktop Dungeons, which also can drive you crazy when a forgotten option causes death, although the forgiving mechanics make this game far more accesible, even with both running off a mechanic of unlocking.This and many more intricities await in this game, and I only have two cons.1: There could be more force abilities and weapons(especially force abilites), hopefully coming later2: More randomized structures and new mechanics would be cool, but not a huge deal for a game of this size and priceOverall, I'd say this fun, fast-paced experience was worth playing.

												One Way Heroics is a rogue-type constantly moving rpg. In short, it's a brilliant game for a lover of rpgs who also happens to be incredibly ADHD. I picked it up for in incredibly low price (less than a dollar!) and got way more than my money's worth. I would pay more for this game, if only I wasn't a cheap sonofagun.The game starts with a basic intro, then throws you right into character making. Not many choices for now, but after the first run (and death) it becomes obvious that there are many more classes, perks, and items to unlock.My first few runs were less than perfect. I found one chest out of thirty and didn't even make it 100km. I tried to esacpe from monsters by going into the mountains. HINT: Don't do that.But I was immediately hooked. I loved the looks, the AMAZING music, and I really wanted to beat the hell out of the enemies that were doing the same to me.I'll be playing this game very often. I give it a 9/10.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
												This is an extremely engaging game with simple mechanics that work well for it. If you are a fan of JRPGs or loot snagging in general, you'll have a great time.Despite this being a procedurally generated roguelike game, it does manage to squeeze in some story and interesting characters. The unique bit is that, the generation is based off of whatever you want to type in. If you die in the dimension you entered if you want to revisit that dimension, the map generated will be the same (from what I've seen). This means that you can try to learn aspects of a specific dimension and plan around it. Don't worry about the random generation screwing you over too hard either. On each character run you are always given 15 free turns that you can use in bundles of 3 whenever you want. So if you see a long stretch of unavoidable mountains, you could in theory use all 15 turns to pass them if it was really that bad/unavoidable. The combat is simplistic, but deep enough that strategy actually matters since your positioning will often determine the outcome of a fight if more than one opponent is present. The game has a fair number of weapons and weapon types, some of which offer longer ranges and others which are really great at busting down terrain (Yes, you can break down walls of a house to talk to the people inside).If you love optimization, NPC party building, pretending you actually have friends or are just looking for a fun game with a wonderful soundtrack, I'd spend the 83 cents to play this. I believe the regular asking price is $3, which is more than fair. Had I not only found this thanks to the steam sale, I would have gladly paid the $3.

												My review for this game is very simple, its fantastic. The game is very clever in both its execution of gameplay and art style and here he is what i love about the game:- Many demensions (worlds) as they are randomly generated- Tried and tested RPG methods that work, sometimes better than other games- Easy to pick up, hard to master- Soundtrack is off the scale (and is free with the game!)However this game wont certainly be for everyone. If you hate turn based RPGs then you wont like this one bit, as it does rely heavily on this feature. Here are a few nags i have about the game:- Can become to easy once your gear is insane - No enough end game for me (except setting my own personal goals)- Classes dont feel different enough (however there is a very wide choice)Also please note, while this game has no direct multiplayer, it does have community demensions in which heroes can compare how they have faired against eachother e.g how far they go in KM.MY RATING: 8/10 - Worth everyone penny!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 7, 2014
												It's really interesting how a very simple concept can make something highly engrossing, and One Way Heroics is a good example of this in play. Take a very basic turn based movement and combat system, simplified stats and gear usage, and rather basic 'save the world' story as their parts, and this isn't anything new nor special by any degree, yet once you add in the ever moving 'Darkness', a mass of black that's always moving ahead, with or without you activly running away from it, and it suddenly becomes this odd pressured race of time and land management. The main key point is whever you take an actions, yet it be attack or talking or even moving, the darkness moves a bit as well, devouring that part of the map with it making it no longger accessible. Suddenly you might be trying to rush towards a small city outpost hoping to sell your overload of loot, only to get there to watch the vender NPC's parish in that very second, having to now make a rush forward hoping another isn't too far off. It suddenly makes every little action you do feel 'importent' in the grand scale of things, and it really forces you to learn to look out for selective map alterations, or carry around Map Scrolls to ensure you don't miss anything vital. The NPC's you can recrute as well also have  rather small, but kinda interesting storylines, each one giving a bit more clear overarching idea of just what's going on, and perhaps a way to really 'save the world'. Not to ruin anything, but those who explore and read up will chances are find far more then this game first lets on.On top of all of this, is a small, but nifty option of online interactions. It's nothing Dark Souls worthy of jolly co-op and the like, but it's more say little snapshots into other's current playing situations as they trek on the same world, able to share a small snipit of text, and be shown how they are status wise. Of course, on death, you can also share something much the same, and depending on where you died, your ghost might help someone else's journey along, dropping a random peice of loot you had at the moment. Beyond all of that, it's a nice, addicting, and simple game you can pick up for an hour or two, feel like you've made some progress, and seems to always have just ONE more little thing to show you even many hours after the fact.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 1, 2014
												First things first, do you like Roguelikes? If so then this game is a very prospective find for your collection! It's a very perma death and turn based unforgiving type game but of course it has features that work around that kind of system, being able to bring items over from previous gameplays and also unlocking new classes and perks to make yourself stronger at the beginning. The pace it sets with the darkness constantly chasing you is very fresh as well because not only is it a roguelike game but it also has aspects of time management almost like Half Minute Hero, making gameplay have a much more frantic pace even though it's still turn based. Another thing that makes the game fun to play is the online features, it's always fun playing a game and knowing others are doing the same, the little pop in messages aren't disruptive at all and seeing how far other people are reaching and how many other people are failing is fun in it's own rights. Of course, it's got the sharing aspect from games like Minecraft and Starbound, you can share any of the worlds that have been generated by simply giving the world's code to friends and other people. All the worlds have their own little leaderboards too, with rankings and other things, you can even see how people went about their adventure. Also, you can actually get better at a world/dimension since it's layout never changes aside from random loot drops and events. Overall, while simplistic and a bit more on the hectic/rushed side, it's still pretty in depth, especially with the carryovers and whatnot, you can even grind items out to twink yourself up for the next run. As an ending note, don't expect to win early on unless you play on the easiest difficulty, losses are inevitable on this game as they are a part of it, take it in as it comes and build yourself up to become stronger to finally defeat the Demon Lord!

content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
												Pure genius.  One Way Heroics is probably one of the better indie games this year that you won't hear about.If you enjoy generated games or the old school sprite RPG's, get this, get it now.The game-play is pseudo-turn-based where every time the player performs an action, the game world will iterate as well.Pros: Excellent replay value. Nice sprite visuals Fun, Simple gameplay: Run right, adventure, fight or flee from a large variety of monsters, search for supplies. Visit towns and talk to NPCS. Do all of the above while impending doom is always advancing towards you. Due to generated content, you never know what you'll encounter.  Each new adventure has its surprises. Lots of secrets to uncover. Works with gamepads other than the Xbox360 Controller. Able to carry some equipment over to a new adventure.Cons: None.  Although you need to come into this game expecting to replay it repeatedly to really get anything out of it.  Not a traditional linear RPG at all.One of my favorite indie games for 2014.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												First of all, this game is unforgiving. If this statment puts a bad taste in your mouth, then this game is not for you. However, if what I just said doesn't bother you at all, then you just might have found a gem worth keeping. This game is a rougelike, so don't expect to have all the pieces of the puzzle when you first begin. (Google "Rougelike" if you don't know what that term means, trust me it helps.) Your first dozen (or few dozen, depending on your luck) playthroughs are more than likely going to end in failure, and the world will be doomed without you. However, as you discover strategies that work (and ones that don't) things will start to turn around. Still, odds are you will die more times than you will reach that happy ending. But that's the thing, the game doesn't stop at the ending. Multiple endings add to replay value, as do multiple objectives that you don't even know exist when the game begins. Add in the fact that worlds are randomly generated, and you will never have two playthroughs that are quite the same (aside from multiple deaths, as that is always a possibility).In short, this game will give you back everything that you put into it. If you don't give it a chance, you will have wasted your money. Fight through the first dozen deaths and learn from your mistakes, and this game will leave you addicted like it has done for me.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
												This is one of the many extremely cheap games I got during the Summer Sales (2014).  I got it simply because I knew the trading cards would make up or at least almost make up for the 74 cents I spent.  I launched it, and was ready to let it sit and run for cards, but then, the music started.  The music was wonderful to listen to.  After sitting on the menu just listening to the music for about 30-/+ minutes, I decided I'd actually give the game a try.  I see a menu allowing me to choose my name, class, and additional perks.  Each of the characters has different standard perks, abilities, and gear.  Though it looks like you're going in extremely weak, you get random perks for leveling up and for exchanging levels with the Goddess statues that you find throughout the worlds.  If you choose the right combination of perks for a class, you can be very well set late-game.The mechanics are simple; Z to attack, X to open the inventory menu, and C to open the grid view so you can aim without moving your character.  You progress to the right of the screen to escape the darkness that's consuming the land.  If you touch the left end of the screen, you die.  There's a boss to fight, and if you kill him, you win (though you will not kill him without leveled gear and good stats).  You can climb mountains and swim in water in exchange for turns and stamina.  You find items scattered about, there are merchants, dungeons, and random villages (of which usually have a person that allows you to save your progress).  It's pretty much a standard turn-based exploration RPG, but is very clever in which they execute certain aspects.The first game I thought of while playing this game was one of my favorites for the GBA- Pokemon Mystery Dungeon: Red Rescue Team.  The moving mechanics, the menus, the navigation, and the soundtrack all are similar, and very well executed.  This game renewed the genre for me.Why I Recommend It: -The game has a very high replay value due to the randomly generated worlds and limitless perk combinations.-The game is very cheap, and is well worth the money.-The soundtrack alone is worth the cost of the game.  The game is almost just a bonus.-It's very well set up, with little to no bugs (I have yet to find one)Who I Recommend It To: -People wanting to experience another classic RPG with a twist.-People that enjoyed the Pokemon Mystery Dungeon series and games similar to it.-People with limited funds.-People that just want a game to play that is unlike many of the games here on Steam.Who Should Avoid It?:-People unwilling to pay the minute price.-Idiots.Final Thoughts:I didn't think I'd invest as much time in it as I have.  This isn't one of those games you usually invest a lot of time in for straight playthrough (say, 5 hour+ sessions), though you can.  This is one of those games you would play for thirty minutes a day everyday.  Personally speaking, I'll certainly be coming back to it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 20, 2015
												Very hard to get used to the controls for some reason, but once you do the game is amazing, i suggest playing it while watching a walk-through for it so that you can better understand the world you've entered. The game itself isn't inherently hard, but you have so little to work with that it takes getting used to. Warning to new players to stay away from Golems, they have set spawn locations per world and they are nasty with or without an axe (which does more damage to them).Characters can be unlocked with points rewarded for your progress after each death or by completeing a certain feat. You can use these points to get a vault and add space to said vault. The Vault NPC is in the set spawn for each character. I recommend always keeping a Key of Seals in the Vault if you manage to come across one. Keys of Seals are used on Temples and can give you Holy Artifacts. My first holy artifact was an Axe that crushed everything before me. By the time it had worn down i found another temple and another key of seals, and got a Holy Spear and Holy Chest Armor. Made it the last 80 km to the Demon Loard and killed him with no struggle. I've only gotten 2.8 hrs of playtime in the time of this review, but i could easily put 200 hours into it. It's cheap for it's value of entertainment, and if you end up in a poor spawn you can always just continue again. More tips-Always buy from a Chef When/If you reach a town. They seem pricey but in actuality they are cheap and extremely valuable.-This game is about Trade-offs, you may end up choosing things that are detrimental to the world you spawn on.-More expensive is not always better, especially when you do not have a high enough Item-Appraisal to know what you are buying.-Randomly Generated worlds always have their problems, the largest map wrecker in this game is large mountain walls that you have to climb. They take a great deal of turns to climb and eat your stamina, if you find yourself having to climb mountains frequently you will die, and you may want to explore a different route or a new world entirely.-Chests in the water are also death-traps but if you can manage it, they may offer useful loot.-Teleportation Pills will save you from Bandits, Bears, or Golems.-Axes will destroy walls and chests with ease for better dungeon navigation.-Bows and Lances will help you kill your enemies from a distance, very beginner friendly weapons, unless you have no arrows. Negatives about this game - The loss of your character after completeing the game is without a doubt a loss, but the ability to save his gear makes up for it, despite the fact it is battered and will probably have to be repaired despite my deep loathing of the brittle debuff.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 24, 2015
												One Way Heroics (OWH), is a Quick paced Rogue-like RPG made from the RPG maker Series. Sounds simple, and is easily hidden amongst the other "Maker Games" on Steam. But this is one RPG that you should not miss. It's Challenging, Fast-Paced, and Addicting. As the name implies you will be going one way with your "heroics" as you battle the Darkness that is plaguing the world you inhabit (as the different world are classified as alternate dimensions in-game)Pros- A Decent array of Classes, 2 to begin 8 overall (3 more if you get the expansion).- No two world are the same allowing for a new exciting experience each time, and if you liked a world you played before you have access to that in your logs.- Simple yet thrilling combat: with the unique "one way" mechanic, the combat does not allow you to dawdle and grind. You will have to defeat enemies Quickly.Con (As the only one i can really think of as of writing this review)- Slow Start: the Game is tough, While it's nice that the first two classes you start with are easy to play, the Classes you unlock will take a bit of practice to get used to making it a tad difficult to unlock early achievements.Otherwise One Way Heroics is a fast paced RPG that looks generic but should Not be Overlooekd just becasue of that. IF you like Simple yet thrilling RPGs then One Way Heroics is a Game for you!

content:
Posted: August 10, 2014
												There's not much I can add that isn't on a dozen reviews already.  I got this game with a Humble Bundle, but it's easily worth the asking price and more.    You move through procedurally generated  worlds while trying not to get swallowed by the darkness (the left edge of the screen), picking up treasure and fighting monsters along the way.  With luck you will be strong enough to take on the demon lord.   But..there's more.  The demon lord can be a friend.  There are other people you can recruit, a number of unlockable classes, and a host of perks.  The real enemy is the darkness itself....I'm averaging about half an hour per playthrough so far.  There's enough here to keep your mind busy - thinking up strategies, and running around looting things without running out of time - but the game's not going to bog down either.As for replayability:  New dimensions, different classes, different endings?  This game has you covered.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 4, 2014
												So the game hits on a lot of nostalgia for me.  With the very retro RPG look, and the handling of an old school adventure RPG, it's already got a lot going for it.The game play is basically a "Run from the wall of death" style game reminicent of old side scrollers, where if the Death Wall (the Darkness in this case) gets you, you die, while at the same time, all of your resources are limited and nothing is infinite.  This makes the game heavy on the two major elements of game play:  Risk/Reward and Resourse Management.  Do I want to venture into that dungeon?  Will I get more out of it then I use to go in?  Will I die?The other big element of gameplay is multiple play throughs.  You do a dimention, and either win or die.  All characters are "one and done."  On each subsequent play through, you make new characters, allowing you knowledge of what your characters are good and bad at, and giving you control over HOW you'll play each adventure.  After each adventure, you get points that you can use to unlock stronger abilities (perks), new classes, and expand the "Dimentional Box" which allows you to carry a limited number of items over to new adventures, or to merely store them for future difficult adventures.The final big element of the game is the randomly genereated dimentions.  Each play through you can go to a new random dimention (with differing base parameters), replay old dimentions (same base parameters but different world layout), or do any of the current special dimentions with descriptions of what's special about them.  Alternately, you can input dimention codes manually to have a similar experience as friends, to find dimentions that spawn things you might want (finding codes online), or just to do your own variety of random.Pros:- That price!- Lots of replay value- Enough customization options- Very rewarding gameplayCons:- Some dimentions can be surprisingly difficult even on the easiest mode- Can be grind intensiveTips:- I have a coveted "Lumberjack Battleaxe" which is just the best at breaking walls.- Nice easy dimention:  RVOFGTKI

												I went into One Way Heroics...not expecting too much. Rogue-likes were always difficult for me to grasp. And I am always weak at taking on the difficulty curve, however those expectations were quickly turned around though. It was great, not only that there's something about the...feel? of the game that really struck a chord with me, the...melancholic, joking, and sometimes self-sacrificing manner the chat, dialogue and text went about.One of the best things I can say about One Way Heroics though, is the relative simplicity of it compared to other Roguelikes. Personally, I always loved Roguelikes, but I could never really enjoy them due to the aforementioned rather crazy steep learning curve which I always had issues handling. However, One Way Heroics was easy, Simple goal, Simple controls. A truly magnificent experience. I am sorely tempted to rate it among the top of the games I played ^_^

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
												One Way Heroics satirizes the classic RPG genre with its 8-bit graphics and generic storyline. Your mission, should you choose to accept it, is to slay the evil Demon Lord and save King Viktor's kingdom from certain destruction. There are different modes/difficulties to choose from; from starting a quick adventure that lasts 400km to an epic adventure to the end of time and space. Gather allies, fight evil, kill innocent animals or fight the very people you sought to protect - nothing is impossible, besides maybe turning youself into a fish. With full steam achievement and trading card support there are plenty of reasons to play and have tons of fun while doing it. Happy Questing.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												To the team who made this game: I wish I could shake your hands. This is just great. Just great.Now, to the rest of the people, who want to know if they should buy the game. YES. DEFINITELY YES!The price is ridiculously low. I got this game by selling trading cards.The graphics are "fine". I don't know the engine this game was made on, but if I had to guess, I would say RPG Maker VX Ace (I use that engine for my works, and the graphics are pretty close) with a loooooot of custom scripting. Another reason this game is so good. A lot of work has been put on it, and I can see it.So yeah, the graphics. They match the gameplay perfectly and they don't "try too hard" to impress. They are pretty, they are simple and they are great.The music is pretty good too. Again, the music matches the gameplay and the whole atmosphere.The story. Well, WHICH one? I mean, every player, has their own experience. YOU choose your path. YOU choose what to do with the guy or girl you are controlling. YOU can go around and kill everyone. Or YOU can be the hero and kill the Demon Lord. And on top of all, it's Rogue-like. That means, that everytime you play, even if you try to do exactly the same things, you will have a different experience.This game has humor. When you "socialize" with your "companion", a smile on your face is guaranteed.The only thing that I kinda hoped I could change, is the speed the darkness advances. The speed is perfect, don't get me wrong, but I would love to mess around a bit.All in all, great game, I bought it for 0,74 euros and I would buy it even if it was 7 euros.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												One Way Heroics is a rogue-type constantly moving rpg. In short, it's a brilliant game for a lover of rpgs who also happens to be incredibly ADHD. I picked it up for in incredibly low price (less than a dollar!) and got way more than my money's worth. I would pay more for this game, if only I wasn't a cheap sonofagun.The game starts with a basic intro, then throws you right into character making. Not many choices for now, but after the first run (and death) it becomes obvious that there are many more classes, perks, and items to unlock.My first few runs were less than perfect. I found one chest out of thirty and didn't even make it 100km. I tried to esacpe from monsters by going into the mountains. HINT: Don't do that.But I was immediately hooked. I loved the looks, the AMAZING music, and I really wanted to beat the hell out of the enemies that were doing the same to me.I'll be playing this game very often. I give it a 9/10.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												First of all, this game is unforgiving. If this statment puts a bad taste in your mouth, then this game is not for you. However, if what I just said doesn't bother you at all, then you just might have found a gem worth keeping. This game is a rougelike, so don't expect to have all the pieces of the puzzle when you first begin. (Google "Rougelike" if you don't know what that term means, trust me it helps.) Your first dozen (or few dozen, depending on your luck) playthroughs are more than likely going to end in failure, and the world will be doomed without you. However, as you discover strategies that work (and ones that don't) things will start to turn around. Still, odds are you will die more times than you will reach that happy ending. But that's the thing, the game doesn't stop at the ending. Multiple endings add to replay value, as do multiple objectives that you don't even know exist when the game begins. Add in the fact that worlds are randomly generated, and you will never have two playthroughs that are quite the same (aside from multiple deaths, as that is always a possibility).In short, this game will give you back everything that you put into it. If you don't give it a chance, you will have wasted your money. Fight through the first dozen deaths and learn from your mistakes, and this game will leave you addicted like it has done for me.

												This game is amazing. It's something that you can just pick up and play whenever you have a bit of free time. The replay value is infinite. You control a character that is running away from the darkness that is engulfing the world. Your goal is to slay the Demon Lord to stop the darkness. Everything in between is a massive fight to survive and power up so that you can actually stand up to the Demon Lord. There are millions of dimensions with different map configurations. You can make the game very difficult if you want a challenge or very easy if you want some quick achievements.Get this if you like old school RPG and RTS games. You won't regret it.For you achievement hunters out there, this is a fairly easy game to 100%. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 4, 2014
												So the game hits on a lot of nostalgia for me.  With the very retro RPG look, and the handling of an old school adventure RPG, it's already got a lot going for it.The game play is basically a "Run from the wall of death" style game reminicent of old side scrollers, where if the Death Wall (the Darkness in this case) gets you, you die, while at the same time, all of your resources are limited and nothing is infinite.  This makes the game heavy on the two major elements of game play:  Risk/Reward and Resourse Management.  Do I want to venture into that dungeon?  Will I get more out of it then I use to go in?  Will I die?The other big element of gameplay is multiple play throughs.  You do a dimention, and either win or die.  All characters are "one and done."  On each subsequent play through, you make new characters, allowing you knowledge of what your characters are good and bad at, and giving you control over HOW you'll play each adventure.  After each adventure, you get points that you can use to unlock stronger abilities (perks), new classes, and expand the "Dimentional Box" which allows you to carry a limited number of items over to new adventures, or to merely store them for future difficult adventures.The final big element of the game is the randomly genereated dimentions.  Each play through you can go to a new random dimention (with differing base parameters), replay old dimentions (same base parameters but different world layout), or do any of the current special dimentions with descriptions of what's special about them.  Alternately, you can input dimention codes manually to have a similar experience as friends, to find dimentions that spawn things you might want (finding codes online), or just to do your own variety of random.Pros:- That price!- Lots of replay value- Enough customization options- Very rewarding gameplayCons:- Some dimentions can be surprisingly difficult even on the easiest mode- Can be grind intensiveTips:- I have a coveted "Lumberjack Battleaxe" which is just the best at breaking walls.- Nice easy dimention:  RVOFGTKI

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
												This is an extremely engaging game with simple mechanics that work well for it. If you are a fan of JRPGs or loot snagging in general, you'll have a great time.Despite this being a procedurally generated roguelike game, it does manage to squeeze in some story and interesting characters. The unique bit is that, the generation is based off of whatever you want to type in. If you die in the dimension you entered if you want to revisit that dimension, the map generated will be the same (from what I've seen). This means that you can try to learn aspects of a specific dimension and plan around it. Don't worry about the random generation screwing you over too hard either. On each character run you are always given 15 free turns that you can use in bundles of 3 whenever you want. So if you see a long stretch of unavoidable mountains, you could in theory use all 15 turns to pass them if it was really that bad/unavoidable. The combat is simplistic, but deep enough that strategy actually matters since your positioning will often determine the outcome of a fight if more than one opponent is present. The game has a fair number of weapons and weapon types, some of which offer longer ranges and others which are really great at busting down terrain (Yes, you can break down walls of a house to talk to the people inside).If you love optimization, NPC party building, pretending you actually have friends or are just looking for a fun game with a wonderful soundtrack, I'd spend the 83 cents to play this. I believe the regular asking price is $3, which is more than fair. Had I not only found this thanks to the steam sale, I would have gladly paid the $3.
