number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 1, 2014
												First things first, do you like Roguelikes? If so then this game is a very prospective find for your collection! It's a very perma death and turn based unforgiving type game but of course it has features that work around that kind of system, being able to bring items over from previous gameplays and also unlocking new classes and perks to make yourself stronger at the beginning. The pace it sets with the darkness constantly chasing you is very fresh as well because not only is it a roguelike game but it also has aspects of time management almost like Half Minute Hero, making gameplay have a much more frantic pace even though it's still turn based. Another thing that makes the game fun to play is the online features, it's always fun playing a game and knowing others are doing the same, the little pop in messages aren't disruptive at all and seeing how far other people are reaching and how many other people are failing is fun in it's own rights. Of course, it's got the sharing aspect from games like Minecraft and Starbound, you can share any of the worlds that have been generated by simply giving the world's code to friends and other people. All the worlds have their own little leaderboards too, with rankings and other things, you can even see how people went about their adventure. Also, you can actually get better at a world/dimension since it's layout never changes aside from random loot drops and events. Overall, while simplistic and a bit more on the hectic/rushed side, it's still pretty in depth, especially with the carryovers and whatnot, you can even grind items out to twink yourself up for the next run. As an ending note, don't expect to win early on unless you play on the easiest difficulty, losses are inevitable on this game as they are a part of it, take it in as it comes and build yourself up to become stronger to finally defeat the Demon Lord!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 15, 2014
												Okay, One Way Heroics is not a normal RPG, not by any means. Sure, there are the usual suspects, such as stats, leveling, items, monsters and even a final boss. But that is where the similarities end. Each game is a race against the clock where the encroaching darkness at the left of the screen advances while your heroic character must scramble right in search of experience, items, gold and helpful npc's.Sound fun so far? It gets better, not only is the difficulty brutally hard and the classes vary in play style, but each world you play in is randomly determined at the start of a game. You can keep the names of these worlds and re-enter them to go back to the same world as before, yet even then the experiences are fresh enough to ensure replayability of the highest caliber.Like in Rogue Legacy, death is not the end of your efforts. Choosing a new class, and storing items in the dimensional vault makes the next game a little less harrowing if you choose. You can use the Hero points, awarded at the end of the game to unlock more classes and perks.That being said, I was not kidding when I mentioned the brutal difficulty. In addition to powerful enemies, you might not have the best equipment because merchants do not appear often and you might not have cash at hand then. Or they appear often, but sell basic articles. And if you find a legendary sword? Use it sparingly as all equipment has a lifebar of such, if it runs out they break. Unless you have awesome perks and have gained levels at a crazy rate you can't beat the Demon Lord naked and unarmed.In conclusion, this game is truly one that gives great bang for so few bucks. So get it!

content:
Posted: August 10, 2014
												There's not much I can add that isn't on a dozen reviews already.  I got this game with a Humble Bundle, but it's easily worth the asking price and more.    You move through procedurally generated  worlds while trying not to get swallowed by the darkness (the left edge of the screen), picking up treasure and fighting monsters along the way.  With luck you will be strong enough to take on the demon lord.   But..there's more.  The demon lord can be a friend.  There are other people you can recruit, a number of unlockable classes, and a host of perks.  The real enemy is the darkness itself....I'm averaging about half an hour per playthrough so far.  There's enough here to keep your mind busy - thinking up strategies, and running around looting things without running out of time - but the game's not going to bog down either.As for replayability:  New dimensions, different classes, different endings?  This game has you covered.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 12, 2015
												I seriously enjoy this game. One of my favorite aspects of a randomly generated world is the fact that you're not going to see everything the first play through... Or the second play through... Or even the twenty-second! I still have not figured out how to recruit other party members during the journey, but I'm fine with that because I've been so preoccupied with discovering all the other things you can do with different classes.Speaking of classes, I normally hate class systems in an RPG. When you have to devote to one for the entire game and you're not even sure if it's your favorite because you haven't got to try the others yet. But in One Way Heroics, many runs are fairly short, so you can try every class that you like. Get a feel for all of them. Then play the one you feel like playing based on your mood. It's kind of like a fighter game in that aspect; you pick a character based on the kind of match you expect to have.Another great thing about the classes in One Way Heroics is the fact that they all have something unique and interesting to bring to the table. Each has a special skills, and each has regular skills that they perform better or with a bonus. It's balanced pretty well and it makes picking a favorite for your style of play easy.The variety of items is the last good point I'd like to touch on. One thing I almost always start out with is increased inventory ability, because I love picking up as many items as I can and using them effectively. One Way Heroics exhibits great balance between character stats and the necessity for equipment. You can make your character strong, sure, but if you don't find a rare and powerful weapon or some really good armor, you're going to be running from the demon lord many times before you can hope to fight him.The one down side to this game I'll mention is the character design. The artwork is a little sloppy looking, though charming in it's own way, and the character dialog, while funny at first, is a little lacking in terms of variety. Well. during gameplay anyway--Dialog is actually pretty good during cut scenes, as I am hit with something new almost every new game and end game. Finally characters feel a little flat. Even though the after story of you and the fairy continuing your journey after the world is saved is rather touching, it feels awkward because I don't really feel connected to the characters. They're too generic, but then, maybe that was intended.All in all, great game. 9/10(This is my first review, so I haven't developed any kind of coherent style.)

												This is a gem of a game that I picked up for $.87, would've paid full price in hindsight. The simple concept, the execution in a rougelike randomly* generated rpg world-- and it all comes together wonderfully in whatever way you want it to. A quick, leisurely stroll into a final boss confrontation that might end with a little cheeky grin? Aye, not too hard to play your cards that way on easymode after you test the game dynamics in a few runs. Something a little more intensive and nervewracking for that character you've grown fond of as they developed? You can have that too. Layer on top the rotating special worlds you can select and the game has fantastic replayability that more than outweighs the meagre price.9/10. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
												One Way Heroics is a Mystery Dungeon-style roguelike (that is, similar to Pokemon Mystery Dungeon, Chocobo's Dungeon, Shiren, Izuna, etc) with an open world that constantly scrolls to the right, meaning you have limited time to spend in each place and you have to keep moving forward to avoid death by screen edge.Gameplay is standard Mystery Dungeon-style roguelike fare; you have an attack button, inventory with weight limit, three pieces of equipment, some basic stats, everything is turn-based, the usual stuff. Unlike other Mystery Dungeons the world is open (though you can't go back, obviously) with mini-towns and dungeons spread throughout the map. Objective of the game is to level up and get good items to defeat the Demon Lord.Items can be passed to future characters after your run, and you get a score in points which you can use to unlock classes, unlock perks or expand your item storage. Character creation is limited to picking a class and a bunch of simple perks. Various difficulty levels, and a 'Maniac mode' makes the game harder by disabling the item storage. Unfortunately there are perma-saves with no mode for a no-save run; not saving is entirely optional and only gets you a few extra points.Definitely worth it for the really low price.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
												Pure genius.  One Way Heroics is probably one of the better indie games this year that you won't hear about.If you enjoy generated games or the old school sprite RPG's, get this, get it now.The game-play is pseudo-turn-based where every time the player performs an action, the game world will iterate as well.Pros: Excellent replay value. Nice sprite visuals Fun, Simple gameplay: Run right, adventure, fight or flee from a large variety of monsters, search for supplies. Visit towns and talk to NPCS. Do all of the above while impending doom is always advancing towards you. Due to generated content, you never know what you'll encounter.  Each new adventure has its surprises. Lots of secrets to uncover. Works with gamepads other than the Xbox360 Controller. Able to carry some equipment over to a new adventure.Cons: None.  Although you need to come into this game expecting to replay it repeatedly to really get anything out of it.  Not a traditional linear RPG at all.One of my favorite indie games for 2014.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2014
												This game is far-worth the less-than-1$ I've spent on it, to get as much time as I've had out of it all in one sitting...The entire urgency feeling that "the darkness" puts upon you is one of (if not -the-) game's defining factor(s).You end up weighing in how much loot you can drag with you, what loot to drag with you, what items to keep on you, what stats to raise at an altar (because you want to carry more items right? RIGHTT??!?), how far you can even get through a dungeon before it becomes too risky, what monsters you should engage (is that lizard behind that chest a noob? or will he kill me in 2 hits right after i open this treasure chest...), how you should play your class (focus characters are a total pain in the♥♥♥♥♥..even though I killed the final boss in only 3 hits, as opposed to 100...total pain-in-the♥♥♥♥♥), what class to play after you've tried them all (heck, I've JUST tried them all...they're all unique enough to want a bit of each of them, even though the first two are quite similar).Its just a total cluster♥♥♥♥ of choices put upon you, all because of the timed factor...I'm ashamed to say I don't even know what some of the stats even DO I've been so sucked into playing the game and not worrying about it...If that sounds too stressful for you, don't worry, it isnt, the game doesn't take itself too seriously, with cutesy anime graphics everywhere, and your hilarious little fairy companion that you might get a dialogue prompt asking to 'equip' (lol!). The first difficulty is cakewalk anyways...you could practically travel all the way to the demon lord (the final boss) without picking up a single item, or leveling up at all, and still beat him if you were careful enough. That doesn't mean it isn't fun as heck to play, since the further you go the harder the game gets, but you get to choose if you go just as far as you need to to finish, or if you push on to get better gear for the final battle...CHOICES! :pHavn't played anything like this before, probably won't find another chance to...That, and, with the time I've had right now (7hrs) I've only scratched the surface, beating the game once with each character on only the easiest difficulty!

content:
Posted: January 2, 2015
												A cute game that satisfied all my expectations!But~ expect a rigid story and you'll be disappointed as the story is rogue-like as is the gameplay. Although this also means that there is room to tell your own tale in the adventures that will be had.The difficulty is hard from the get go, and you'll take risks along the way to level up- Being too careful will hinder your level from rising, but barging in to a fight expecting to win will usually not end well!So you will have to take use of the turn-based system to plan a strategy. But! Is there enough time for a rigid strategy as the world is swallowed up behind you? (each turn) -That is for you to adapt to as you discover this ever changing landscape.-Good-About the turn-based system, keep in mind it goes as fast as you want it to. You can run just as in any overview-2d game. But when you stop, everything else stops. This makes it both exhilarating but calming at the same time to me!Want to compete with other players? You can play the very same world (not simultaneously) and check leaderboards for whom performed the best in a variety of aspects such as leveling and treasure hunting etc-.And lest forget the character art, they have a charming manga-illustration kind of look which takes me back Final Fantasy IV.-Cons-Not a variety of tile texture- Since you'll find yourself writing a story to complement the lack of complete story, a larger variety of landscapes to inspire our minds would be nice. Also weather and lightning effects would be welcome.No simultaneous multiplayer (just leaderboards). If the creators got an idea for how to implement multiplayer but still hold this fast-paced turn-based system, i could potentially see how that'd make for a sequel with great promise! But that's just me. (^^)Okay! Get to the adventure! :3楽しんでくださいね！

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												To the team who made this game: I wish I could shake your hands. This is just great. Just great.Now, to the rest of the people, who want to know if they should buy the game. YES. DEFINITELY YES!The price is ridiculously low. I got this game by selling trading cards.The graphics are "fine". I don't know the engine this game was made on, but if I had to guess, I would say RPG Maker VX Ace (I use that engine for my works, and the graphics are pretty close) with a loooooot of custom scripting. Another reason this game is so good. A lot of work has been put on it, and I can see it.So yeah, the graphics. They match the gameplay perfectly and they don't "try too hard" to impress. They are pretty, they are simple and they are great.The music is pretty good too. Again, the music matches the gameplay and the whole atmosphere.The story. Well, WHICH one? I mean, every player, has their own experience. YOU choose your path. YOU choose what to do with the guy or girl you are controlling. YOU can go around and kill everyone. Or YOU can be the hero and kill the Demon Lord. And on top of all, it's Rogue-like. That means, that everytime you play, even if you try to do exactly the same things, you will have a different experience.This game has humor. When you "socialize" with your "companion", a smile on your face is guaranteed.The only thing that I kinda hoped I could change, is the speed the darkness advances. The speed is perfect, don't get me wrong, but I would love to mess around a bit.All in all, great game, I bought it for 0,74 euros and I would buy it even if it was 7 euros.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
												One Way Heroics satirizes the classic RPG genre with its 8-bit graphics and generic storyline. Your mission, should you choose to accept it, is to slay the evil Demon Lord and save King Viktor's kingdom from certain destruction. There are different modes/difficulties to choose from; from starting a quick adventure that lasts 400km to an epic adventure to the end of time and space. Gather allies, fight evil, kill innocent animals or fight the very people you sought to protect - nothing is impossible, besides maybe turning youself into a fish. With full steam achievement and trading card support there are plenty of reasons to play and have tons of fun while doing it. Happy Questing.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
												I managed to snag this game for one dollar, and even at it's worst it is a couple bucks. And quite frankly it feels like I'm robbing the developers. I've been pretty hooked the last few days on it and expect to push through until I get full completion.It is a rogue-like game, meaning that it has perma death and randomly generated worlds. You make a character, you pick from some classes and perks, and you push that character as far as it can go. A darkness on the left side of the screen keeps you moving ever forward in your attempt to get as much gear and power before your inevitable death or the death of the endboss. When you die, you gain some points that you can use to unlock more bonuses to choose from and slowly amass a constant storage between characters so you can save some epic items.There is no real multiplayer other than a Dark Souls-like feature where you encounter the ghosts of players on the same server that benefit you slightly and that you can compete with. The sound is cute and retro, nothing astounding. The visuals are about Final Fantasy 1 quality but are pretty enough to get you through. The gameplay really hooks me. For some people, you will spend many hours through many characters striving to do better and unlock everything. For others, you'll play for an hour or two. And for the price you pay, you really can't go wrong.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 17, 2015
												=HEADS UP=I had a review before this one about the game being good. This stays of course but i had to clarify some points and fix this old messy review that i made before.=INFO ABOUT THE REVIEW=1. My reviews tend to be a bit longer. If that is the case please be patient and read everything.2. This review is about my point of view and opinion. [If you disagree on a certain point or want to correct me: Be reasonable or i will ignore your comment.]3. If you want to try to change my opinion with arguments that make no sense in any way then please do not comment at all.=REVIEW=Now what can i say about this game? That it is worth the money. It is a small game with only one purpose for you. Go forth and kill stuff. But there is a twist to it. The World is ending and you are the legendary hero to venture out and try to get ahead of what is coming after you to kill you. And what is that right behind you? Pure Darkness.This game leads in a certain direction and that one is Right. You go as far as you can get to meet at the end the Bad guy to stop the End of the World. But that is not an easy task. Even though this game is semi roguelike you wont have that much trouble with it like other roguelike games. Over the time of you playing you will die. But everytime you can transfer items into a little box that is between the dimensions. And as soon as you visit a new world you can decide if you want to take it with you or not. This makes the game a bit more enjoyable and easier for you. But in the end it depends on you how it ends.The game brings you into a randomly generated world. Here will the Adventure begin and here you can do whatever you want. Go on and kill some bad guys. You are the Hero. Go into the Taverns and buy gear and let the people help you. Or just kill them and their guards. That is right. You are allowed to do everything you want. Kill, destroy and so on and so forth. But there is a nice twist to it. If you are the great Hero you are able to find people that want to help you defeating the bad guy. And since everyone trusts you they will not attack you when seeing you. If you do attack other people though the game will punish you. The word goes around very fast and in other inns or taverns the guards will recognize you for what you did and will try to kill you. But not only the guards will turn aggressive but also the other people.So it is up to you what will happen in the game. At the very end it is the bad guy who you want to kill. But it depends on you how easy or hard this may be.

content:
Posted: January 29, 2015
												Hey everyone and this is my review about the game!This is a RPG Rogue-like game.Interface/Menu/SettingsThere are some settings before the launch. at Config. You can choose if you want to play on a high pc/medium pc or a low end pc. (you can change during the game by pressing F5).There is 3D mode and software mode. Software mode is better for low end pc.There is a Sound volume slidebar and it is marked with bars.There is a music volume slidebar and it is marked with bars.Pressing F10 will make it fullscreen. Pressing it again will make it windowed.You can play with a controller.About the game.You are playing a hero that has to defeat the evil. You can choose between a class and a perk. Each with their own effect and attritbutes. Each step that you take will bring you closer to the evil. But the game is side-scrolling and everything on the left is "destroyed" and you are forced to keep walking to the right. Whenever the screen has catched up, you will die. Every step, Every move, Every action that you will do, will bring the left side of the screen closer to you. You have to kill enemies to get experience to level up and finding loot to make your character stronger. Once you have finished a run, you will get points at the end of the level which will help you on the next run. (once you have spend it ofcourse).Game has very good music.Gameplay is fun but a bit repetitive.Graphics is decent.The game is fun but at some parts tricky too.There are different save slots.Other things.Let's Try Video:

			HEY EVERYONE, Im going to make every game out of my steam library, a let's try. If the game is approved i will make a recording for later.		

-------------------I Give this game a 8/10

content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
												Welp, if you're a fan of either RTS or Rouge-likes, this game is for you. Scratch that, this game is for anybody! Its really entertaining, espically the characters and dialouge. The combat is fairly average, at first! Firstly you have a sword, you target with shift and press space. Then you find out you can break blocks a'la'Minecraft. Then you get a shield AND sword! And then you realize you have special moves! And then you realize they take up energy/stamina! And then you die. :P  Like that, the game is very in-depth about multiple things, and, like many rouge-lites, you will die. But I swear, this game is the Dark Souls of RTS.  Now, the only bad thing about the game is that due to the impending wall of black death, you never really get the chance to explore dungeons, so they'll just be part of the scenery in most laythroughs. Also, some the terrain generation can be kinda weird, causing mountains to spawn and impede you, thus killing you because you couldn't move in time because of the darkness. These instances are both rare however, and can be overlooked for the sheer joy of this game.Epic Game, buy it now since its on sale, and I can promise you it'll be a blast.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 20, 2015
												For a game that regularly goes on sale for less than a dollar, it's absolutely amazing, the dlc for the game, while making the game harder, adds so much convenience to the interface. Now for the breakdownMusic The music is never really downbeat, though there are times when it's calmed down. It tends to pick up to a rousing adventure theme when combat really begins to happen The music in towns is really calming, to the point that I've just sat in towns listening to the music playing I tend to reccomend listening to the music of any game prior to purchase though, and there's an awesome playlist on youtube containing all of the music from the game.Interface The interface in the base game is kind of unintuitive, with the keys being used as follows: R T W A S D Ctrl Shift There might have been more, but either never needed them, or they just didn't come up. The intro menu here is really simple, but the opportunity to rerun a map you like just because you remember its seed is awesome, but there's not much that's all that interesting in the intro menu. The in-game menus are interesting, but I do have just one issue in that you can "use" a bomb, by which I mean it will just explode on you. I don't know why this is an option but I accidently use the bomb instead of throwing it more often than I'd like to admit. But beyond the occasional issue with that, the menus are easy to understand, just getting into it the first time is a bit interesting. The interface in the expansion is much more compact with the numbers on the keyboard being used for quick acess inventory slots. The rest of the keys are: Z X C V Shift Ctrl W A S D or the arrowsThe expansion makes the menus even easier to use, as well as picking up dropped items.Gameplay It's a Turn based roguelike with the opportunity to overcome every map that I've come across, though it may take several attempts to do so.The combat is really intuitive, where the combination of shift and direction makes aiming easy, and there's only one attack button, which allows you to really take advantage of the turn-based global interaction.It is possible to get all pooped on by the spawning of the enemies, or even by travelling to the wrong bit of the map and getting stuck behind a wall of mountains, but so far, I've had only a couple of instances where this happened. My complaints here are really just twofold, with the first one being the bomb issue. There's a number of games I lost because of that, but it's my fault. The other is how slow the game can be on the longer runs, but the expansion allows the speeding up of movement so I no longer have this issue.StoryNope. not telling you. If you want to find out, do so yourself.It is a compelling story found out through gameplay if done correctly though.Really, as a quick sum up of all that: the game is really well put together and the expansion just tightens some controls and adds to the game as a whole. I spent $7 on this and as you can see I've put in 40-ish hours into it. I love it, and it's something that, if you like the gameplay, you'll love the game. If you don't like the aesthetics and or the gameplay, you won't really feel bad about it because you've probably spent more money on worse games.Enjoy! I did.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 29, 2016
												One Way Heroics is a 2D overhead rogue-like game where you're constantly escaping from an ever encroaching black mist coming from the left. If the mist catches up to you, or you die then it's completely game over and you start again while given the option to retain some of the items from this run, unlocking various new features classes and goodies along the way.The game, at first, gives you a constant drive to play. The classes seem interesting and relatively varied and unlocking new skills, classes, and goodies in general is a fun. The interface and visuals are basic but well fleshed out and feel great, giving a bit of nostalgia to the 8-bit era of games like Dragon Quest Warrior. However, the issues with the game become apparent after the honeymoon period wears off.The first of two major issues is the most unique aspect of the game - the darkness. The darkness was undoubtedly designed to create a sort of pacing and pressure, and at first it does. But once you become accustomed to the pacing of the game all it really does is discourage exploration. So long as you don't explore you'll never run into any problems with the darkness. But I happen to enjoy exploring!The second is in the balance of the game. I think the best way to illustrate this is with one particularly absurd example. The main villain in the game is the demon lord. He'll occasionally fly in and you're supposed to wack at him a bit, constantly denting his hp a bit, until he flies away only to come back again. Rince, wash, repeat, until he's dead and the credits roll. One major strength of his is in shields - each time he appears, he has up to 45 layers of shields that need to be removed before you can even start damaging him. With a mellee class that might do just a few hits per turn at most while he's pounding on you with all he has - this is a big problem. For a mage class? Well for some reason their attacks go right through the shields. On the hardest difficultly level in the game, I defeated him the first time he appeared by just zapping him a few time with the weakest attack the mage has boosted by a pretty generic staff and beat him the first time he appeared - achieving consistent victory on the max difficulty in about 15 minutes. Pretty anticlimatic for a roguelike. This isn't a game you'll be spending hundreds and probably not even tens of hours on, but for a fun 10 or 20 hour romp it's an enjoyable experience.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 1, 2016
												One Way Heroics is a simple rogue-like with a lot of character. The worlds are randomly generated and randomly populated, so each play through is different. The difficulty is moderate, and each run through a campaign yields points that can be used for upgrades, making subsequent runs easier. OWH keeps a large record of all sorts of statistics and completionists will find plenty of stuff to do in order to fill out the statistics screen.OWH includes all sorts of endings and random events within the worlds. Every supporting character has their own interesting stories, and discovering the whole story behind the game across multiple playthroughs an interesting approach to narrative. It also has a fantastic soundtrack.The DLC is a great addition and adds a fair bit of content and replayabilitiy, though the base game still feels complete enough to have provided me dozens of hours of play. The game is flexible enough where you can do a short 15 minute run or a several hour long journey, if you wish. At the asking price, One Way Heroics is more than worth it, and is my favorite rogue-like on Steam. I cannot recommend this game enough.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 12, 2016
												One Way Heroics is an auto-scrolling rogue-like. As you move about and act in the game, the screen will slowly moves to the right - and should it reach your character it will devour you in darkness..... The goal of the game is essentially all about keeping ahead of the encroaching darkness as you travel across various lands. You get stronger, collecting items and leveling up, stop in settlements (before they can consumed by darkness) and eventually you will battle across the lands against the Demon Lord behind it all!And... that's it. The vanilla game is a cheap game after all and the DLC you get adds in a good deal more content to improve the gaming experience. Without it, you'll get a nice taste of what the gameplay is all about though it will feel somewhat lacking quite quickly.Notably though you can buy the game and its DLC for a fairly cheap price bundled together. Also, keep in mind that you may want to keep and eye out for Mystery Chronicle: One Way Heroics; which is a sequel to this game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 17, 2015
												Short answer: Reccomended for completionists, peopel who love NG+, and achievement hunters. If you like to complete a game and put it away, your experience may be lacking.This review is somewhat late, as I beat it several months ago. It only took me about 4-6 playthroughs if I remember right. I think I only unlocked 2 additional classes and barely any of the other content, as I was able to "win" through the luck of the RNG. I am someone who does not mind restarting games over and over due to dying and learning, but I can't say I like replaying a game once I've beat it.One Way Heroics has fairly standard roguelike combat which I got the hang of fairly easily having played other games. The darkness adds an additional layer to this, almost making it like chess - you have to be able to plan your moves several steps ahead, taking into account each enemy's movement speed, movement patterns, item locations, and whether you might get trapped by the terrain. This can all be done fairly rapidly in most areas outside towns and dungeons. The game, being a rogelike, has a decent amount of teaching through experience and playthroughs.The big big big gripe I have with the game, and is the primary reason I wish I could give a "mixed" rating? I managed to kill the dark lord before I think I should have been able to. I discovered one of the special artifact items and managed to fight him inside a town. Just a single artifact, my level wasn't that high. I truly expected him to be harder. Then I expected that to not be all and for the devs to pull a "Disc 1 final boss" on me. But no, the Big Bad of the game can be defeated by simply holeing up in an inn with a single artifact weapon and blowing all your items and special abilities.  I had no longer felt a real desire to play it afterwards.However, this is my personal taste. While I find the idea of NG+ and completing a game many many times fairly dull (in most cases) for those people who DO like that sort of gameplay, this is a decent offering. I didn't encounter many, if any bugs in my playing, and the visuals are uniformly presented with nothing that seemed out of place. Worth the money for that kind of player, and having gotten it on sale and with the addition of trading cards I can't say it wasn't worth the 69 cents I paid for it, if not more.

content:
Posted: June 18, 2015
												So, I picked this game up for under a dollar, not really expecting much. And I can fairly say that this is one of the best RPGS that you can pick up on steam. Interestingly enough, it's a top down perspective sidescroller. You can travel in all directions, but must continue on towards the right, for an ever-moving darkness is coming from the left, which kills on contact. Which randomly generated worlds, as well as 'challenge worlds', it has quite a bit of replay value. Very much worth picking up.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 26, 2014
												It has been fun to pick this one up  and play it for about 20-30 minutes at a time.  Whether that means 5 deaths, or "beating" the game (i've only done it in the most obvious way a few times) plus a death or two, it tends to hold the same amount of fun for me.  I appreciate the way that the difficulties are ramped, as well as the increased difficulty for certain maps given as options during new game selection.  Only thing that I haven't had a chance to read up on, is why the game is built with old squarish monitor ratios.  Screen is very busy with all of the stats on screen, but I got used to it rather quickly.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 17, 2015
												Even if I had paid full price for this, I would still recommend this game. Its a quick to play roguelike game that is easy to jump in to and play and can be difficult to master, although being that its a roguelike still means that there is an element to randomness so that even if you feel you have the hang of it you can be thrown a curve ball and knocked out.In addition to the roguelike nature of it, there is some perma elements, such as unlocking new classes to be played in next playthroughs as well as a stash that allows you to store good items for next playthroughs.Overall for the cost, whether you get it on sale or not, definitely a recommend and I definitely wish more games were as easy to jump into and have fun as this game.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 31, 2015
												Have you ever gotten a game for sale price and after playing it, you feel like you'd have been satisfied with the value even if you paid full price? For me, One Way Heroics is that, except I'd feel happy paying more than sale price.One Way Heroics is a rouge-like game kinda like a Mystery Dungeon game, except you're not stuck in a dungeon and have a randomly generated world to explore. Except with one twist: There's Darkness to the left. And it endlessly creeps up on you. And if you fall in it, you're dead! So you're stuck going to the right. And there's monsters out there, too, so remain on guard! Of course, there's helpful stuff out there, too!One Way Heroics is kinda tough at first, but it gets easier as you go along, unlock classes, and generally get an idea of what to do. And it's alright if you mess up after you got some cool item, because after you die or clear you game, you're allowed to put items into the Dimensional Vault, to use them on another run. You've got limited space, though, so until you're heroic enough to expand it, watch how you use it!I had a lot of fun with this game, and I only spent 87 cents on it! So it's a definite recommendation from me.

												Rogue like with lots of snes era jrpg nostalgia baked in, lots of classes/perks/abilities to unlock giving it loads of replayabilityIf you playd anything like FTL, Rogue Legacy, or BoI you should like this game, also an amazing soundtrack that is very nostalgic of old school snes Final Fantasy and Chrono Trigger style musicThis is one of those games that costs you a penny (less than $3 at the writing of this post) but can give you upwards of 70 hours of gameplay depending on how much you get into unlocking all the classes and stuffFor a price that low, I say, give it a go

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 26, 2014
One of the best and most addictive indie rogue-like RPGs I ever played.Personally this is my favorite!Unique idea of going "One Way" to the right of the screen, without turning back or you will be consumed by the "Darkness" and die. The goal is to defeat the "Demon Lord", defeat the "Darkness Dragon" or reach the "End of the World" at 2000 kilometers.Many different and exciting quests/endings along with strong storytellingVarious difficulty settings and random map generation, which increases the replay valueIt has perma-death, but you can still save your gamePick up and deposit items from other playthroughs (dimensional vault)Lots of items, classes, perks and NPCs to unlockLeveling up system including different affected statssimple fast paced/turn-based combat and class specific skillsLots of depth, still simple and quick learning curveJ-RPG menus & comedytowns with merchants and other NPCsdungeons with monsters and lootonline feature which shows other players current progression in their world (live)online events/quests with specific rules, which change every daymanually input seed to replay a worldNice Anime "RPG-Maker"-like graphics. If it´s made by RPG-Maker, I would say it´s the most possible content you can get out of that engine, so far.Great fitting soundtrack :)Highly recommended and totally worth the money =P

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful6 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 17, 2015
												I bought this game not expecting too much for the price tag *insert subliminal buy now message*. Maybe a couple of hours fun or an atrasfomany like so many others. You know? The type of game where you take a break from a big game just to break the pace a bit? It has that quality sure. But never did I expect the amount of content, replayability and just plain fun I have had with this game so far. I haven't even tried out harder difficulties and many of the classes I have yet to unlock! I'll tell you about some time spent in game.I played this a bit on my own and a friend said it looked interesting. So I got it for him...the price is too good *insert subliminal buy now message* and Smoking Wolf deserves it for the excellent work!This game isn't co-op but we chose the same map to kinda compete and help each other out. We got into the same map. A nice, easy, stroll in the park difficulty map for his first time. He chose the Swordmaster class and I choose the Force user. Me being all experienced from my 2-3 hours game time, ran off looking for treasures, things to kill and xp. While happily one shotting every thing (first time Force user class...dayum) he asks some questions about the mechanics, the tutorial isn't great but you can figure most things out.I run into a Carzy Dragon knight, or something simliar, whom I one shot with glee because these guys are tough and I've died to them many times! Meanwhile my friend runs around, way behind, having a grand time. Some time passes.Suddenly he yells: "Oh **** that guy just killed me!"Me: "What? Who killed you?"Him: "Some guy in a building! What the hell!? He just killed me in one hit!" Me: "Huh? Where? All these creeps are pretty basic. Noob! Thought you had this old gamer style!? Hahahahaha!" We pride ourselves on being born gamers (another way of saying we are getting old), because we do well or above average in most games, having played games since the first Commodores. So if a game is hard or we fail our pride takes quite a hit.Him: "Some green dude in building with chests. What the ****!? Such BS..."Realization dawns. Fail friend...Me: "Hahahahaa! Sorry dude forgot to tell you those green dragon knight guys are very tough! I had no problem. Just one shot them muehehehehehe."With his fail run of the map he somehow managed to unlock the Adventurer class and decides to try it out on the same map.Him: "Ok so screw that place, Ima go ova mere." Apologies...he actually talks like that.Him: "OMF A ****ING BEAR!"NOOO!!"Me: "Hahaahhaa a bear!? What the hell man, you have the worste luck!"Him: "Noooo! He has friends!! They're chasing meeeee! They're chasing meeeeee!!! Aahhhh!"Just rofling at his attempts to run away from the killer bears. He dies horribly gain.Him: "**** those bears. I'm gonna get them."Me: "Dude bears are sick, we don't even have gear or levels to kill them, just go take another route."Him: "Nah **** that. Them bears are going down!"Me: "Psh, good luck fool."He restarts.Him: "Ok they're coming for me, gonna lead them to these guards."Me: "Could work, maybe."im: "Shweet! The guards did all the work for me! See I told you I'd get those ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s!"Me: "Nice one. Now you can finally catch up. Sheesh you suck! You've only gone like 20km all this time. I'm almost to the Demon Lord." Him: "Oh my sweet cheesus balls..."Me: "More bears?"Him: "Duuuuuuude..."Me: "What?"Him: "Duuuuuuude..."Me: "WHAT?!"Him: "Duuuuuuude...I just picked up a Godslaying longsword...."Me: "What the ****!? Where?" <----already turning jelly.Him: "From a Feral Dog! Hahaha! I just killed it and it dropped this! It has X and Y and OMFG check this Z out"Me: "..."  -.-Him: "Omg this thing is ridiculous! ###dmg in one hit! Gib, hahahahahah...gib, hahahahahaha!"Me: "How the **** does that drop from a dog!?" all jelly now, and greedy.Him: "I dunno. You're s'posed to be the expert...gib, hahahahahaha!"Me: "..." full of jelly and careless.Me: "**** I just died trying to open a stupid chest."Him: "The darkness?"Me: "Yes the darkness."Him: "Noob. Gib, hahahahahah!"He dies later because he didn't watch his Hp and we decide that dimension YYOCIFHH  has beaten us...for now. But HE gets to take his Godslaying sword over to the next level if he wants...where is MY Godlsaying longsword?? Sorry. Still jelly he got it and I didn't.This is what I like about this game:Cool new map any time you want. Adventuring and never knowing what you might find.Leveling and getting loot...so much loot. I cry a little bit every time I have to drop an unidentified item.The mechanics and gameplay are simple but I think mastering each class will be a challenge.This is "Roguelike" to a degree but far enough away to not make it grindy, repetitive and boring after 20 games. I never expected this to become one the games I regard with this much respect.So grab it! *insert subliminal buy now message* You won't regret spending a penny.Thanks for reading and thanks for a cool game Mr Wolf!

I'm gonna get them."Me: "Dude bears are sick, we don't even have gear or levels to kill them, just go take another route."Him: "Nah **** that. Them bears are going down!"Me: "Psh, good luck fool."He restarts.Him: "Ok they're coming for me, gonna lead them to these guards."Me: "Could work, maybe."im: "Shweet! The guards did all the work for me! See I told you I'd get those ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s!"Me: "Nice one. Now you can finally catch up. Sheesh you suck! You've only gone like 20km all this time. I'm almost to the Demon Lord." Him: "Oh my sweet cheesus balls..."Me: "More bears?"Him: "Duuuuuuude..."Me: "What?"Him: "Duuuuuuude..."Me: "WHAT?!"Him: "Duuuuuuude...I just picked up a Godslaying longsword...."Me: "What the ****!? Where?" <----already turning jelly.Him: "From a Feral Dog! Hahaha! I just killed it and it dropped this! It has X and Y and OMFG check this Z out"Me: "..."  -.-Him: "Omg this thing is ridiculous! ###dmg in one hit! Gib, hahahahahah...gib, hahahahahaha!"Me: "How the **** does that drop from a dog!?" all jelly now, and greedy.Him: "I dunno. You're s'posed to be the expert...gib, hahahahahaha!"Me: "..." full of jelly and careless.Me: "**** I just died trying to open a stupid chest."Him: "The darkness?"Me: "Yes the darkness."Him: "Noob. Gib, hahahahahah!"He dies later because he didn't watch his Hp and we decide that dimension YYOCIFHH  has beaten us...for now. But HE gets to take his Godslaying sword over to the next level if he wants...where is MY Godlsaying longsword?? Sorry. Still jelly he got it and I didn't.This is what I like about this game:Cool new map any time you want. Adventuring and never knowing what you might find.Leveling and getting loot...so much loot. I cry a little bit every time I have to drop an unidentified item.The mechanics and gameplay are simple but I think mastering each class will be a challenge.This is "Roguelike" to a degree but far enough away to not make it grindy, repetitive and boring after 20 games. I never expected this to become one the games I regard with this much respect.So grab it! *insert subliminal buy now message* You won't regret spending a penny.Thanks for reading and thanks for a cool game Mr Wolf!

content:
Posted: July 30, 2016
												The game's great and very, very unique, but there's some serious UI / HUD issues that need addressing. The game's super cluttered with a lot of unnecessary junk and the menus are so hard to follow. There are definitely ways to make this game look more charming and polished while still keeping that old-school 8-bit feel that they're going for. It makes it way, way, WAY too hard for new players to follow and is actually really off-putting. I had a lot of fun with playing the game, but the whole time I just couldn't overlook those two things due to just how annoying they were. Move the life and energy bars to the top corner, give them nice little borders, get rid of a lot of the unnecessary information like.. "Made it to x place!" and instead, just have a little notification pop up above your character when you're in game to say "You've reached x place!". There's a lot of junk that can be moved around or removed to open up the game and make it look nicer. The fact that there's a watermark in the top corner for the music creator is just absurd. Put that crap in the menu, NOT in game. Also, give the same treatment to the menus. Clean them up and make things easier to understand for new players. Once that's done, the game will be great.

												This is an amazing game. But you have to becarful about hitting the buttons twice or not. I made a few mistakes.  The price should be a bit higher but it's ok. The game is really great. number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 14, 2014
												I have played a decent amount of this game, and I think it is time to write a review. One Way Heroics may not seem much as it is an RPG game, but once you get into it, you will fall in love with it. The first thing you may notice of the game is the music. The music practically sets it apart from other RPG or any other games in general. The music is the emotion of the game. The story is pretty interesting too, and the whole time you have to run away from the looming darkness. That is where the name comes from, since you can only go in one way or direction. The last thing I have to say about this amazing game is: The difficulty. This game is not easy at all, you will die many times. Sure, you may rage quit, but this game will draw you back. It is different everytime you play it. To sum all things up, get the game. The money is worth it, and you will enjoy playing it.

												I really didn't expect much going into this game - it was cheap, and I didn't even attempt to play it for a few months after buying it. The controller support is a great touch.  There are quite a few levels of difficulty though I haven't experienced any of the more advanced stuff myself yet.  If you're looking for a game that's worth a few bucks, this is a nice addition to your library.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 1, 2014
												The game is exactly what it says on the tin, it's a procedurally generated RPG-roguelike where you can go where you want, pick special challenges, unlock classes to play with and suck less with each time, if the RNG approves of it by giving you nice (or not-so-nice) things.What makes it excellent compared to most other roguelikes is the actual J-RPG feel, quick pace, and variety of challenges you face as you level onwards. I can't think of another game where I can be a swordsman that beats the final boss with just overly buffed plate armour.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 4
												This is a highly addicting game for something so simple.You simply keep going to the right and kill anything on the way there.While you do so, you level up, try not to starve, try not to get killed by the giant massive cloud of darkness which is the reason why you're going right and even recruit possible allies as you venture forth.Even ignoring the simple gameplay, the hidden story this game tells is quite elusive and you'll find yourself struggling to learn what's going on.One moment you just want to kill the Demon Lord.Then you find out  The Demon Lord's a girl and is the sister of the king who sent you on this quest.	Then you manage to  Kill the Darkness that's trying to swallow the entire Earth. Oh, it's also a GIANT DRAGON	 which is generic, but at the same time, it's pretty interesting.But wait, if you buy the DLC, you get to  Fight and kill god	This is just the basic mainstream story, because there's a plethora of characters with their own little story, ranging from Dosey to you simply trying to be a tourist.In the end, I highly recommend this game, especially if you're the type of person to want to hoard legendary holy items, which I did.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 26, 2015
												The best classical final fantasy game that had never been created by square enix.Can get repetitive, but not bad if you are up for a challenge. Yes, it gets repetitive. The roguelike curtain the game hides itself behind is a huge illusion here, don't be fooled by it. Because you do the exact same things in every run, regardless of how different the map is. Even the direction you advance is the same. Definitely don't expect a life-changing, groundbreaking RPG experience neither. But still can be an alternative to any other time-waster game.Energy concept had gave a nice survival feeling to the game.I really don't like the minimap though, it's so hard to distinguish if there's a mountain or a road there, I hope they improve the quality of the minimap in the future.When you are able to beat the endgame boss and unlock new things, it's damn satisfying though!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 29, 2014
												One Way is a multiplayer RTS, it kind of reminds me like Starcraft II, but before the big update. In this game you play as a small, low quality character with low stats, and get better by killing things, the aim is to get strong enough to take the enemies base before he takes yours. In the campaign mode you're tasked to destroy the Government by progressively building up your rep through street racing, and (Spoilers) taking the crown off of the president when you long distance race for pinks.All in all I really enjoyed playing this game, and I would recommend it to my friends, I will update this when I have tried the Co-op mode :D

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 10, 2014
												The first thing that I noticed about this game was that it reminds me of the very first Final Fantasy, both in terms of looks and sound. Although, it plays nothing like it. Simply put, you travel in one direction (east) to avoid being consumed by the darkness that chases you. Meanwhile, you are fighting monsters and collecting treasure and visiting every little settlement along the way. You will die often, but that is kind of the point. You collect points at the end of your adventure so that you can upgrade your character. Thats about it. I paid about $0.30 for this game during a major sale, and I think it was a good deal. But I don't see myself playing this game very long. About an hour was enough for me. Then again, I have spent more money on steam trading cards than I did on this game, so no complaints here.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 1, 2014
												A buy at 2.99.This game is easy to learn, hard to master. It rewards perserverence.I would call on the developer to continue to market their game and to improve it, XBOX 360 wireless controls were a little iffy, especially considering that the sprites are small on the screen.Finally, at first glance this is a RPGMaker cloneware, but there is something existential about the ever aproaching darkness that gives the game a deeper meaning, while it remains entertaining. Dare we call it art?A great pick up for a weekend (I bought a pineapple more expensive than this game, and while it was a good pine apple, the game will be  with me longer...) cheap enough to be a good gift as well.

number of helpful: 7 of 14 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 28, 2014
												I got this game on a sale, long time ago, for a dumb and extremely low price, something like half an euro, or even less. To tell you the truth, for such a price, I was expecting something horrible, dreadful, like an 8-bit Ride to Hell. Did I got surprised? Yeah! Buuuuuuut as usual, let me explain the BAD things the game has first, so we can take them out of the way:The game is kind of short. Of course, for such a price, you can understand it, so it's not that big of a deal. Besides, this is a Rogue-like game, and rogue-like games are usually short, but change in every playthrough, this is no different from the standard on that regard.The other thing that I did not like at all, is the lack of multiplayer. This game had such extreme potential for a Coop experience, but instead you can play the same randomly generated world at the same time as one of your friends, to see who goes further...INSTEAD OF PLAYING TOGETHER, AND HAVING FUN! I was indeed dissapointed by that, by looking at the captures of some friends that got the game, and by looking at the pictures and videos of the Steam-Store, I was expecting to play at least with one friend in a journey to save the world by punching demons on their d#cks.  You know, the usual. Now, let's talk about the GOOD stuff, pretty much everything else. As I said, it's a Rogue-Like. At the start of the playthrough you select the kind of character you desire to control, and special skills for you: You want to be fast? You want to be strong? You want to use magic? You want to start with a companion? You want to start with insane amoutns of gold? It's your choice, and it's indeed well made. I really did enjoy starting in different ways, and testing different strategies.The game pretty much goes like this: The world is being taken out by some sort of "Dark Sonic Boom" (Damn Obama, he stole that from Guille!), and ANYTHING NEAR THE LEFT SIDE OF THE SCREEN IS F#CKED. Your goal is to travel to the right, getting stronger, surviving the wilds, getting better gear, meeting other people, saving lives, and if you get far enough, saving the world. It might sound simple enough, but the game mechanics make this journey, a journey to remember: First of all, you have to eat, or your character will get tired. Sounds easy enough? Well, there's not that many free food out there, so you have to make sure to visit any Inn or Town and get supplies before they got suck up into Oblivion (I bet that portal leads to Obama's #sshole, NOW THAT'S ONE SICK WAY TO END UP DEAD). Not only that, but your equipment won't last forever. Your stuff has limited use, for example, 100 uses on a sword. Once you swing it for the 100th time, the thing breaks, and it's lost forever. There are ways to repair it and make it last longer, but you should make sure to AT LEAST CARRY 1 BACKUP WEAPON. Infact, I always try to carry at least 3 weapons on myself. And armor? HAH, THOSE THINGS BREAK TOO, SHIELDS INCLUDED! You're far pass f#cked on these lands, specially later on when enemies start to get dangerous!For a cheap game, there's a lot of fun to be had in this game, and I do recommend it. The game is worth 3€ WITHOUT sales, and that's already cheap enough, on sales it usually lowers to 1€ or so. It's up to you to buy it or not, but I do recommend that you give it a try.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 4, 2014
												This game is brutal no matter what difficulty you pick, in best possible way as a rogue-like. It has a VERY surprising amount of depth for a game that is by default played on a resolution of about a smart phone (what you see in the screenshots is what you get, and full-screening it does not help its prettiness!). Graphics-wise, it's incredibly indie -- see the character "portraits" in the bottom left corner that seem to be sketches made a bored developer, especially Swordmaster Class C for a laugh.If you get this game, it's for its gameplay, which does one thing, but does it really, really well. The turn-based gameplay with a constant timer and emphasis on movement will make it incredibly addicting for old-time Rogue-like players, as experience points (read: monsters to farm) and treasure may be within arm's reach but inaccessible due to the choices you have to make. The item appraisal system makes every item a mystery and makes even a new starting sword drop a desired reward, as durability constantly counts down with few ways to repair items and replenish supplies. Even when you're on top of the world, you'll feel pressured and challenged by item weights and inventory limits, decreasing energy and stamina, and other factors to encourage you to weigh risk and reward ("how long should I wear this Training Bracelet, which cripples my stats for more experience?") to get ready for the next area.The "hidden" parts of the game are by far the most enticing. You simply have to go out and find out for yourself how to get access to things like Party Members, Force powers (spells), the Dark Brotherhood, Hidden Elf Villages, Goddess Statues, and Key of Seals and their associated doors. After each death or victory, the progression system encourages trial and error, mixing and matching unlockable classes and perks with rotating featured Dimensions and allowing players to access the Dimensional Vault to carry over a limited number of items. The game is well-supported outside of a playthrough with a replay system, a hall of fame for each dimension and for your overall profile, and, of course, the different daily Dimensions featured. It does not hold your hand after kicking you out of the castle with a fairy of questionable use, explaining only the most basic and necessary mechanics until you recruit party members: you have to go out and discover it for yourself, since at a base level the game is so simple! Even the limited story and simple humor is fun to discover, especially as more party-member-specific endings are unlocked.One of the best games on Steam under $5, and amongst my favorite Rogue-likes; highly, highly recommend.

												Looking at the game is one thing, but actually playing it is another.I love turn based RPGs, and dungeon crawler type games with Rougelike elements to it, loved playing the Mystery Dungeon: Shiren the Wanderer games, Torneko - The Last Hope - World of Dragon Warrior, Izuna: Legend of the Unemployed Ninja 1 & 2, and the Pokémon Mystery Dungeon games, after playing this game it gives me some of that satisfaction and a feeling of nostalgia, the gameplay is great, the music is beautifully set, the menu is well done especially being able to customize your hero player before you set off on your random generated adventure, you only start off with 2 classes to play with, after each playthrough by completing it or dying through you'll get points to unlock other perks and classes to help you strategize for your next playthrough  since there's also difficulties to choose from as well, oh did i forget to mention that the far left side of the map is trying to consume you and the whole world, yeah this game is great. :D

number of helpful: 8 of 17 people (47%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 28, 2014
												A game that puts you to the test in every press of time and action.  This game puts you think not only about stock, but the matter of stats in what you have. Tthe game provides a good random world generation and fun little remarks along the way with each playthrough. However at the end, they provide advice, help, tips, and tricks that will help you in your next playthrough. The points you obtain after each playthrough are put to the end game to help you decide if you want to unlock a class, perk, or add items to a dimensional vault. With that said, the game provides entertainment. I give it a 5 out of 5 in my opinion for keeping it good paced, makes me go back for more. If to put it accurately on scale, It would be nice if would be a 4.8 out of 5 because of some things such as the matter of certain monsters. Nonetheless even if it is a "walk in the park" mode, each playthrough in each world provides an experience unique. I found it quite entertaining and enthralling. However at points can get mad because of the fact of certain options, do yo wanna save now and lose 5 levels. I think not, however as you play more and more throughout you get more info around the world and develop more points that add up. Rack them all up and bonuses appear on skills and perks. Eventually you will obtain a nice amount and make your experience turn. I hate to admit it but dying in this game sort of helps you out.  Reminds me of other games and concepts. Nonetheless great game  I recommend for those interested in a fun highly replayable and growing game. It's something that is quite indulging. I took the time going through the npcs, areas, while running for my life against that horde. Yet I feel bad everytime I think about some of them. Nonetheless as some say, you realize what really matters or what you have to do when it is about to be gone in your life. Still this game adds quite the element on point of classes. They give you each specifics with bonuses and will help you understand how you want to play if you choose this. There are as many worlds you can make and use as long as you keep trying. Been playing at odds and ends with it in my first world since I got it. I got highly addicted.

content:
Posted: February 27, 2015
												One way heroics is a great rogue-like turn-based quasi-tactical rpg. It's hard to label this game as any one specific catagory, but it's ideal is apparent.This game is all about strategy, and uses a grid-based platform.If you are a fan of fire emblem style gameplay, you may like this game.The second element is more of a rough and tumble type of turn-based rogue-like battle system.First you choose your action, then all other actions occur after your action, then time moves foreward and stops when it comes back to your turn. It's a very simple, yet complex system as there are a multitude of effects to change the style that you play. (examples: combos, criticals, ranged, meditation, throwables, etc etc)Another huge aspect, which I believe carries this game to a better aspect, is it's music.While the volume isn't always properly adjusted for some of the areas, the music is still great for every single area/theme in the game.also I swear I heard guile's theme...In addition to to having great music, the effort they put into the smaller details in the game, such as character interaction and ending sequences, goes to show how much they actually cared for the game. This is something more developers need to do.I would give this game a solid 9/10.-1 point for including hippy tree huggers.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 10, 2015
												Overall    :   7.5The game overall is very simple, straight forward, yet incredibly complex all at once.  This game uses the "Inheritance" system, where as you level though the game, you will gain attributes/abilities from one save to the next.  Because of this, every playthrough is new, and every time you make a character, you can choose to continue with the gear you had (or have) or start fresh.  If you are a fan of rogue likes, you should give this a try.Graphics   :   7The rogue style game really has nothing that 'stands out'.  Simply put though, if you play rogue games for graphics, you are probably looking in the wrong genre.Sound       :  9The music and sound effects for the game are astounding.  They really add to the look and feel of the game as you are moving through the world.Storyline    :  6I can't really comment too much on the storyline, as I keep dieing before I get to a boss fight, but the general theory of running away from a mist that is chasing you that destroys all feels very similar to FTL, but with a very awesome roguelike style.  Presentation:  6The games graphics and menus work well, are very easy to use.  The only reason I can not give this an 8 is because while there is localization for controllers, the UI does not reflect that you have a controller plugged in and are using it.  Often when I first started playing I had to push the buttons to figure out what did what.  This cost some turns and a few deaths (although kind of funny).Replayability:  10Every playthough gets better and better, this game is incredibily addictive and has an extreme level of enjoyment with each playthroughContent         :  7There are adequate skills/classes/weapons and status to engate a truely unique rogue like expreience.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 10, 2015
												Overall    :   7.5The game overall is very simple, straight forward, yet incredibly complex all at once.  This game uses the "Inheritance" system, where as you level though the game, you will gain attributes/abilities from one save to the next.  Because of this, every playthrough is new, and every time you make a character, you can choose to continue with the gear you had (or have) or start fresh.  If you are a fan of rogue likes, you should give this a try.Graphics   :   7The rogue style game really has nothing that 'stands out'.  Simply put though, if you play rogue games for graphics, you are probably looking in the wrong genre.Sound       :  9The music and sound effects for the game are astounding.  They really add to the look and feel of the game as you are moving through the world.Storyline    :  6I can't really comment too much on the storyline, as I keep dieing before I get to a boss fight, but the general theory of running away from a mist that is chasing you that destroys all feels very similar to FTL, but with a very awesome roguelike style.  Presentation:  6The games graphics and menus work well, are very easy to use.  The only reason I can not give this an 8 is because while there is localization for controllers, the UI does not reflect that you have a controller plugged in and are using it.  Often when I first started playing I had to push the buttons to figure out what did what.  This cost some turns and a few deaths (although kind of funny).Replayability:  10Every playthough gets better and better, this game is incredibily addictive and has an extreme level of enjoyment with each playthroughContent         :  7There are adequate skills/classes/weapons and status to engate a truely unique rogue like expreience.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 8, 2015
												This is an amazing roguelike game. Just like any other, YOU WILL DIE the first few times you try. However, you will eventually get the hang of it, and be able to survive just about any situation. For example: I recently got the plus version, and in it they added a couple new biomes and new items. One new biome is an ocean area, where there is a very large area of water. Water takes 5 times as long to navigate as dry land, and this is a major issue with the darkness chasing you. What made the area worse is that the Demon Lord (powerful boss) spawned for me right after I found the ocean. I fought for a while, before I realized I was screwed if I kept fighting. I was trapped between a very powerful enemy and an ocean that would cause my death. Luckily, I found an item that proved highly useful. Its called Magic Bridge. It forms a bridge that extends to 15 tiles in front of you. I used it over the ocean, and managed to run away for a little while, and heal. However, the bridge wasnt long enough to make it all the way over. So I was trapped once again. However, through strategic item, skill, and using my followers as bodyguards, I was able to get him down to about 10% hp. However, I couldnt survive another hit. I thought to myself "How can I possibly survive?" I was skimming my skills, and I noticed I had one more awakening left. Awakening is a skill that freezes time for 3 turns. However, you can only use it 5 times a playthrough. I used it. And on the last turn of the awakening, I managed to finish him off. It was the single most intense moment of my One Way Heroics life.I highly advise that you get this game, and the Plus version. Easily worth the money. And with time, Im sure you too will overcome impossible odds!

content:
Posted: June 21, 2015
												A rouge-like/rpg hwhere you must keep moving to avoid the darkness (AKA the dark void of death).You first begin the game with the hero (you) selecting a class and a variety of perks to aid you on your quest. You can enter a randomly generated world or scenarios that change in real time. Depending on what mode you choose, the dark lord will appear at a certain time during your playthrough. You must defeat him to beat the game but this is no easy feat without proper equipment or items. Of course, there are dungeons and towns but you have to plan how to get in and out safely throughly without being eaten alive by the void. If you die on a playthrough, you can store items you had in the dimensional vault and use them on the next playthrough. You also accumulate hero points after each playthrough in which you can spend these points on extra vault space or hidden perks or classes for your next run. The amont of points you get depends on how well you did on your last playthrough.A nice, time-killing game overall with buckets full of replayability but try not to swim in lava. Can you reach the end of the world?

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 26, 2015
												I love this game, however I *really* wish the flaws werent so blistering.-Your weight limit is abysmal. You can literally start the game, pick up a SINGLE weapon and you're already overencumbered. - Your stat increases per level are completely random. You could literally get nothing but SP upgrades from Level 1 - 15 and you'd be just as weak as when you started. - The Identify System is unfair. Like I said earlier, your weight limit is terrible so, you end up picking up a Sword???, you have no idea what it is... and because the system is so unfair, odds are you wont Identify the weapon. You can't bring it with you because it's too heavy. It's just not fair. And considering Item Shops rarely have Apraisal Scrolls and an Apraiser is Expensive / Sometimes to Hard to Come by.... It's almost wiser to just ignore weapons.- You have no idea how powerful your enemies are. One Bat could be the easiest bat in the game and the next one could possibly 1 shot you. Who knows? It's not consistent. I wish it was. Now, all of these things by themselves are not bad... but put together, it's almost unforgiving how hard the game is.But still...The music is *amazing*.The gameplay is addictingAnd you have a Shared Loot system between games that helps you out.And I'd say it makes up for all that.

												A solid turn base strategy game that caters to players who don't mind honing one of 3 effective ways to fight enemies and wants to complete endurance challenges. Highly encourage getting the game for those who like to compete with other players with the use of the Seed Generation system.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												If you like roguelike games, this one is a must buy in my opinion. The system is kept rather simple, and games necessarily have a relatively short duration even if you win them by killing the demon lord at the end. (I managed to win on my 3rd try, which took about an hour.)Multiple playthroughs are worthwhile because there are various classes and perks to be unlocked. Additionally you have a "dimensional vault" that you can use to store up items from your previous attempt to use in your next one. So while your character isnt all that persistent, your profile is.I bought the game on sale for $1, and it was one of the best $1 purchases I've made here.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 4, 2015
												This is the story of a Hunter who threw away his puny bow and picked up a super-manly Sharp Holy Axe Elizabeth+6. Because this item was guaranteed to deal critical damage when it hit the target, this Hunter managed to kill every enemy that came his way in one hit. Even golems and polar bears. As a result his level grew very rapidly. Soon he had a level above 30, even, and enough Strength to where he could carry several battleaxes and greatswords with ease. But it all went to his head. For his head, much like every other part of his body except for his massive beefcake arms, was puny and weak. So it was, when he got cocky and decided to break into the hold of the Dark Brotherhood (not THAT Dark Brotherhood), that he soon realized he could only kill one of them, before all the other members inside would shank him from all sides and kill him instantly. And so they did.That is the story of my... I wanna say my twelfth time playing through the game. I lost count, honestly. This game is wicked addictive. It's a really good buy if you're into rogue-likes and your computer is getting on in years or is otherwise not that strong. I play it on a laptop with Intel HD 3000 graphics and it runs 60fps solid at the highest detail settings.I want the expansion pack though... (sniff)
