number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2014
												Like FTL, but as a medieval RPG.This game has a deceptive level of depth to it, especially for such a cheap game. What makes this roguelike different from most other roguelikes and yet similiar to FTL, is that there is an advancing wave of darkness that forces the screen to scroll to the right. If you fall into the darkness? You die, and thus you need to keep moving to the right to survive, hence the name of the game. You would think that something like that would leave very little room for story, and in a way you are correct. But there is actually a bit more plot than it appears on first glance and you will need multiple playthroughs to fully understand what is going on. The gameplay is mostly based around exploring, killing enemies and finding items while staying ahead of the scrolling wave. You need to find items to recover your energy, health and stamina, while also looking for weapons, armor, and enchantments. During this time the Demon Lord will occasionally pop in to try to kill you, and you either have to run from him, using whatever status effect items you have to slow him down, or finish him then and there. This sounds very simple on paper, but in practice it's actually a quite expansive resource and time management game, and you often need to plan your movements carefully to avoid getting killed by the scrolling darkness.There are also a number of interesting NPCs, but sadly they very rarely appear. Each one has their own backstory, personaliy quirks, and even an associated ending. To mix things up even more, there is a random prefix system that can sometimes spawn either an enemy or an NPC with a stat changing prefix such as "stiff-necked", with some of them even changing the character's dialog, often in hilarious ways.Like most roguelikes this game has a lot of replay value, but here it's even more enforced by the fact that you can "vault" items at the end of a playthrough so you can get them at the start of another playthrough. Combined with the various classes, starting perks, and random world generation, you will likely end up with quite a bit of variety right at the start of your various runs through the game.There is even a limited online play component, in that you can start on a world where other players have played and see their ghosts where they have died. At the end of a run you will also see leaderboards listed all the other players who have played on that world.Unfortunately this game isn't perfect, which is to be expected with it's nearly non-existant price. The stats aren't very balanced, with some like intelligence being less useful than the others, and charm in particular is almost useless given that it's mainly used for recruiting companions, who, as said before are extremely rare. I also noticed that bows seem a bit underpowered since they can't combo like melee weapons and often you can just throw things for similiar damage. Hopefully the upcoming expansion polishes the game up a bit, but even with the few issues this game has, it's worth far more than it's listed price at the moment.

content:
Posted: February 9
												This is the game that made me realize how great roguelikes can be. I love this game, even though I probably will never beat it. The core premise of this game is what got me to buy it, and all the stuff i could unlock just by playing the game kept me coming back for more. New classes, more health, better stats, etc. I love it! Then there's the fact that there are nearly infinite worlds to explore and you can replay the ones you like and you have a vault where you can store items for subsequent playthroughs-allowing you to keep things you don't want to risk losing. There's so much more to this game than I could fit into a few paragraphs. It's something you'd have to play for yourself and see. If you like JRPGs, replayability, and roguelikes, you almost certainly will like this game.

content:
Posted: May 13, 2015
												It's an alright indie rogue-like game but there isn't much to it. Pretty much just try to see how far you can get in a certain amount of steps or something... Idk the game is kind of vague on how it works. It took me 4 hours to beat the Demon Lord the first time and I didn't have the motivation to try to get any further. Doing well rewards you with more usable characters and you can use chests to store items you might want on your next character walk. SO basically with storing your items you're saying screw it to this play-thru and the next one will be better or something.The game seemed kind of counter-productive as you have to make very fine decisions on whether or not to even fight monsters as they slow you down or deal alot of damage. You pretty much have to get lucky enough to get some good items and also fight enough enemies, but not too much, to be able to fight the Demon Lord at the end with high enough stats to survive. If I were to give this game a rating I would have to say something around 6/10.  It's an alright adventure game but just seems like I'm making no progress while I play. Also there is not a whole lot of content but it's only like $3.50 so it's forgivable.

content:
Posted: April 23, 2014
												One Way Heroics is like an old Ultima game condensed into a Roguelike. The various classes and goals make the game very replayable, and I think this is a really interesting model for RPGs to overcome the monotony and over-simplification of Final Fantasy style games. The only thing I would say is, I wish they'd combine the great maps and interesting gameplay with some kind of story and/or more unlockables or goals. To me, this game is a model of the potential unlocked by games like League of Legends or Binding of Isaac, where there is always a reason to try your best during the game, and to be satisfied with losing. The only thing designers need to do is combine this perpetual effort by its players with some kind of story that works despite the seeming interchangability of the maps. Recommend this game to a RPG roguelike fans who are slightly on the hardcore side.

number of helpful: 14 of 31 people (45%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 1, 2014
												UPDATE:  The game works (that is, will not crash to your desktop) if you turn off the "online features" option.  I have no idea what the online features are supposed to allow you to do, but they apparently crash the game, so I definitely recommend turning them off until the game is patched.Even without the online features, the game itself is a lot of fun, from the limited time I have played it so far.  You will die a lot, but it's never too frustrating.  It reminds me a bit of a turn-based Rogue Legacy in that you get to keep a set of the old equipment you have found from run to run.  Success in earlier runs makes more success in later runs easier (possible).  Now that I can actually run the game without it crashing, I'm happy to recommend it -- it's certainly a lot of fun for the price.--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------OLD REVIEW:  This game looks like it could be fun, but the Steam version isn't stable.  I've launched the game twice, created characters, ventured out, and within five minutes both times, the game has crashed to the desktop.  I'd wait until the patches come in before buying it.

content:
Posted: November 17, 2015
												Got this on a sale for like 0.3£, and have to say, I love it so far, it's better then I thought it would be. Even for the standard price of 2.99£. get it, it's worth it, small price for a fun game on a bad day and you don't know what to play of those 150 games you have on the list. Gameplay, well you make a character, and at start you have one class, and then you can put in the start perks. As you start, you have to run and get away from the left part of your screen and it only moves whenever you make a move that get's time to go again. As you progress you find items, friends, enemies. You will die, I promise that. But your stats progress wont die, you will then start again and continue with your stats from the start. You can upgrade some dimention box or something and save your items for your next run. Every level you give that box you can store one more item. And when you die, you will get to a screen with some kawaii ughuu fairy gurl that will give you weary helpfull tips of how you could have changed your run to survive longer. Warning, only tutorial you get is, how to walk, turn and talk. No more help then that, rest you have to figure out yourserlf... unless I missed something. You can find save points btw. Like I said it's fun, and worth playing. I had a good time and I thought this game was going to be♥♥♥♥♥♥honestly.

content:
Posted: August 2, 2016
												I realized it's called One Way Heroics for a reason.Anyways, it's a gem that's fairly well for it's price (on sale for me) for 0.77 USD. Combat might not be in depth as it should be, but it serves it purpose of wasting your time of the mist to get you. Combat was really clunkly because of the directional aspect (I got killed by a Spooky Skele because I was a noob and did not know how to change direction). Dialogue with Iris is the most fun part of this game, breaking the 4th wall all the time. When I smashed every button on my computer, she popped up out of nowhere, and questioned me about ignoring her for the last 3 runs I attempted. Perhaps it's better that there is classes at all that, but it's really kinda like Killing Floor 'cept being more niche at their roles.Verdict: It's a timewaster for 1 hour at best, but's it's like a short comedy, not a full game. Don't treat it as one.(still cheaper than a movie ticket, more fun to play.)

number of helpful: 12 of 28 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 17, 2014
												Across all dimensions, the only constant is Darkness! A procedurally generated RPG-roguelike journey across the multiverse!In One Way Heroics, you take on the role of an intrepid adventurer who must travel across the land and face the Demon Lord before a mysterious darkness engulfs everything.Darkness always approaches from the left, and with each movement, attack and action you take, the darkness creeps ever closer. Forced to run right, you'll encounter any number of monsters, allies, thieves and shops on your desperate journey to stop the end of everything.The good news is that you don't just have access to one world. You have access to all of them. Born with the mysterious power to travel to other dimensions, you can choose which dimension you wish to travel to in order to get to the Demon Lord.Dimensions vary based on their name. One might be full of lush forest landscapes full of adorable animals and cunning thieves, while another might be full of corrupted hellscapes infested with demons. You might find likeminded heroes willing to journey with you, or you might meet no one and be forced to venture into the unknown alone.Like a dimension you previously visited? Simply input the name at the Dimensional selection screen before you begin your journey. Want to try your luck with a random dimension? Type any word that pops into your head, and watch as One Way Heroics builds you a world based on the name you chose.Infinite permutations. Infinite worlds. Infinite adventure.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2015
												There are two philosophies in making Roguelikes: The classic Roguelikes like NetHack had dungeons that weren't terribly long with permadeath, but were excessively lethal because the point was that you, the player were the one "leveling up" by learning new techniques for beating the game that you never thought about before you had YASD or hit the oracle; The other usually eschews permadeath to have a more classic RPG sense of character progression through nigh-infinite procedural dungeons.  One Way Heroics goes the ultra-short game route with none of the character progression, but it also manages to be so rules-light that it fails to really give the player any sense that they learned anything.  I "beat" the game on my second try, and it just said, "Yay, now try again!"... WHY? What goal do I have in playing through a 10-minute game I've already beaten to get more loot I don't need to beat it again?It just feels like it gutted the biggest reason I enjoy RPGs - the sense of customization and development of your characters - in favor of nameless forgettable nobodies, and there's nothing in the game that replaces that or gives me any sense of reason why I'd want to play any more than that 10 minutes it takes to see the whole story play out once.

number of helpful: 8 of 21 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 21, 2016
												I bought this because it was labeled as an RPG. I realize this is a rogue like also. In my personal opinion this game feels like it fails both genres.When playing an RPG there needs to be a sense of exploration/story. However, this game really punishes you for exploring. You will come across tons of little enemy houses with treasure in them, but most of the time it is impossible to kill the swarm of enemies inside and unlock a box before the area gets swallowed by the black edge of the screen. Furthermore, the character progression just isn't there. I get that one of the man features of rogue likes is permadeath, but the perks you can buy and upgrade a new character with don't make you feel stronger. You can unlock different classes of hero but they don't feel any different.  The controls suck for the combat style. It's both live action and turn based. You pretty much walk around the map, but when you come across enemies you must take it slow and be very deliberate about facing the right direction before initiating any action, otherwise you swing at air and waste a turn. The controls just felt very clunky and took away from the immersion. I feel like pure turn based combat would have been better.My final verdict is 5/10. This game probably is more enjoyable as a rogue like than an RPG. Only worth purchasing when on sale for 50% off or more.

content:
Posted: March 1, 2014
												After disableing the online features(Thanks whisperling!) the game has not crashed. While playing I noticed the game works a lot like the pokemon mystery dungeon series. At first I didn't think that was good thing as I played those games a lot and assumed I would get nothing out of this game.*predictable twist* The sense of urgency that is thrust apon you gives the game a very unique feel.It stops you from grinding enemies and forces you to stop and make very important desisions, especially considering being a nuetral persons house is more dangerous that fighting a zombie. Even swapping out items takes time and you end up keeping the item just to throw it at a bat.One thing that draws me to the game is what happens when you die. The game is designed to be quite difficult, which I think works great in these kinds of greenlit games, but what works good in this one is the ability to make your next run slightly easier with upgrades without making it too easy.The only downside I have with this game is that when changing to the controller, the button prompts stay as keyboard buttons meaning you have to work out the corresponding button and remember it, often leading in you doing the wrong thing.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2015
												Simply put: I didn't find this game fun. The gameplay mechanics are interesting and I especially like the idea of character progression through new characters, but the content is just... lacking. Going through the game and advancing my character gave me no sense of accomplishment or progression. Nothing immersed me in the world or made me care about the Demon Lord. The interface was frustrating and took away most of the enjoyment I could get out of the rougelike aspect of it. Oh, and the lack of language support in the game itself is frustrating--I decided I wanted to play through in English this time instead of Japanese and changing it via Steam (the only way) wiped all of my data. There's no real excuse to not have proper language support these days... except that I'm pretty sure this game was made with RPG Maker, which has absolutely no localization support.Anyway, despite the low price I'd recommend giving this game a pass.

content:
Posted: September 14, 2015
												Didn't like it. While it does feature proper randomization and varied starting options, I can't say I find it an enjoyable roguelike. First of all, interface is bad, no mouse support, and various dialogues during each run start / end repeat every time without ability to skip them. Also, it was obviously designed for Japanese language, the information is crammed in too tightly, and those dialogues I mentioned are like something out of a jRPG/visual novel but, you know, this is a roguelike with many retries necesseary to achieve something, so you'll see those pop up every now and then, forcing you to rapidly skim trough same lines every time!Next, it's... I can't really say it has that much tactical depth. I mean, there are special abilities which are not very convinient to use due to interface, some of them cost stats, some can be used just few times, but due to the price you pay to use them they are only handy in extreme situations. Same with items, they run out of durability and break, so you have to spare better ones, but even then there's no depth beyond "know when it's right time to use this".Also, can't say I enjoyed either visuals or audio. Guess I'm just not weaboo enough to enjoy Japanese style. Although if you are into this sort of thing, you should probably enjoy it.Finally while it has some nice simple ideas, the balance is pretty♥♥♥♥♥♥ Like charisma is near-useless except for getting extremely rare companions, meanwhile other stats are essential for survival. While unfairness is a common thing in random roguelikes, having one of the essential stats useless outside of daily events and extremely rare occurences is just plain wrong.All in all, this might be a pretty good simple timekiller for a weaboo, you might even enjoy the extra challenges the game offers, but for anyone not used to Japanese game design practices and aesthetics this might prove rather dull.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2015
												There is a TL:DRIf you grab this game for less than $1 then it is very much worth it. I actually REALLY like the game and the simplicity of combat but boy oh howdy is it a very shallow experience. Aside from tiny modifiers and higher difficulties this is a very easy game to beat once you figure out how not to die to the moving wall of darkness.There are 2 types of rogue like games. The first type you actually progress your character accross playthroughs (Dead Rising, Rogue Legacy) where you get your sense of accomplishment despite not beating the game.The other type consists of losing literally everything stat and possession and see if you roll the dice better this time around. Thats much harder to remain satisfying since from a stat angle you can't tell who has 80 hours of play time and who has 5 hours. So why invest the additional 75 hours?This game is the latter, sure certain games can pull it off like Faster then Light because you unlock ways that alter the game in a dramatic way that getting those unlocks feels worth it even if you lose. This game has a few different classes but they control and play almost identically and their bonuses would only be noticed if this game was in the former catagory. It wouldn't be hard either, you remove weapon degredation (since you can save items between playthroughs) and allow perminent base stat increases using the levels you gain in playthrough as currency. Make this playthrough harder so that future ones will be easier sort of deal, they already have something like that but it only applies to the current playthroughTL:DR this game is very much worth if you're buying it for literal cents on the dollar. It goes on sale frequently

content:
Posted: July 23, 2015
												I bought this one during the Summer Monster Sale for very little money, but it also brought me very little enjoyment.The game feels really, really basic. You move towards the right on a wide plain/desert/forest (terrains have different effects), fight some monsters, explore some dungeons (really just rooms with a few monsters and an item chest in them).The terrain is generated procedurally, so each run is a little different.Combat is really simple. You either attack with your weapon or use abilities.There are little tactical moves beyond moving so that you get the first attack, or running away from stronger monsters.After a certain distance travelled, the boss appears.In case you die, you get a little lecture (like "you should use your time travel skill in dire situations") and then get some points with which you can unlock other characters and perks.You can also put some of your items in a dimensional stash, to have them present in your next run.I can honestly not understand the massive praise this game receives, maybe I just did not "get" it.So I have no hard feelings downvoting it, despite its very low price.

Product received for free
												I don't understand how this game gets such huge amounts of praise, i feel like the game concept was good but executed in such a bad way, Going into it i already cringed at the fact that it had Anime in it (Don't hold this point against the game, this is just my personal preference) After making my hero I played the game and was killed off instantly when trying to visit a home, you only get very small time windows to visit shops, save or raid a dungeon, which is a bit challenging and kills off my need for exploration and monster fighting, speaking of monster fighting lets talk about how lack-luster it is, you'll come across almost no enemies in the beginning but once you reach a further area you get overwhelmed and killed instantly, healing items can almost never save you and shops sell very little healing items at a time, and seeing as you have too get in and get out as fast as possible when it comes to the shops, it's extremely hard to stay alive.  there was almost no story in the mode i chose, other than the fact that we're running from darkness to get to a demon to defeat him, The game mostly never explains most things, like identifying items. i find this game really hard to wrap my head around the full concept of the game, thank god i didn't pay for this and got it as a gift.

												It's an interesting idea, but little more than that.One Way Heroics is a typical roguelike, that (thankfully) lets you gain in power on restart based partially on what you've done in  previous games.However, it's always-move-right-or-you-die nature doesn't let you really enjoy an area; it makes encounters overly tough; and, worst of all, it actively discourages exploration in a a genre, and most importanntly, IN A GAME, that rewards exploration.While some may find fun in it, it's overwhelmingly a game based in randomness, and I personally don't like games that prioritize randomness over skill.

content:
Posted: August 25, 2015
												I strive to look for good RPG Maker style games, but I can never find any. I think that everything in this game is great, however with every seemingly good game, there is a gimmick. I dont know if anyone will pay attention to this review but you may want to. Everything you do in this game causes the screen to move to the right. Everything. Talking to someone repeatedly will move the screen, and if you go off screen at all, game over. So if you're really far and die, well there goes everything. I was really excited when I bought this game. The random worlds feature lured me in and I was so happy to finally play, then when I did, I was so disappointed. It's not the game, or the price, or anything else. It's just that the screen keeps moving right, and it will kill you. Oh, and it's not a glitch, it's a main feature of the game. Just a heads up to anyone thinking of buying it.*Edit:*I know this is the main feature of the game and I'll admit I shouldn't have acted so surprised about it, however I still have to say that that feature drives me off. Personal preference I guess. Games cool but the screen going to the right is just too bothersome.~

												I decided to write an in depth negative review beyond "Its♥♥♥♥♥♥quot; that the other negative reviews seems to boil down to.Whenever I start a game and its by default in such a small screen that you cant really see anything, I get a bad feeling. Turns out you can pick between three settings in a windowed mode. So small you cant see, Slightly bigger you cant see, and about the size of a tablet screen.  There are no more visual options to speak of.There is no tutorial so its going to take a second to figure out what you are supposed to be doing. The mechanics aren't very deep but it takes a while to get used to the awkward controls that will have you moving with the arrow keys, attacking with the enter key, and using the menu with the escape key.You can unlock new heros and new perks as well as carry over a few items from playthoughs. Your progress resets everytime though so its a very samey feeling every time. It really has the JRPG grinding thing going on. There isnt much else to it. The story is the basic of basic stories, there arent many other characters, and the new items are kind of boring minor stat increases.As a rogue like game it fails because it much to grindy to be any fun and as an rpg it fails because other than having your hero level up, it is missing any other rpg elements. All in all its a novel idea but is plauged by some strange design choices and a horrible options menu.

content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
												The music is ear-bleedingly bad and manages to sound repetitive without actually being repetitive.  Why would the "artist" put their name on this? The sounds in general are terribad.  It is trying to pay homage to the 8 bit games of NES and the like, but it manages to actually be the same quality, only more shrill.  Paying homage does not mean trying to literally copy the original, and then amp up the worst aspects.There are 3 available resolutions.  None are wide screen.  One is so small that my phone actually has a larger screen.  Terrible.The resolution in general is very poor.  Again, paying homage does not mean turning the negative aspects of something up to 11.  There are numerous interface issues.  EG, why doesn't moving into an enemy attack them?  Overall, I cannot recommend this.  It's an interesting idea done poorly.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2014
												I thought this game was going to be a procedural generate game with elements similer to final fantasy or phtasy star. The point is a dark wave from the right kills everything and u have to stay ahead of it fighting monsters and collecting loot. It sounded too good to be true which it was. The dark wave chases you down a procedurally generated corridor where the top and the bottom end very soon which gives you a complete lack of a world of any kind. The game does not allow you to feel like to grow like an rpg should. This game is more like a poor imitation of old archade games that need a quater to play. I understand that it is trying new things and thats cool but it somehow lacks almost all the things that make and old fashion 2D rpg game so special. I give it an overall 3/10.

												Edit: I'm changing this to a 5/10 because I didn't realize the game crash was related to server issues. I still have gripes (comments below) but if those get fixed, I'll be happy to edit my review again. The game is simple enough but the learning curve for newbies is pretty steep. (Preview review below)I don't write reviews often - like, hardly at all - but this game randomly crashes. Normally I'd suck it up but in a game where literally everything is randomly generated and you get points taken away from your complete game if you save (essentially forcing a perfectionist to never save in a run-through, which you can clear in 15-20 minutes tops) this is a huge problem. 0/10 would not buy, even for the 2 bucks and change I spent on it. I'd love a refund.

												One Way Heroics is a nice semi-Rougelike RPG where you have to constantly move to the right to out run the Darkness that's eating up the world. For the really low price, there's tons of content, such as different classes and skills to help you with each attempt to beat it. There's multiple endings to go for and companions to get along the way. For the really low price, I recommend it for those who really enjoy games like Mystery Dungeon or RPGs in general.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
												If you like JPRGs and Roguelike you'll love this. The crux of the game is the sidescrolling mechanic.  DARKNESS is on the left side of the screen and you have to keep moving right. Touch the left and it's game over. However, getting game over is not the end...OWH lets you pick a few items to carry on your next run via a Dimensional Vault. This means you can get stronger on subsequent runs. You put items in that box after your run is over and when you start a new game you can pull them out of the Dimensional Box and power up your character. Gameplay: 9/10Sometimes you will get annoyed with how things turn out, but as with many roguelikes, the next run is usually better than the previous. There is also plenty of things to unlock such as more classes and stat perks can be chosen to further customize your character. There are save points like a traditional JRPG, if you find a town you can save your progress. If you just can't let go of that one run, then just fire up the previous save.Graphics: 8/10Classic 16-bit RPG style. One caveat: The game will go fullscreen mode, but there is no way to change the resolution. Compared to the rest of the game, this is a minor gripe.Soundtrack: 8/10 Great! At times I was reminded of greats like Chrono Trigger. It's not that good, but its a very solid soundtrack. Fits the adventuring motif perfectly.Replayability: 10/10This game is an absolute steal on sale for $0.87 on Summer Sale. BUY IT.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
												The world is ending, what do you do? Go out and kick the crap out of a demon lord. But in all seriousness this is a very good game. At its core it's a JRPG but has roguelike mechanics. You start off with 2 classes and a few minor perks(which are optional) and you'll unlock more as you meet certain requirements. Each class can equip basically any type of equipment(which has durability), with each class having their own unique passive ability. For example the hunter has longer range with bows or the knight being able to defend against more attacks. As you travel through the world fighting monsters and visiting towns you'll probably notice the big wall of death to your left. That's pretty much what your trying to stop. Pushing forward while leveling and gearing up seems to be your only option. Eventually you'll make it to the demon lord(hopefully powerful enough to stop him). Died to him, the wilderness, nature, and/or the big wall of looming death? No problem. There's a carry over feature. Every playthrough allows you the chance to purchase perks and transfer items with your hero points(how much you gain depends on your performance). All in all it's a solid game(especially considering the price(even more so during the summer sale)).

Like the developer actually cares! *gasp*Not to mention it seems like theres a bit of things you can unlock to keep the game engaging and its seemingly randomly generated so theres that. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
												For anyone who's a fan of roguelikes, this game is right up your alley. It's actually got a bit of personality above and beyond many roguelikes that are out there, and the pixel graphics really add charm, if they're your style.Progression is quick, and every death seems to lead to either a new bit of knowledge, or extra strength for the next run. It also provides a fine amount of replay, incorporating daily realms and other online elements, so if you're looking for another run on a new class, or a new level of challenge, the game is constantly giving you new stuff to contend with.For whatever reason, the game won't let me play in fullscreen, despite my best efforts to do so, but that's really just a tiny complaint. Same thing for the keyboard-only controls, which thankfully are very simple and intuitive.  All in all, this game provides a remarkable amount of content for under five bucks, and even if it was ten, I'd heartily recommend it to roguelike fans.Final rating: 8/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												This game is AMAZING!I love the music, I love the gameplay, I love the story and characters.But will you love this game?First of all, it's turn-based. Good to think over in critical situations.For these situations there is also a power that gives you the ability to make 5 moves without having fear the darkness swallows you/enemies are beating you. (five uses per run)There are a few "classes", like hunter, "force user" (the force is similar to magic) and pirate, each with his own unique strengths and weaknesses. On your journey you can find statues, which are giving you stat boosts against reducing your level.The stats of weapons and armor you will find aren't visible from the beginning, but are unlocked once you die or pay someone to reveal them. After you die, you can buy new perks and classes with "hero points", you'll get more of them the better your performance was.One of the mechanics I love the most is the "dimensional vault". This useful function allows you, once you bought slots with hero points, to carry your best items over to your next character! I've already created a very overpowered blade with it, sharping and boosting it with scrolls again and again in every run ^_^The screen resolution is low, although I think it's OK. The price is awesome, in my opinion it's very cheap! If you're a miser, for example in summer sale 2014 it was reduced to 75%, but if you want to support the developer buy it full priced.(My first review, I'm not a native speaker.)

content:
Posted: December 1, 2015
												Amazing blend of classic jRPG and rogue-lite. Original, amazingly deep content, interesting and simple mechanics, fair, really all that's needed for a top notch rogue-lite. It does have some limited saves, but I still think it qualifies. The humor is also very good, and the story surprisingly interesting despite how the entire game can be finished in an hour or so. Which is good because that's a type of game you're meant to finish many times to get the many different endings and face the many different daily challenges.The graphics and soundtrack are also good in a 8-bit kind of way, but the real draw is really the gameplay.It's a very solid recommendation for anyone who likes roguelikes and don't mind jRPGs. If you're a fan of jRPGs and can stomach roguelike mechanics, you should also definitely give it a try, it's an experience you have to make. Easily one of my favorite games.

												This is a charming game. It's in the "easy to learn, difficult to master" category. You're being chased across the map by inexorable darkness, which can only be defeated by the death of the Demon Lord! It's your job to wander the land, kill monsters, collect loot, sell it (and if you're like me, feel slightly sad at all the town NPCs who get eaten by the encroaching darkness), and kick some Demon Lord butt so you can unlock new classes and abilities. It's a steal at twice the price. (Twice the price, btw, would still only be like $7. I'm broke these days and can afford this game. Go get it!)

Posted: June 26, 2014
												For the low low price (87 cents as I write this), this game has so much to offer. It's a roguelike and JRPG hybrid, and for the gamer with little time, it's great, as you can finish games very quickly. It's also forgiving to lesser-skilled gamers, as it has difficulty levels, easier and harder dimensions, and persistence between playthroughs with the ability to spend points earned each playthrough on perks, classes, and the ability to transfer items between playthroughs.The art style and music are very charming, and if you like games like the Final Fantasy games for the SNES, you'll love this.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 17, 2014
												Basically a rogue-like with a procrastination prevention method.  The Darkness in the game keeps you continually advancing to the right of screen.  Otherwise you die.  This is a consistent play mechanic.  Otherwise the levels, or "dimensions" are randomly assigned from a large specifically coded database, and the game saves your last 2 recent ones.  So, if you played a dimension you really liked, you can come back to it.  If the next random one generates a virtually impassable mountain range, you can go back to the first one.  I'd recommend keeping a list of the favourable dimensions.You're given a choice of a variety of classes, with more unlockable as you play, with little restriction on equipment.  Nevertheless, some classes are geared to more specific weapons and styles of play than others.  You can also unlock perks that help out in general, and can give that bit of a boost to a class that may otherwise lie outside your usual play style.  You can also save items and equipment to your Dimension Vault to take between playthroughs, but I haven't found anything awesome enough yet to make it worth finding out how to retrieve it.And fear not, those on lunch breaks, there is a save feature.  It does require either buying a Save Crystal item, or finding an NPC who will save your game.  But if you've invested time on especially the higher difficulties, you can come back to a game you may not have had time to finish in one sitting.As far as price and gameplay value go, it gets a thumbs up from me.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												One Way Heroics is an open-world roguelike.  You explore the world from left to right, running away from the darkness that will literally kill you, so be afraid of the dark.  This is a good feature as it prioritizes movement (such as if that chest behind me is worth getting) rather than just attacking.  Combined with terrain effects, like evasion rising in forests, this is a must-have for such a low price (on sale for 87 cents).  I have only seen movement set up in such importance in those grid-based strategy rpg's like Final Fantasy Tactics.  The random story loading up during the first load is an excellent idea too, and it is pretty decent.You have various classes to try out for replay value.  The only issue I have with this game is that hotkeying isn't really mentioned.  I would prefer to have a hotkey for a few items or skills, but that isn't a big deal.  Neither are the tiny graphics because it can immerse you on your very first play.

												I like it. a rougue lite with perma death. It's like a mix of Half Minute Hero and Desktop Dungeon, but with a bit more freedom and longer game sessions - around 20 minutes till the (first?) boss. There is a save feature provided by certain NPCs, so you can experiment during one playthrough and pick it up again at an ealier point - which is very rogue-unlike. Otherwise the meta progression is like in Rogue Legacy and others: You gain points based on your performance and you keep them between sessions  and use them do unlock perks and new classes. GO DIAGONALLY, DON'T GO RIGHT!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 8, 2015
												Really quite a cool little replayable JRPG roguelike with a great personality!  If you enjoy games like Half-Minute Hero and Final Fantasy 1, you'll enjoy this game.  8/8.The replayability feature-set is very similar to Realm of the Mad God.  You gain hero points when you die.  With these hero points you can unlock perks, classes, and add inventory spaces for your "Dimensional Vault".  This is where it really gets interesting.  Upon death, you can choose 1 or more items to put in your "Dimensional Vault" to make them available on the start of your next game.  Found an awesome weapon or armor that you don't want to lose?  Throw it in the vault and start a new game with a powerful item!  You can increase the capacity of the vault by using more hero points!  Very cool concept!

content:
Posted: July 18, 2015
												(/O_O)/  |VVV|  \(O_O\)A unique and easy to learn rogue-like role-playing game. Main gist of the game is that you have to keep going! Why? Behind you all world is falling into the darkness because of the demon lords curse, which you're trying to hunt down. So, taking on this side-scrolling adventure, you have to keep in mind to not waste time on ANYTHING. Yes, don't go into buildings you won't be able to get out of, don't trip, don't fight if you don't have time to and hell don't flirt with the grills, they will vanish in less than a blink. The character design and great humour guarantees some good laughs and is quite refreshing. The price...man, that's almost for free. I can see having spent 50+ hours to play through the basic stuff.So, if you like the art style, rogue-likes or just played a few old rpg's, give this one a try!-I will come back after going real hard on it and see if it holds this awesomeness up!

content:
Posted: July 10, 2015
												Rating: 9/10If you're looking for a roguelike game in an RPG setting, then you will not be disappointed in this game. It offers endless amounts of fun since each game is randomly generated. And to top things off, each game has its own seeded value allowing you to play the same world again if you found it interesting enough!The game has multiplayer in the sense that everyone in the same generated world will be listed at the side of the screen. This makes things interesting as the developers generate daily challenges and list worlds to play on if you wanted a more multiplayer experience.The classes, items, and monsters in the game is solid. The mechanics of climbing mountains and swimming through rivers really create a roguelike atmosphere as moving though the terrain can make your life difficult. So you're forced to path around objects which could force you into bad situations if you're not careful due to the darkness chasing you. The game has different difficulty settings allowing those hardcore roguelike (or RPG) fans to go crazy with their accomplishments.This is a MUST BUY for any RPG fan.

												Simply one of the best deals on Steam. While it's not free-to-play, you know what that means these days? number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 30, 2015
												A distinctly (but not stereotypically) Japanese take on the (real) roguelike. Kill things. Collect utility items. Find good gear, hopefully. Carefully contemplate your options as a cabal of imps breathe down your neck. Probably get killed, or more likely kill yourself in a nearsighted blunder. Every once in a blue moon, reach the the Big Bad only to lose your head to a casually-flung fireball. Every once in a hundred blue moons or so, actually kill the guy. It's simpler than, say, Nethack, but bears more depth than grandaddy Rogue.In true roguelike spirit, there is a leveling system, but progression is heavily biased towards gear, and by extension very random.The advancing wall of doom is a unique spin on the roguelike formula, forcing you to budget your actual turns. Can you make it back to the entrance of the dungeon? You can easily kill the enemy harassing you, but do you have time? It creates a real sense of urgency without imposing actual time limits. You have plenty of time to think... about the 8 turns you have remaining before the darkness consumes you.Another unique mechanic is the final boss periodically shows up and harasses you before running away. It's a double-edged sword; this gives you an opportunity to slay him early, if you got lucky enough or twinked over powerful items from your vault. At the same time, you have to know not just when, but HOW to run. The game does warn you when he'll be showing up soon, so you always get a chance to put your pants back on.And unlike your average roguelike, it's controller-friendly, being largely driven by graphical menus as opposed to keystroke commands.If you like very unusual games, buy it. If you enjoy a proper roguelike, buy it. Hell, it's dirt cheap even without a sale. And quite good.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2015
												Do not be fooled by the cheap price, this game is worth way more than what it's up for. At first i thought it was going to be another cheesy sidescroller game, and boy was I wrong. This game is absolutely fantastic, a real gem, and I'm suprised it's not exploding. The game is fun. Anyways, enough ranting about how fun it is, here's my pros and cons.PROS: Massive replay value. There is a lot of hidden content, and a lot more to the game than what you see on your first clear.Multiple classes for your own style of adventuring. While this may not seem huge, the differences in classes are a lot more diverse than what you think. Join up with a party of a few people, or go completely ham solo with a knight. Choice is yoursGreat soundtrack. Honestly, i really enjoy the music in this game. It's something i can sit down to, and not mute the game for my own music.Difficulty. This game can throw some suprising difficulty at the most unexpected places. I've died at some very unexpected places. There is a lot of strategy into this game. Very good for those who enjoy a challenge.CONS: Well, I haven't run into anything that would deter me or anyone i know away from the game yet, but I'll update this if I do.

content:
Posted: December 1, 2015
												Amazing blend of classic jRPG and rogue-lite. Original, amazingly deep content, interesting and simple mechanics, fair, really all that's needed for a top notch rogue-lite. It does have some limited saves, but I still think it qualifies. The humor is also very good, and the story surprisingly interesting despite how the entire game can be finished in an hour or so. Which is good because that's a type of game you're meant to finish many times to get the many different endings and face the many different daily challenges.The graphics and soundtrack are also good in a 8-bit kind of way, but the real draw is really the gameplay.It's a very solid recommendation for anyone who likes roguelikes and don't mind jRPGs. If you're a fan of jRPGs and can stomach roguelike mechanics, you should also definitely give it a try, it's an experience you have to make. Easily one of my favorite games.

												The cheery beat is what got me into the game and I stayed for the tactful gameplay and progression system. You start off as a character with a little gear and a potted plant worth a kings ransom, if you play it on easy. You basically venture through this wonderful 2-D sidescroller fighting baddies and picking up loot all the way. When you die (and you will) you are allowed to pass items down to your decendents through the use of the vault, an expandable bank for the goodies you pick up in your travels. My only tip is to keep a key of seals on you at all times in the later games and always run from golems. No matter how BA you feel you are... they will destroy you.

content:
Posted: October 23, 2015
												Probably one of my favorite games on Steam.  It's a rogue-like game, except the catch is the screen is always moving to the right, and if you get swallowed by the darkness on the left side of the screen you die.  It does always keep you moving, and makes exploring the small dungeons you may come across rather quick, but that is part of this game's charm.  It is loads of fun, quite challenging, and has tons of different ends.  Since every world is different, no two games will play the same.  I definitely recommend it (it is 3 dollars, technically under a dollar as of the sale at the time of this review) as it is well worth the money.  And if you like the game, the expansion is also well worth the cost and has some excellent additions to the game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 22, 2015
												On sale for less than a dollar, highly reviewed, sure I'll sell a TF2 item and buy it.I looked up 5 hours later after my phone rang. It has been years since I played a game where I did that.This is my very first review ever, in my 3 years of steam. The fact that this game has made me want to write a review is a feat. Enough rambling, to the game.Most 2d tile based rpg lack a real since of progression and story. This is not the case here. I dug deeper into the game, and discovered some secrets that made me cry manly tears. The combat is excellent, and the difficulty is perfect. Easy first difficulty is just hard enough, while the second can still throw a hard curve even to experienced players, but is not frustrating like deaths in minecraft. This game has a storage system you can upgrade to store important items you find on your journey, then use from the beginning on a new world or character. Then there's the random world generation, like Terraria and Minecraft. TL:DRBuy this. It's cheap, and fantastic.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 20, 2015
												To be honest, I was very skeptical when I heard this was a good game. Only after i bought it did I realize that it was true. The game is pretty straight forward and the name doesn't lie; you are forced to move to the right and fight the monsters you come into contact with. Along the way, you may come into contact with some companions that will help you fight. The companions each have their own story and quest that you can complete during your adventure. Collecting food and health items that are scattered throughout the randomly generated map are essential to your survival and can be the deciding factor between victory and a slow failure. There is a begginer mode that lets you fight the final boss after a set amount of time and you get two companions to help you through the battle. The normal mode is actually quite challenging as the final boss will chase you from time to time and the enemies are relentless in their efforts to destroy you. All in all, this game is well worth the money and is fit for those who like to casualy play and for those who like a good challenge from time to time.

												What if I told you there was a game that had used RPG mechanics with a forced side scroling game to DEASTROY THE DEMON LORD? Well, this is it. One Way Heroics is definitely for those who want to play single player.  With infinate number of maps (three of which are challenge/story specific) you will find a lot of replayability and extra content. By yourself you can spend time having some awesome adventures!Pros:  Great SinglePlayer Experience  Decient number of Classes/Perks  Some character persistance between playthroughts  Weapon Upgradability  Under $5  3 different endings revieling more underlying plot and story  Dark Souls-like multiplayer (without the invading part)  Procedually generated "Dimensions/Worlds"   Companion NPC's story lines that are like F***ing roller costers and contribute to the overarching storyline  Difficult, but in a good way.  Ingame accesable dedicated servers (Offline capable)  Tutorial woven into the story, and intuitiveness allows for learning on the fly easilyCons:  No real multiplayer; just messages people leave, or their dead ghosts that help you   Simplistic graphics (It's a WolfRPG-Maker game though. . .  so, duh.)Final Suggestion:  Get It!! number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 28, 2015
												OWH is a roguelike RPG in the shape of one of the old classics. Pick your hero and hack your way through one of the many worlds as you try to save it. You can influence your strengths and weaknesses by selecting different perks that'll allow you to increase your attack/health or other stats. A dimensional vault will allow you to carry on the items of your dead hero unto the next unlucky chap in line. It also bears to mention that OWH has one of the most interesting takes on turn-based combat that I've seen for quite some time. While the game is technically "turn-based", everything happens in real time. Enemies will move as you move, attack as you attack and so forth. If you don't plan ahead, you'll likely find yourself stuck between 5 killer hounds.Due to the random nature of the game, differences in the gameplay between the classes as well as the ability to have maps randomly generated for you, the replay value of this gem is off the charts. Oh, and the difficulty options will allow you to choose between having a quick 20 minute adventure, or an epic struggle for survival that might stretch on for hours.  With the risk of overselling a bit, One Way Heroics has gorgeous aesthetics, fun gameplay and a great soundtrack. I'd recommend this for anyone who enjoys roguelike games, or RPGs with a bit of a twist.

content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
												This is a surprisingly solid title. It's a JRPG turn-based game with roguelike elements. Every decision you make, be it talking or equipping, the darkness moves a tile towards you. If you can't keep the distance from the ever encroaching darkness, you will die. There are varying difficulty levels to try, which presents different kinds of challenges. You can choose among different classes with different playstyles such as Hunter, Pirate, Knight, Bard etcAnd you can unlock perks to customize your classes with or choose to skip them for a greater challenge.Bought it on sale a while ago on chance that it "might" be interesting and I was pleasantly surprised :)The price of this title is really cheap and fans of the genre should definitely give this one a go.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
												At a non sale-price, this is the best game I've ever managed to find for only $3.49.  It's a fair value given the stigma of the RPG Maker engine, but that stigma is easily made up for with the gameplay, UI, and fun dialogue. The idea is that you're exploring a procedurally generated open-world that is being consumed by a darkness that kills everything in its path. With roguelike turn-based combat, this can make for a very challenging game until you spend a few hours onit. You can play the game with permadeath, as appears to be intended, or save, which is discouraged by several penalties. I recommend playing it as a roguelike. There are quite a few characters with different traits to beat the game with, giving it a lot of replay value, even when the game starts to get a bit easier, too, so if you're a roguelike fan, this one may start to occupy quite a bit of your time.At $3.49, this is a great game, as well as a fantastic way to introduce yourself to roguelikes if you're unfamiliar with the combat style. I would suggest anyone pick it up, if not just for the sake of giving it a try.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 19, 2015
												This game is a fun Roguelike dungeon crawler where the entire world is your "dungeon". In this game the world is being engulfed by darkness and you have to outrun it while killing enemies, collecting treasure, and recruiting teammates along the way. Whats more is that each teammate has their own story you gradually learn as they travel with you as well as several alternate endings involving them. The goal of the game is to stop the darkness from spreading which you do by defeating the Dark Lord who appears after 400km (Walk in the park mode) or randomly set distances in every other mode. With Walk in the park (easy) mode the Dark Lord only spawns once but chases you indefinitely until either of you dies while with other modes the Dark Lord will despawn if he doesn't kill you within 3 hours game time (aprox 27 actions) and it's spawn timer will reset.After each attempt win or loose, the dungeon crawler portion of the game kicks in. Your performance will be rated and you will get an amount of hero points based on how well you did. These hero points are used to purchase bonuses to make your future attempts easier such as new perks, more dimensional vault room, and new classes. After your performance is rated if you already have the vault unlocked you are free to move your most important items to the vault which can be withdrawn at the start of your next attempt. I'd also like to point out that this game is very informal both through your fairy companion who answers your questions and through the tips you get if you die which actually analyzes how you diedOverall it's a really fun game I like it

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 11, 2014
												One Way Heroics is one hell of an interesting concept - A mix of 'forced scrolling' RPG concept, as said by the developer, Smoking WOLF, himself on his triumphant Playsim product page:Originally posted by Smoking WOLF: Over time the belief that I could create a fun Forced-Scrolling RPG got stronger, and I decided I’d give developing it a go. The result of that attempt is this game: One Way Heroics.	 I have to say, it is strangely addicting at the least, and the addition of forced scrolling really adds an extra level of depth to an RPG concept. The game plays like a rougelike 8-bit top down JRPG, if you can imagine that - every step you take, and every action you take, a turn is made. The game will then play out the rest of the character on the screen's moves - damage taken, monsters moved, status effects applied. There's a catch, though. The world you are in is subjected by an encroaching 'darkness', which will move from the left edge of the screen by one pixel every turn. A cold, chilling touch from this darkness will send your body flying into the air (or so you're told) and your character will die from what I assume to be asyphxiation from the cold vacuum of space. So effectively, you must plan your next moves, and be sure you aren't trapped or caught fighting, or else succumb to a frosty death. Combat in the game is that of classic rougelike RPGs - press a button to attack, and you will attack in that direction. This makes combat smooth and doesn't impede on the sense of urgency the scrolling darkness imposes. You will soon find yourself trotting along the landscape, uninterupted and fleeting from the ever-infringing darkness. However, it does have the challenge to it - after all, it is a rougelike and will have different layouts if you so choose to play a randomly generated one. Sometimes, the game will throw obstacles in your way that require you to think ahead in order to escape the deathly left edge of the screen - climbing mountains, swimming through water, fighting, breaking down walls will take precious turns, and you must decide weather if you can wing it, or play it safe. What I love about this game and has kept me intrigued is the progression, not only through one game session but across multiple game sessions - a la Rouge Legacy, at the end of each session you will gain 'Hero Points', points that allow you to unlock various different starting perks, and allow you to purchase new classes if you don't want to meet the objectives for unlocking them. From this, I take away a kind of Dark Souls mentality - your starting class is just what you start with, and what you make of your character during the game is up to you, for example I could start with a knight class, which has low agility, but stack agility starting perks to make him agile and combo more hits in an attack turn. This allowed me to decide right at the start of an adventure what kind of character I wanted to play - the treasure hunter, who has a high lockpicking skill, the ranged hero, who is quick to escape, or the tank, who has high vitality. It also has the allure of getting benifits from NPCs, too. There is a gold system in place, and you'll find yourself picking up strewn items (which are abundant) from the floor and selling them for cash at the next town or city you come across. Overall, the game definately hits all the right RPG notes whilst still maintaining action. Characters can have party members, different classes, spells, abilities and must actively manage their time, stamina and energy to escape the darkness and ultimately defeat the demon lord. You can also choose the level of challenge you want, each world you choose will give you the option to play 'A Walk In The Park' mode which pits you against the boss at a certain distance travelled, or 'Afternoon Stroll' where the boss will appear at different intervals. Music will change dynamically depending on the terrain you're in, for example in a dungeon or in a town, and the art style is the classic 8-bit sprite look. If you're a fan of roguelike RPGs like Sword of the Star and Half Minute Hero, then you'll love this game, and the apocalyptic twist of darkness chasing you will add a refreshing approach to the RPG genre. That being said, it is a very unique experience and you'd really have to try it out to understand the game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 13, 2014
												   A great, simple and entertaing Rogue-like rpg with a twist.This games offers engaging sessions of rogue-like adventuring , while being able to persistently unlock new features such as classes, perks and more. While its gameplay mechanics are pretty simple, there are many combinations of randomly-generated equipment, skills and events for you character. Each class is a bit different in terms of gameplay so you'll probably be wanting to try out every available combination of class+perks more than once. The gameplay gets repetitive after a while so I doubt anyone would be playing it 24/7 nonstop, but nevertheless it's a good experience for its price.   One of the few features that caught my eye was a 'Daily Online Challenge' or 'Campaign Dimensions'. Each day the seed is generated for a world where everyone who plays a game can join. While it's impossible to interact directly with other players you can encounter the ghosts of defeated players and read the recent chat logs of other adventurers, how much time they have spent, who killed them and what items they have obtained in this world.   Same with the 'online' adventures, new adventures with different conditions are also generated daily. E.g. The ones where you can recruit a powerful ally, or a world covered in constant darkness, limiting your vision.9/10 will play again.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 17, 2014
												Basically a rogue-like with a procrastination prevention method.  The Darkness in the game keeps you continually advancing to the right of screen.  Otherwise you die.  This is a consistent play mechanic.  Otherwise the levels, or "dimensions" are randomly assigned from a large specifically coded database, and the game saves your last 2 recent ones.  So, if you played a dimension you really liked, you can come back to it.  If the next random one generates a virtually impassable mountain range, you can go back to the first one.  I'd recommend keeping a list of the favourable dimensions.You're given a choice of a variety of classes, with more unlockable as you play, with little restriction on equipment.  Nevertheless, some classes are geared to more specific weapons and styles of play than others.  You can also unlock perks that help out in general, and can give that bit of a boost to a class that may otherwise lie outside your usual play style.  You can also save items and equipment to your Dimension Vault to take between playthroughs, but I haven't found anything awesome enough yet to make it worth finding out how to retrieve it.And fear not, those on lunch breaks, there is a save feature.  It does require either buying a Save Crystal item, or finding an NPC who will save your game.  But if you've invested time on especially the higher difficulties, you can come back to a game you may not have had time to finish in one sitting.As far as price and gameplay value go, it gets a thumbs up from me.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 1, 2014
												"Journal Excerpt No. 5: Hefting my Longsword on my shoulder I sprinted away from the golem. In past lives I have always been killed by golems. This time I hope to escape. I used my awakening power to stop time for a short while so I can easily escape the golem. Finding a small village I ran inside hoping for the guards to save me. The golem took them apart. Suddenly my way was blocked by a mountain pass. There was no way I could scale it in time without taking a dozen hits from the monster. I am doomed. My last thoughts as the golem clobbers me is this, 'I hope that this haracter earns lots of hero points' "This is a very fun rogue-like. Dont be confused about my lack of play time because I have played this before it was released on Steam.Basically it is a rogue-like game that is different in the fact that there are no real dungeons and the "darkness" follows you across the world. Touching the darkness kills you instantly.There is still random treasure and random world generation but it has a different spin on it. Instead of dungeons and narrow, dark pathways, it is a large strip of earth with mountains, water and lava. There are random NPC'S and little monster houses that are filled with enemies and treasure.Each game that you start you choose your characters name, class and up to 3 perks that change the gameplay. Each time that you die (it will happen) you are awarded "Hero Points" based on things like how far your guy got, what level you died at, how many monsters you killed and the like. These Hero Points are used to buy things like more classes, more perks and let you upgrade the amount of slots in this Between-Game inventory. This inventory lets you save OP items and stuff that you got in your last game to be used in your next game. you need to buy the slots though.It isnt a very difficult game to grasp. On my first game my Hero Point score was 3.  By my second my Hero Point score was 8, and by my third my score was 91 due to killing the final boss and being an all-around nice guy. These were all on the easy mode though. The next mode is much harder.For $3.50 I recommend this game for being simple, fun and have tons of replayability.

												Surprisingly fun. I saw this on sale a few times and thought it looked really boring (going in one direction with little plot), but its more than just that. It's difficult to start at first because of the lack of a tutorial and how punishing the game is even early on. After the first few deaths, though, you get the hang of it and it starts to get fun - you can upgrade your weapon infinitely (or at least I've put about 10 upgrades on my sword at one point) and you can recruit different people to your party. Among many other small things, I think this game should be tried and is definitely worth more than the price tag.

content:
Posted: April 21, 2014
												Recently got this game after seeing video of it online and I have to say I'm very pleased already.  This game is deceptively simple, appearing like a normal roguelike in gameplay and presentation, but the more you play the more you learn it has surprising depth of mechanics and writing, getting this for such an astoundingly cheap price is well worth your money.Starting with two available classes - Swordmaster who's good with combo hits and Knight who starts with a shield for extra defence you unlock more classes either by performing certain actions in game or by 'buying' them with the Hero Points you earn after each playthrough.  Hero Points can also be used to unlock new Perks you can add to your character at the start of an adventure or to expand your Dimensional Vault which allows you to store items from characters you've played then give them to a new character to start off stronger - very helpful for the higher, harder difficulties.In short I highly recommend this deceptively simple, tremendously affordable and greatly fun game to anyone a fan of RPGs and Roguelikes.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 20, 2015
												It was hard to understand how the game worked at first, but after a little bit I figured it out. It's a simple game with an interesting concept. You can only move in one direction, hence the title. If you are caught on the far left side of the screen, you can die. So you always have to move forward. Each move causes the screen to move, so the more time you waste in one position, the less time you have to escape the left side of the screen. It sounds weird but you'll understand when you get into the game. Now, the game is simple, you buy equipment, level up, and defeat enemies. It's pretty difficult to fight the first boss at first, but at least you can transfer items from your first playthrough to the next one, making it easier. You can also receruit party members if your charisma is high enough. Just like in Magicite, another permanent death game, the point is to play multiple times to increase your stats and chances of survival. You'll get more bonuses to your character and it'll be easier to move on. The game is great when it's on sale! I think I got it for less than a dollar.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 8, 2014
												If you're looking for an arcade-depth roguelike, you've found it! While it lacks the depth and intricacies of the pure breeds of the genre, such as the classic ADOM or more recent Dungeons of Dredmor, this game delivers familiar mechanics in a session you can begin AND win within an hour. The gimmick is simple, darkness is literally spreading across the land from the left side of the screen to the right, forcing you to run from it at all times. Every encounter or location you try to explore is an opportunity cost, and time is precious. However, failure to probe enough of the world will result in insufficient necessary medical supplies or a total lack of gear in time for the boss fight, should you survive long enough to hike to it. It follows a lot of the genre's standards, such as the world not moving until you take your actions, but since it is more simplistic, it adds something most roguelikes cannot do comfortably: 360 Controller support. Another fun feature is the world is generated by a key phrase, so you can replay a particular map, or seed a new one by letting your cat walk across your keyboard.

content:
Posted: August 9, 2014
												I'm usually a guy that requires graphics and gameplay however occasionally there is a "Super Nintendo" graphic game that comes out and shines for me.  This is one of those games.  Reading the overall concept of the game my first impression was, ok it's a half minute hero redub, And in some ways it does feel like that when you play it.  It really is not though.  Each time you finish a dungeon for better or worse you get points that you can use to unlock new classes, abilities, and storage slots.  This allows you to play as that new class your next play through or maybe carry some gear over from your previous experience.  The world generator while it is random using an 8 digit code that you can even manually control to challenge friends to the same world is fun even if in the end its all the same concept behind things.  There are various terrains as you travel through the different worlds to change up scenery now and again. And when you beat a world it will list off everyone else that had beaten it as well (if anyone) providing you are doing online synch updates.  Mind you the amount of possibilities of worlds is next to endless so unless you are actually writing down codes from friends for challenges you may always be the first one to beat a world.  All in all I give this game a good recommendation.

												I've beaten the end boss twice now and really like the pacing of this game. It's a classic roguelike in that enemies move only when you move / perform some action and the forced scrolling mechanic adds an interesting element to navigation. The average playtime for a successful run is 20-30 minutes, although I've only done the walk in the park mode. The dimensional chest also adds a nice way to store gear for a different class that may drop during your run. Overall I'm very happy and you can't beat the price - 87 cents during the Winter Sale. I'm even considering buying this for a few of my friends to share this gem and help support the dev since they did a stellar job with this.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 6, 2014
												I bought this game on sale for $0.87, and I feel a little bad for doing so because this game is worth much more than its full price.One Way Heroics is, as you probably already know, a scrolling roguelike in which if you get stuck in the darkness, it's game over. I can't speak much to the mechanics here - they are standard roguelike mechanics and, while there are a few imaginative additions (pills of teleportation, buddy tablets, etc), the game plays essentially like the standard roguelike. The gameplay is solid, and outperforms many other well-recognized roguelikes, but doesn't attempt to re-invent the genre.The charm of the game is in how well it is built. I enjoy the music and the look and feel of the world, as well as the characters (most of whom only have a few lines of dialogue). The world feels varied and interesting thanks to a variety of enemies and enemy modifiers, multiple area types (such as mountainous regions that force careful movement planning or deserts that drain energy), and NPC encounters. The fact that the game will generate a world based on an alphanumeric codeword is also a plus, since it can make every run different. To sum up: Aside from the scrolling mechanic, the game doesn't do anything new or different. But it doesn't really have to. It's well put-together, carries its own brand of charm, and it's definitely worth the $3 pricetag.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 1, 2015
												One Way Heroics might look like a cheap and generic jrpg made in rpg-maker but it's definitely not the case.The game is a procedurally generated turn-based roguelike with many interesting features. One of the most noticable ones is that the game takes place on a world map, each move will take you one turn and the darkness on the left side of the screen will draw closer. Basically as you move and battle across the world, darkness will consume everything behind you. Be it an enemy, friendly npc, objects or the entire terrain. You have to avoid it at all costs. During your journey you can find various loot and treasures. From simple weapons and armors up to supplies and precious magic scrolls. The rpg mechanics are fairly generic, you defeat enemies and gain level points which can be spent later on cetain spots on the map. Although you still increase your stats normally by gaining experience. Various weapons and armors have different attributes. Scrolls and magic items might have special abilities, pretty much the usual roguelike stuff.Combat is extremely simple and only requires you to attack the enemy by pressing one key, then a series of dice rolls will determine everything. It's not that engaging but yet very enjoyable mainly due to the smooth controls and fast pace of the game. Your character has certain special abilities though that require stamina points which are automatically generated as long as your energy is high enough. Energy is another ressource and acts mostly as a starvation meter. You lose energy with each term and depending on the terrain, you might lose even more. You refill your energy by consuming various food items.Now let me explain the goal of the game and perhaps one of it's more compelling features. As soon as you start a new run, your goal is to defeat the Demon Lord which appears in 400km in the world map. During those 400km, you want to level up and get the most loot in order to prepare for the final encounter. But due to the darkness, time  management is vital and you have to carefully plan ahead your moves. Even if the combat is simple, there are many things to take into factor. For instance various terrain types can give you additional bonues/mali, some enemies are more resistant than others to various weapons. Furthermore with the spreading darkness, you really want to make the combat the most efficent as possible. Turning it into somewhat of a puzzle game. During your journey, you can also meet tons of charactets that have their own quests, some may join you on your journey. Others provide services or act as merchants. Finally there is a lot of variety and content in this game, there are tons of classes and things to unlock. Each generated map feels really unique and offers different challenges.Also the game let's you save items that your next character can chose right at the start of a new run. So there is some progression in this game, furthermore you can spent a rare currency to save at certain points of the maps.To conclude, there is a lot to talk about but this game is definitely a blast to play and offers something refreshing to the roguelike formula. It really conveys a sense of adventure.

												One Way Heroics emulates the aesthetic of old school JRPGs without feeling like it’s trying too hard to recapture nostalgia. With each procedurally generated world, each combination of Perks and Classes, and each difficulty level, there are infinite gameplay experiences possible. If you’re a fan of sprite-based JRPGs and want a break from traditional turn-based combat and random battles, I would highly suggest you check out One Way Heroics. The simplicity of the game makes it easy to get into and hard to put down, creating an experience that borders on addiction.

												Love it. I wanted to punch it. I couldn't stand the fact I had to have a 4:3 aspect ratio. The graphics were pretty average. Then I played it through a few times, got off my high horse and realised a few things.First, they way they've designed it, you need to maintain a 4:3 ratio. widescreen would change the scrolling field of view and actually change the game, making it easier. So, i moved on from that.Then I moved on from the graphics. After all - I still play Master of Magic. Sure, that game is 21 years old and this game is the ripe old age of 1, but hey - the old adage that playability trumps graphics is alive and well.The other comment to make is the balance. Some rogue-likes out at the moment are really hard. Fun, but searingly hard. This one is still damn hard, but play it through a few times and you can absolutely get your wins. Loving it. And it's crazy good value! Particularly right now. It's on sale for $1.18. That's just stupid. As in, stupidly good. You pay more than that for a piece of crap on the iTunes store... AND you then need to give them $25 just to actually be buffed enough to win. Summary: A nice indie gamer. Fun. Replayable. Easy to get into but with a bit of depth. You win some, you lose some, and it's all gravy!
